eng: The suburb of Saffron Park lay on the sunset side of London, as red and ragged as a cloud of sunset.
fr: Le faubourg de Saffron Park s'etendait a l'est de Londres, rouge et dechire comme un nuage au couchant,

eng: Weak if we were and foolish, not thus we failed, not thus; When that black Baal blocked the heavens he had no hymns from us (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They twisted even decent sin to shapes not to be named: Men were ashamed of honour; but we were not ashamed. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Life was a fly that faded, and death a drone that stung; The world was very old indeed when you and I were young. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Like the white lock of Whistler, that lit our aimless gloom, Men showed their own white feather as proudly as a plume. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Round us in antic order their crippled vices came Lust that had lost its laughter, fear that had lost its shame. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Science announced nonentity and art admired decay; The world was old and ended: but you and I were gay; (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Children we were our forts of sand were even as weak as we, High as they went we piled them up to break that bitter sea. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: A cloud was on the mind of men, and wailing went the weather, Yea, a sick cloud upon the soul when we were boys together. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He said that he (Syme) was poet of law, a poet of order; nay, he said he was a poet of respectability.
fr: Syme se donna pour le poete de la Loi, le poete de l'Ordre, -- bien plus : le poete des Convenances.

eng: He signalised his entrance by differing with the established poet, Gregory, upon the whole nature of poetry.
fr: Son entree fut signalee par un differend entre lui et le poete etabli, Gregory, sur la nature meme de la poesie.

eng: But an impression grew that he was less meek than he looked.
fr: On le soupconnait, toutefois, assez vite d'etre moins doux qu'il n'en avait l'air.

eng: The new poet, who introduced himself by the name of Gabriel Syme was a very mild-looking mortal, with a fair, pointed beard and faint, yellow hair.
fr: Le nouveau poete, qui se presentait sous le nom de Gabriel Syme, avait les apparences d'un mortel de moeurs fort douces. Les cheveux d'or pale ; la barbe blonde, taillee en pointe.

eng: For a long time the red-haired revolutionary had reigned without a rival; it was upon the night of the sunset that his solitude suddenly ended.
fr: Longtemps le revolutionnaire aux cheveux rouges avait regne sans rival. Le soir du fameux coucher de soleil, sa solitude prit subitement fin.

eng: There are others who may remember it because it marked the first appearance in the place of the second poet of Saffron Park.
fr: les autres, parce qu'elle marqua l'apparition d'un second poete a Saffron Park.

eng: So all the Saffron Parkers looked at him as if he had that moment fallen out of that impossible sky.
fr: Les gens de Saffron Park le regarderent avec stupeur, comme s'il venait de tomber de l'impossible ciel de ce soir-la.

eng: I say that there are some inhabitants who may remember the evening if only by that oppressive sky.
fr: Les uns, donc, se rappelleront cette soiree a cause de l'oppression que faisait peser le ciel ;

eng: Fools as we were in motley, all jangling and absurd, When all church bells were silent our cap and bells were heard. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I find again the book we found, I feel the hour that flings Far out of fish-shaped Paumanok some cry of cleaner things; (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: To Edmund Clerihew Bentley (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: G. K. C. CHAPTER I. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We have found common things at last and marriage and a creed, And I may safely write it now, and you may safely read. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Between us, by the peace of God, such truth can now be told; Yea, there is strength in striking root and good in growing old. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The doubts that drove us through the night as we two talked amain, And day had broken on the streets e'er it broke upon the brain. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The doubts that were so plain to chase, so dreadful to withstand Oh, who shall understand but you; yea, who shall understand? (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Not all unhelped we held the fort, our tiny flags unfurled; Some giants laboured in that cloud to lift it from the world. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Of what colossal gods of shame could cow men and yet crash, Of what huge devils hid the stars, yet fell at a pistol flash. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: We have seen the City of Mansoul, even as it rocked, relieved Blessed are they who did not see, but being blind, believed. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: God and the good Republic come riding back in arms: (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: But we were young; we lived to see God break their bitter charms. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Yea, cool and clear and sudden as a bird sings in the grey, Dunedin to Samoa spoke, and darkness unto day. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Or sane and sweet and sudden as a bird sings in the rain Truth out of Tusitala spoke and pleasure out of pain. (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: And the Green Carnation withered, as in forest fires that pass, Roared in the wind of all the world ten million leaves of grass; (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: This is a tale of those old fears, even of those emptied hells, And none but you shall understand the true thing that it tells (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The very sky seemed small.
fr: le ciel meme paraissait petit.

eng: It expressed that splendid smallness which is the soul of local patriotism.
fr: Il etait l'image et l'expression de cette splendide petitesse qui est l'ame du patriotisme local :

eng: The very empyrean seemed to be a secret.
fr: L'empyree tout entier semblait l'expression d'un secret impenetrable.

eng: A man who stepped into its social atmosphere felt as if he had stepped into a written comedy.
fr: On avait, en y entrant, l'impression qu'on allait prendre part a quelque comedie.

eng: Thus, and thus only, the whole place had properly to be regarded; it had to be considered not so much as a workshop for artists, but as a frail but finished work of art.
fr: Voila, disons-nous, le bon point de vue d'ou il convenait d'observer le faubourg de Saffron Park : non pas un atelier d'artistes, mais une oeuvre d'art, delicate et parfaite.

eng: He had not discovered anything new in biology; but what biological creature could he have discovered more singular than himself?
fr: il n'a fait aucune decouverte en biologie : mais n'est-il pas lui-meme la plus extraordinaire creature que puissent etudier les biologistes ?

eng: That scientific gentleman with the bald, egg-like head and the bare, bird-like neck had no real right to the airs of science that he assumed.
fr: Ce personnage aux apparences doctorales, au crane chauve et brillant comme un oeuf, au long cou decharne comme celui d'un oiseau, n'a aucun droit aux dehors de savant qu'il se donne ;

eng: That old gentleman with the wild, white beard and the wild, white hat that venerable humbug was not really a philosopher; but at least he was the cause of philosophy in others.
fr: Ce vieux monsieur, avec sa vaste barbe sauvage et son vaste et sauvage chapeau, ce venerable charlatan, ce n'est pas un philosophe : c'est un theme de philosophie.

eng: That young man with the long, auburn hair and the impudent face that young man was not really a poet; but surely he was a poem.
fr: Ce jeune homme, par exemple, avec ses longs cheveux chatains et sa mine impertinente, ne voyez pas en lui un poete : c'est un poeme.

eng: More especially this attractive unreality fell upon it about nightfall, when the extravagant roofs were dark against the afterglow and the whole insane village seemed as separate as a drifting cloud.
fr: Ce charme de l'irreel etait surtout sensible le soir, quand les toits bizarres se decoupaient en valeurs sombres sur le couchant et que tout le chimerique endroit se detachait, en quelque sorte, visiblement du monde ordinaire, comme une nuee flotte dans le ciel.

eng: Even if the people were not "artists," the whole was nevertheless artistic.
fr: Si ce n'etaient pas des artistes qui habitaient la, l'ensemble n'en avait pas moins un caractere artiste.

eng: Nor when he met the people was he disappointed in this respect.
fr: Et, s'il rencontrait l'un d'eux, son impression n'en etait pas modifiee.

eng: The stranger who looked for the first time at the quaint red houses could only think how very oddly shaped the people must be who could fit in to them.
fr: L'etranger, qui jetait pour la premiere fois un regard sur ces curieuses maisons rouges, devait faire sans doute quelque effort d'imagination pour se representer la structure singuliere de leurs habitants.

eng: But although its pretensions to be an intellectual centre were a little vague, its pretensions to be a pleasant place were quite indisputable.
fr: Endroit fort agreable, d'ailleurs, si ses pretentions au titre de centre intellectuel pouvaient passer pour exagerees.

eng: It was described with some justice as an artistic colony, though it never in any definable way produced any art.
fr: Dans le public, on traitait ce faubourg de colonie d'artistes. Non qu'aucun art y fut particulierement cultive, mais l'aspect, l'atmosphere en etait << artiste >>.

eng: It had been the outburst of a speculative builder, faintly tinged with art, who called its architecture sometimes Elizabethan and sometimes Queen Anne, apparently under the impression that the two sovereigns were identical.
fr: On devait cette creation a la fantaisie d'un speculateur audacieux, qui possedait quelque vague teinture d'art. Il qualifiait l'architecture de son faubourg tantot de << style Elizabeth >>, tantot de << style reine Anne >> ; sans doute, dans sa pensee, les deux souveraines n'en faisaient qu'une.

eng: It was built of a bright brick throughout; its sky-line was fantastic, and even its ground plan was wild.
fr: toutes construites en briques claires. Le sol meme en etait etrangement tourmente.

eng: The place was not only pleasant, but perfect, if once he could regard it not as a deception but rather as a dream.
fr: Cet endroit etait non seulement agreable, il etait parfait pour peu qu'on le considerat non comme truque mais plutot comme un reve.

eng: This again was more strongly true of the many nights of local festivity, when the little gardens were often illuminated, and the big Chinese lanterns glowed in the dwarfish trees like some fierce and monstrous fruit.
fr: Ce charme etait, veritablement, irresistible les soirs de fete locale, quand de grosses lanternes venitiennes, fruits monstrueux des arbres nains, illuminaient les jardinets.

eng: And this was strongest of all on one particular evening, still vaguely remembered in the locality, of which the auburn-haired poet was the hero.
fr: Et ce charme fut plus sensible, plus irresistible que jamais, un certain soir dont on se souvient encore dans le voisinage et dont le poete aux cheveux chatains fut le heros.

eng: It was not by any means the only evening of which he was the hero.
fr: Il avait ete, du reste, le heros de bien d'autres soirs avant celui-la.

eng: The whole was so close about the earth, as to express nothing but a violent secrecy.
fr: Et tout cela etait si rapproche du sol qu'on ne pouvait s'expliquer le phenomene.

eng: Across the great part of the dome they were grey, with the strangest tints of violet and mauve and an unnatural pink or pale green; but towards the west the whole grew past description, transparent and passionate, and the last red-hot plumes of it covered up the sun like something too good to be seen.
fr: Au milieu du dome celeste, ces plumes etaient grises, avec de bizarres touches de violet, de mauve, de rose, de vert pale invraisemblablement. Mais il est impossible de rendre la transparence et le ton passionne de l'occident ; les dernieres plumes, d'un rouge feu, couvraient le soleil comme une chose trop belle pour que personne meritat de la voir.

eng: All the heaven seemed covered with a quite vivid and palpable plumage; you could only say that the sky was full of feathers, and of feathers that almost brushed the face.
fr: Tout le ciel paraissait couvert d'un plumage palpable et vivant. Un ciel plein de plumes, de plumes qu'on croyait sentir vous effleurer le visage.

eng: It looked like the end of the world.
fr: Un coucher de soleil de fin du monde.

eng: This particular evening, if it is remembered for nothing else, will be remembered in that place for its strange sunset.
fr: La soiree dont il s'agit restera memorable tout au moins par son etonnant coucher de soleil.

eng: This combination at once tickled and terrified the nerves of a neurotic population.
fr: Ce contraste surexcitait jusqu'a la peur une galerie de femmes neurastheniques : elles goutaient ce blaspheme vivant, cette combinaison d'ange et de singe.

eng: From within this almost saintly oval, however, his face projected suddenly broad and brutal, the chin carried forward with a look of cockney contempt.
fr: Mais de ce cadre mystique jaillissait une face large et brutale ; le menton avancait avec une expression meprisante qui sentait le cockney.

eng: His dark red hair parted in the middle was literally like a woman's, and curved into the slow curls of a virgin in a pre-Raphaelite picture.
fr: Ses cheveux d'un rouge sombre, separes au milieu, etaient longs comme des cheveux de femme ; ils bouclaient en decrivant les molles courbes dont les peintres preraphaelites ne manquent pas d'agrementer les chevelures de leurs Vierges.

eng: He was helped in some degree by the arresting oddity of his appearance, which he worked, as the phrase goes, for all it was worth.
fr: L'originalite de son aspect physique le servait a souhait, et il savait en jouer, en connaissant la valeur.

eng: He put the old cant of the lawlessness of art and the art of lawlessness with a certain impudent freshness which gave at least a momentary pleasure.
fr: Il debitait la vieille fable de l'anarchie de l'art et de l'art de l'anarchie avec une certaine fraicheur, un ragout d'insolence ou l'on pouvait trouver quelque bref agrement.

eng: And Mr. Lucian Gregory, the red-haired poet, was really (in some sense) a man worth listening to, even if one only laughed at the end of it.
fr: A vrai dire, M. Lucien Gregory meritait qu'on l'ecoutat, ne fut-ce que pour rire, ensuite, de ses discours.

eng: Yet these new women would always pay to a man the extravagant compliment which no ordinary woman ever pays to him, that of listening while he is talking.
fr: Or, ces personnes << nouvelles >> etaient toujours disposees a vous accorder cet honneur que jamais aucune femme ordinaire n'accorde a aucun homme : elles vous ecoutaient tandis que vous parliez.

eng: Most of the women were of the kind vaguely called emancipated, and professed some protest against male supremacy.
fr: Elles appartenaient presque toutes -- je parle de celles qui habitaient le faubourg -- a la categorie des emancipees, et faisaient en consequence profession de protester contre la suprematie du male.

eng: The attitude of women in such cases was indeed one of the paradoxes of the place.
fr: L'attitude des femmes, dans ces occasions, etait meme fort remarquable.

eng: On many nights those passing by his little back garden might hear his high, didactic voice laying down the law to men and particularly to women.
fr: Il ne se passait guere de jour qu'on ne put entendre, des le crepuscule tombe, la voix haute et professorale de ce jeune homme dicter, du fond de son petit jardin, des lois a l'humanite entiere, et plus particulierement aux femmes.

eng: A NIGHTMARE (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: THE TWO POETS OF SAFFRON PARK (No direct equivalent in text)
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: In fact, Mr. Lucian Gregory, the anarchic poet, connected the two events. ~~~ "It may well be," he said, in his sudden lyrical manner, "it may well be on such a night of clouds and cruel colours that there is brought forth upon the earth such a portent as a respectable poet.
fr: M. Lucien Gregory, le poete anarchiste, remarqua expressement qu'il y avait entre les deux phenomenes un rapport : -- Sans doute, dit-il a sa facon brusque et lyrique, sans doute il fallait une soiree comme celle-ci, il fallait ces nuages aux couleurs cruelles pour que se montrat a la terre un monstre tel qu'un poete convenable.

eng: You say you are a poet of law; I say you are a contradiction in terms.
fr: Vous dites que vous etes le poete de la loi : je dis que vous etes une contradiction dans les termes.

eng: I only wonder there were not comets and earthquakes on the night you appeared in this garden."
fr: Je m'etonne que nulle comete et pas le moindre tremblement de terre n'ait annonce votre presence dans ce jardin.

eng: The man with the meek blue eyes and the pale, pointed beard endured these thunders with a certain submissive solemnity.
fr: L'homme aux doux yeux bleus et a la pale barbe en pointe se laissa foudroyer d'un air soumis et solennel.

eng: The third party of the group, Gregory's sister Rosamond, who had her brother's braids of red hair, but a kindlier face underneath them, laughed with such mixture of admiration and disapproval as she gave commonly to the family oracle.
fr: Une troisieme personne du groupe, Rosamonde, la soeur de Gregory, qui avait des cheveux tout pareils a ceux de son frere, mais un visage plus agreable, eclata de rire, et dans le ton de ce rire, elle mit ce melange d'admiration et de desapprobation qu'elle eprouvait pour l'oracle de la famille.

eng: Gregory resumed in high oratorical good humour. ~~~ "An artist is identical with an anarchist," he cried. ~~~ "You might transpose the words anywhere.
fr: Gregory reprit, avec l'aisance et la bonne humeur d'un orateur de grand style : -- Artiste, anarchiste ; personnages identiques, termes interchangeables.

eng: An anarchist is an artist. ~~~ The man who throws a bomb is an artist, because he prefers a great moment to everything.
fr: L'homme qui jette une bombe est un artiste, parce qu'il prefere a toutes choses la beaute d'un grand instant.

eng: He sees how much more valuable is one burst of blazing light, one peal of perfect thunder, than the mere common bodies of a few shapeless policemen.
fr: Il sait qu'un jet eblouissant de lumiere, un coup de tonnerre harmonieux ont plus de prix que les corps vulgaires de quelques informes policemen.

eng: An artist disregards all governments, abolishes all conventions.
fr: L'artiste nie tous les gouvernements, abolit toutes les conventions.

eng: The poet delights in disorder only.
fr: Le desordre, voila l'atmosphere necessaire du poete.

eng: If it were not so, the most poetical thing in the world would be the Underground Railway.
fr: Si je me trompais, il faudrait donc dire que le metropolitain de Londres est la chose la plus poetique du monde !

eng: "So it is," said Mr. Syme.
fr: -- Il faut le dire, en effet, repliqua Syme.

eng: "Why do all the clerks and navvies in the railway trains look so sad and tired, so very sad and tired?
fr: -- Pourquoi, continua-t-il, tous les employes, tous les ouvriers qui prennent le metropolitain ont-ils l'air si triste et si fatigue, si profondement triste et fatigue ?

eng: I will tell you.
fr: Je vais vous le dire.

eng: It is because after they have passed Sloane Square they know that the next station must be Victoria, and nothing but Victoria.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent qu'apres Sloane Street la prochaine station sera Victoria et jamais une autre que Victoria.

eng: It is because they know that the train is going right.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent que le train va comme il faut.

eng: Oh, their wild rapture! oh, their eyes like stars and their souls again in Eden, if the next station were unaccountably Baker Street!"
fr: Oh ! quel ravissement, comme tous ces yeux morts jetteraient soudain des rayons, comme toutes ces ames mornes seraient emparadisees, si la prochaine station, sans qu'on put dire pourquoi, etait Baker Street !

eng: It is because they know that whatever place they have taken a ticket for that place they will reach.
fr: C'est parce qu'ils savent qu'ils arriveront a la station pour laquelle ils ont pris leur billet.

eng: "Nonsense!" said Gregory, who was very rational when anyone else attempted paradox.
fr: '-- Ridicule ! Non-sens ! ~~~ s'ecria Gregory qui devenait tout a coup tres raisonnable des qu'un autre se permettait devant lui quelque paradoxe.

eng: "It is you who are unpoetical," replied the poet Syme.
fr: -- C'est vous qui manquez de poesie, repliqua Syme.

eng: But man is a magician, and his whole magic is in this, that he does say Victoria, and lo!
fr: L'homme n'est un magicien que parce qu'il peut aller a Victoria, ayant dit : Je veux aller a Victoria.

eng: Chaos is dull; because in chaos the train might indeed go anywhere, to Baker Street or to Bagdad.
fr: Le chaos est stupide, et, que le train aille a Baker Street ou a Bagdad ou n'importe ou quand c'est a Victoria qu'il devrait aller, c'est le chaos.

eng: "If what you say of clerks is true, they can only be as prosaic as your poetry.
fr: Si ce que vous dites des employes est vrai, c'est qu'ils sont aussi prosaiques que votre poesie.

eng: The rare, strange thing is to hit the mark; the gross, obvious thing is to miss it.
fr: Le rare, le merveilleux, c'est d'atteindre le but ; le vulgaire, le normal, c'est de le manquer.

eng: We feel it is epical when man with one wild arrow strikes a distant bird.
fr: Nous admirons comme un beau poeme epique qu'un homme d'une fleche tiree de son arc frappe un oiseau, loin dans le ciel.

eng: Is it not also epical when man with one wild engine strikes a distant station?
fr: N'est-il pas tout aussi epique que l'homme au moyen d'une sauvage machine atteigne une lointaine station ?

eng: it is Victoria. ~~~ No, take your books of mere poetry and prose; let me read a time table, with tears of pride.
fr: Gardez pour vous vos livres de vers ou de prose ; moi, je verserai des larmes d'orgueil en lisant un horaire.

eng: Take your Byron, who commemorates the defeats of man; give me Bradshaw, who commemorates his victories.
fr: Gardez votre Byron qui commemore les defaites des hommes, et donnez-moi l'horaire de Bradshaw qui raconte leurs victoires,

eng: "Must you go?" inquired Gregory sarcastically.
fr: Allez-vous loin ? demanda Gregory sarcastique.

eng: Give me Bradshaw, I say!
fr: donnez-moi l'horaire, entendez-vous !

eng: "I tell you," went on Syme with passion, "that every time a train comes in I feel that it has broken past batteries of besiegers, and that man has won a battle against chaos.
fr: -- Je vous l'assure, continua Syme avec ardeur, chaque fois qu'un train arrive en gare, j'ai le sentiment qu'il s'est fraye son chemin sous le feu d'innombrables batteries ennemies et que l'homme a vaincu le chaos.

eng: You say contemptuously that when one has left Sloane Square one must come to Victoria. ~~~ I say that one might do a thousand things instead, and that whenever I really come there I have the sense of hairbreadth escape.
fr: Vous trouvez pitoyable qu'apres avoir quitte Sloane Street on arrive necessairement a Victoria ; et moi, je vous dis qu'on pourrait fort bien ne jamais arriver a Victoria, qu'il est merveilleux qu'on y arrive et qu'en y arrivant je me felicite d'avoir echappe de tres pres a mille malheurs. ~~~ Victoria !

eng: 'And when I hear the guard shout out the word Victoria,' it is not an unmeaning word.
fr: 'Ce n'est pas un mot depourvu de sens, pour moi, quand c'est le conducteur qui le crie !'

eng: 'It is to me indeed Victoria'; it is the victory of Adam."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'It is to me the cry of a herald announcing conquest.'
fr: 'C'est pour moi le cri du heraut annoncant la victoire : la victoire d'Adam !'

eng: 'Gregory wagged his heavy, red head with a slow and sad smile.'
fr: 'Gregory, lentement, branla sa lourde tete fauve, en souriant avec melancolie.'

eng: "And even then," he said, "we poets always ask the question, And what is Victoria now that you have got there?'
fr: -- Et nous, dit-il, nous autres, les poetes, en arrivant a Victoria, nous nous disons : << Qu'est-ce donc que Victoria, maintenant que nous y sommes ?

eng: You think Victoria is like the New Jerusalem. ~~~ We know that the New Jerusalem will only be like Victoria.
fr: >> Victoria vous apparait comme la Jerusalem Nouvelle : et nous, la Jerusalem Nouvelle nous apparait simplement comme une autre et toute pareille Victoria.

eng: Yes, the poet will be discontented even in the streets of heaven.
fr: Oui, meme dans les rues du ciel, le poete restera mecontent.

eng: The poet is always in revolt."
fr: Le poete est l'eternel revolte.

eng: "There again," said Syme irritably, "what is there poetical about being in revolt?
fr: -- Encore une fois, s'ecria Syme irrite, qu'y a-t-il de poetique dans la revolte ?

eng: You might as well say that it is poetical to be sea-sick.
fr: Autant dire que le mal de mer est poetique !

eng: Being sick is a revolt.
fr: La maladie est une revolte.

eng: Both being sick and being rebellious may be the wholesome thing on certain desperate occasions; but I'm hanged if I can see why they are poetical.
fr: Dans certains cas desesperes, il se peut que la maladie et la revolte soient des signes de sante, mais que je sois pendu si j'y vois la moindre poesie !

eng: Revolt in the abstract is revolting.
fr: La revolte en elle-meme est revoltante.

eng: It's mere vomiting."
fr: Ce n'est qu'un vomissement.

eng: "It is things going right," he cried, "that is poetical! Our digestions, for instance, going sacredly and silently right, that is the foundation of all poetry.
fr: C'est le cours normal des choses qui est poetique ! La digestion, par exemple, qui s'accomplit a souhait dans un silence sacre, voila le principe de toute poesie.

eng: The girl winced for a flash at the unpleasant word, but Syme was too hot to heed her.
fr: La jeune fille, a ce mot choquant, fit la grimace, mais Syme etait trop emporte pour y prendre garde.

eng: Yes, the most poetical thing, more poetical than the flowers, more poetical than the stars the most poetical thing in the world is not being sick."
fr: Oui, la chose la plus poetique, plus poetique que les fleurs, plus poetique que les etoiles, la chose la plus poetique du monde, c'est de n'etre point malade !

eng: "Really," said Gregory superciliously, "the examples you choose " "I beg your pardon," said Syme grimly, "I forgot we had abolished all conventions."
fr: -- Vraiment, observa Gregory avec hauteur, les exemples que vous choisissez... -- Je vous demande pardon, dit Syme amerement, j'avais oublie que toutes les conventions etaient abolies entre nous.

eng: For the first time a red patch appeared on Gregory's forehead.
fr: Pour la premiere fois, le rouge monta au front de Gregory.

eng: "You don't expect me," he said, "to revolutionise society on this lawn?"
fr: '-- Vous n'attendez pas de moi, fit-il, que je revolutionne la societe sur cette pelouse !'

eng: Syme looked straight into his eyes and smiled sweetly.
fr: Syme le regarda en face et sourit :

eng: "No, I don't," he said; "but I suppose that if you were serious about your anarchism, that is exactly what you would do."
fr: '-- Non, je ne vous demande rien de tel. C'est pourtant ce que vous feriez, je pense, si vous etiez un anarchiste serieux.'

eng: Gregory's big bull's eyes blinked suddenly like those of an angry lion, and one could almost fancy that his red mane rose.
fr: Les gros yeux de taureau de Gregory jeterent un eclair, et l'on aurait cru voir sa criniere fauve se herisser.

eng: "Don't you think, then," he said in a dangerous voice, "that I am serious about my anarchism?"
fr: -- Vous pensez donc, s'ecria-t-il d'une voix mauvaise, que je ne suis pas un anarchiste serieux ?

eng: "I beg your pardon?" said Syme.
fr: '-- Plait-il ? fit Syme.'

eng: "Am I not serious about my anarchism?" cried Gregory, with knotted fists.
fr: '-- Oui ou non, suis-je un anarchiste serieux ? interrogea Gregory en serrant les poings.'

eng: "My dear fellow!" said Syme, and strolled away.
fr: '-- Mon cher garcon !... dit Syme. ~~~ Et il s'eloigna.'

eng: With surprise, but with a curious pleasure, he found Rosamond Gregory still in his company.
fr: 'Avec surprise, mais non sans plaisir, il vit Rosamonde se lever pour l'accompagner.'

eng: "Mr. Syme," she said, "do the people who talk like you and my brother often mean what they say? Do you mean what you say now?"
fr: '-- Monsieur Syme, dit-elle en le rejoignant, les gens qui parlent comme vous et mon frere pensent-ils souvent ce qu'ils disent ? Pensez-vous vous-meme ce que vous venez de dire ?'

eng: Now, sometimes a man like your brother really finds a thing he does mean. It may be only a half-truth, quarter-truth, tenth-truth; but then he says more than he means from sheer force of meaning it.
fr: 'Eh bien, il arrive parfois qu'un homme comme votre frere finisse par trouver quelque chose qu'il pense reellement. Peut-etre n'est-ce qu'a demi vrai, au quart, au dixieme : mais il le dit avec plus de force qu'il ne le pense, -- a force d'y penser.'

eng: "What do you mean?" asked the girl, with grave eyes.
fr: '-- Comment l'entendez-vous ? fit la jeune fille, et il y avait de la gravite dans son regard.'

eng: "My dear Miss Gregory," said Syme gently, "there are many kinds of sincerity and insincerity.
fr: '-- Chere miss Gregory, dit Syme doucement, la sincerite et l'insincerite ont bien des formes !'

eng: When you say 'thank you' for the salt, do you mean what you say?
fr: 'Quand vous dites : << Merci ! >> a la personne qui vous passe le sel, pensez-vous ce que vous dites ?'

eng: No.
fr: 'Non.'

eng: When you say 'the world is round,' do you mean what you say?
fr: 'Quand vous dites : << La terre est ronde, >> pensez-vous ce que vous dites ?'

eng: No.
fr: 'Non.'

eng: It is true, but you don't mean it.
fr: 'ce que vous dites alors est vrai, mais vous ne le pensez pas.'

eng: "Do you?" he asked.
fr: '-- Pensez-vous vous-meme ce que vous dites ? demanda-t-il.'

eng: Syme smiled.
fr: 'Syme sourit.'

eng: She was looking at him from under level brows; her face was grave and open, and there had fallen upon it the shadow of that unreasoning responsibility which is at the bottom of the most frivolous woman, the maternal watch which is as old as the world.
fr: Elle le regardait de dessous ses sourcils egaux ; son visage etait serieux et franc : on y lisait la preoccupation instinctive de la responsabilite, qui est au fond de la femme la plus frivole, cette sollicitude maternelle, aussi vieille que le monde.

eng: "Is he really an anarchist, then?" ~~~ she asked.
fr: -- Enfin, interrogea-t-elle encore, est-il vraiment un anarchiste ?

eng: "Only in that sense I speak of," replied Syme; "or if you prefer it, in that nonsense."
fr: -- Au sens restreint que je viens de dire, oui, et ce sens est insense.

eng: She drew her broad brows together and said abruptly "He wouldn't really use bombs or that sort of thing?"
fr: Le front de Rosamonde se crispa, et brusquement : -- Il ne jettera donc pas de... de bombe, ou quoi que ce soit de ce genre, dit-elle.

eng: "Good Lord, no!" he said, "that has to be done anonymously."
fr: -- Seigneur ! s'ecria-t-il, certes non ! Cela ne se fait que sous l'anonymat.

eng: Syme broke into a great laugh, that seemed too large for his slight and somewhat dandified figure.
fr: Syme eclata d'un rire enorme qui paraissait trop fort pour sa frele stature, d'un rire excessif pour le dandy qu'il etait un peu.

eng: And at that the corners of her own mouth broke into a smile, and she thought with a simultaneous pleasure of Gregory's absurdity and of his safety.
fr: Rosamonde rit aussi. ~~~ Elle pensait avec plaisir a la fois que Gregory etait absurde et qu'il ne se compromettrait pas.

eng: Syme strolled with her to a seat in the corner of the garden, and continued to pour out his opinions.
fr: Ils firent quelques pas ensemble et gagnerent un banc dans un coin du jardin. ~~~ Syme continuait a developper avec abondance ses opinions.

eng: For he was a sincere man, and in spite of his superficial airs and graces, at root a humble one.
fr: C'etait un homme sincere et, malgre l'affectation de son attitude et ses graces artificielles, un homme plein d'humilite au fond.

eng: And it is always the humble man who talks too much; the proud man watches himself too closely.
fr: C'est toujours l'homme humble qui parle trop ; l'orgueilleux s'observe de plus pres.

eng: He defended respectability with violence and exaggeration.
fr: Il defendait les convenances et la respectabilite avec violence, avec exageration.

eng: He grew passionate in his praise of tidiness and propriety.
fr: Il louait la correction, la simplicite, avec emportement.

eng: All the time there was a smell of lilac all round him.
fr: Une odeur de lilas flottait autour de lui.

eng: Once he heard very faintly in some distant street a barrel-organ begin to play, and it seemed to him that his heroic words were moving to a tiny tune from under or beyond the world.
fr: A un certain moment, les sons lointains d'un orgue de Barbarie lui parvinrent et il lui sembla qu'une voix mysterieuse et menue s'elevait du fond de la terre ou d'au-dela pour accompagner ses heroiques discours.

eng: He stared and talked at the girl's red hair and amused face for what seemed to be a few minutes; and then, feeling that the groups in such a place should mix, rose to his feet.
fr: Il n'y avait, semblait-il, que quelques minutes qu'il parlait ainsi, sans perdre du regard la fauve chevelure de la jeune fille, quand, songeant tout a coup qu'en un pareil endroit les couples ne devaient pas s'isoler, il se leva.

eng: To his astonishment, he discovered the whole garden empty.
fr: A sa grande surprise, il vit que le jardin etait desert.

eng: Everyone had gone long ago, and he went himself with a rather hurried apology.
fr: Tout le monde etait parti. ~~~ Il se retira a son tour, en presentant rapidement ses excuses.

eng: He left with a sense of champagne in his head, which he could not afterwards explain.
fr: La tete lui pesait, comme s'il avait bu un peu trop de champagne, -- ce qu'il ne put, dans la suite, s'expliquer.

eng: In the wild events which were to follow this girl had no part at all; he never saw her again until all his tale was over.
fr: Dans les incroyables evenements qui allaient se produire, la jeune fille n'avait aucun role ; Syme ne devait pas la revoir avant le denouement de l'aventure.

eng: And yet, in some indescribable way, she kept recurring like a motive in music through all his mad adventures afterwards, and the glory of her strange hair ran like a red thread through those dark and ill-drawn tapestries of the night. ~~~ For what followed was so improbable, that it might well have been a dream.
fr: Et pourtant, a travers ces folles aventures, sans qu'on put dire comment, elle ne cessait de revenir, comme un leit-motiv, la gloire de son etrange chevelure fauve transparaissait a travers les tendres tapisseries mal tissees de la nuit : car ce qui suivit fut si invraisemblable qu'aussi bien eut-ce pu etre un reve.

eng: Directly outside the door stood a street lamp, whose gleam gilded the leaves of the tree that bent out over the fence behind him.
fr: Juste en face de la porte qui venait de se fermer derriere lui, brillait la lumiere d'un reverbere, jetant un eclat d'or sur les feuilles de l'arbre qui depassaient la grille.

eng: Then he realised (in some odd way) that the silence was rather a living silence than a dead one.
fr: Puis, il se rendit compte obscurement que le silence etait vivant.

eng: When Syme went out into the starlit street, he found it for the moment empty.
fr: Ayant gagne la rue qu'eclairaient les etoiles, Syme la trouva deserte.

eng: The tall hat and long frock coat were black; the face, in an abrupt shadow, was almost as dark.
fr: Le grand chapeau et la longue redingote etaient noirs ; le visage, dans l'ombre, paraissait noir aussi.

eng: He made a sort of doubtful salute, which Syme somewhat more formally returned.
fr: Il esquissa un salut equivoque, que Syme lui rendit plus correctement.

eng: About a foot from the lamp-post stood a figure almost as rigid and motionless as the lamp-post itself.
fr: A un pied, a peu pres, du reverbere se tenait un homme, presque aussi droit et immobile que le reverbere lui-meme.

eng: Only a fringe of fiery hair against the light, and also something aggressive in the attitude, proclaimed that it was the poet Gregory.
fr: A quelques meches de cheveux rouges qui depassaient les bords du chapeau et a je ne sais quoi d'agressif dans l'attitude, Syme reconnut le poete Gregory.

eng: He had something of the look of a masked bravo waiting sword in hand for his foe.
fr: Il avait un peu l'air d'un bravo attendant, l'epee a la main, son ennemi.

eng: "I was waiting for you," said Gregory.
fr: -- Je vous attendais, dit Gregory.

eng: "Might I have a moment's conversation?"
fr: Pourrais-je vous parler un instant ?

eng: "Certainly.
fr: -- Certainement.

eng: Gregory struck out with his stick at the lamp-post, and then at the tree.
fr: Gregory frappa de sa canne le reverbere, puis un arbre voisin.

eng: "About what?" asked Syme in a sort of weak wonder.
fr: "Et de quoi ? demanda Syme avec une nuance d'etonnement."

eng: "About _this_ and _this_," he cried; "about order and anarchy.
fr: -- De ceci, repondit-il, et de ceci : de l'ordre et de l'anarchie.

eng: There is your precious order, that lean, iron lamp, ugly and barren; and there is anarchy, rich, living, reproducing itself there is anarchy, splendid in green and gold."
fr: Voici cet ordre qui vous est si cher ; c'est cette mince lampe de fer, laide et sterile. ~~~ Et voici l'anarchie, riche, vivante, feconde, voila l'anarchie dans sa splendeur verte et doree.

eng: The silence fell again, and Syme, though he understood nothing, listened instinctively for something serious.
fr: Le silence retomba. Syme, sans y rien comprendre, s'appretait a ecouter, s'attendant a quelque chose de serieux.

eng: "All the same," replied Syme patiently, "just at present you only see the tree by the light of the lamp. I wonder when you would ever see the lamp by the light of the tree."
fr: '-- Et pourtant, repliqua Syme avec patience, en ce moment meme vous ne pouvez voir l'arbre qu'a la lumiere de la lampe. Pourriez-vous jamais voir le reverbere a la lumiere de l'arbre ?'

eng: Gregory began in a smooth voice and with a rather bewildering smile. "Mr. Syme," he said, "this evening you succeeded in doing something rather remarkable. You did something to me that no man born of woman has ever succeeded in doing before."
fr: Gregory commenca, sur un ton singulierement radouci, avec un sourire inquietant : -- Monsieur Syme, ce soir, vous avez reussi quelque chose d'assez remarquable. Vous avez fait ce que, jusqu'a cette heure, personne, ni homme ni femme, n'etait encore parvenu a faire.

eng: "No," cried out Gregory, in a voice that rang down the street, "I did not stand here to resume our argument, but to end it for ever."
fr: -- Non ! ~~~ cria Gregory, et sa voix remplit la rue. Je ne vous ai pas attendu pour reprendre notre discussion, mais pour y mettre fin a jamais. ~~~

eng: Then after a pause he said, "But may I ask if you have been standing out here in the dark only to resume our little argument?"
fr: Puis, apres un silence : -- Me permettez-vous de vous demander si vous etes reste ici, dans l'obscurite, uniquement pour reprendre notre petite discussion ?

eng: "Indeed!"
fr: -- Vraiment !

eng: "Now I remember," resumed Gregory reflectively, "one other person succeeded in doing it.
fr: -- Attendez, reprit Gregory pensif. ~~~ Maintenant que j'y songe, il me semble que quelqu'un y est parvenu avant vous.

eng: The captain of a penny steamer (if I remember correctly) at Southend.
fr: C'etait le capitaine d'un bateau-mouche, si mes souvenirs sont exacts, a Southend.

eng: You have irritated me."
fr: Monsieur Syme, vous m'avez irrite.

eng: "I am very sorry," replied Syme with gravity.
fr: -- Je le regrette profondement, dit Syme avec gravite.

eng: "I am afraid my fury and your insult are too shocking to be wiped out even with an apology," said Gregory very calmly.
fr: -- Je crains, continua Gregory, tres calme, que ma fureur et votre insulte ne soient trop grandes l'une et l'autre pour que des excuses puissent les faire oublier.

eng: "No duel could wipe it out.
fr: Un duel ne les effacerait pas.

eng: If I struck you dead I could not wipe it out.
fr: Votre mort ne les effacerait pas.

eng: There is only one way by which that insult can be erased, and that way I choose.
fr: Il n'y a qu'un moyen d'en detruire la trace et je vais l'employer.

eng: "You said I was not serious about being an anarchist."
fr: 'Vous avez dit que je ne suis pas un anarchiste serieux.'

eng: "In what I said?"
fr: 'Qu'ai-je dit ?'

eng: "I am going, at the possible sacrifice of my life and honour, to _prove_ to you that you were wrong in what you said."
fr: 'Je vais vous prouver, au prix peut-etre de ma vie et de mon honneur, que vous avez eu tort de dire ce que vous avez dit.'

eng: "There are degrees of seriousness," replied Syme.
fr: -- Il y a des degres dans le serieux, repliqua Syme.

eng: "I have never doubted that you were perfectly sincere in this sense, that you thought what you said well worth saying, that you thought a paradox might wake men up to a neglected truth."
fr: Je n'ai jamais doute de votre parfaite sincerite, en ce sens que vous jugiez vos paroles bonnes a dire, que vous recouriez au paradoxe pour reveiller les esprits et les ouvrir a quelque verite negligee.

eng: Gregory stared at him steadily and painfully.
fr: Gregory le regardait fixement, avec douleur.

eng: "And in no other sense," he asked, "you think me serious? You think me a _fl neur_ who lets fall occasional truths.'
fr: Et vous ne me croyez pas serieux en un autre sens encore ? Vous me prenez pour un oisif, pour un flaneur qui laisse parfois tomber de ses levres quelque verite, par hasard ?

eng: You do not think that in a deeper, a more deadly sense, I am serious."
fr: Vous ne me croyez pas plus profondement serieux, en un sens plus fatal ?

eng: Syme struck his stick violently on the stones of the road.
fr: Syme frappa violemment de sa canne les paves de la rue.

eng: "Serious!"
fr: -- Serieux !

eng: 'One comes here and talks a pack of bosh, and perhaps some sense as well,'
fr: 'On arrive ici, on parle a tort et a travers...'

eng: 'he cried. "Good Lord! is this street serious? Are these damned Chinese lanterns serious? Is the whole caboodle serious?"'
fr: 's'ecria-t-il. Eh ! bon Dieu ! qu'y a-t-il de serieux dans cette rue, dans les lanternes venitiennes et dans toute la boutique ?'

eng: 'but I should think very little of a man who didn't keep something in the background of his life that was more serious than all this talking something more serious, whether it was religion or only drink."'
fr: 'Peut-etre aussi dit-on quelques paroles sensees ; mais je n'aurais pas haute opinion d'un homme qui ne saurait se reserver a l'arriere-plan de son existence quelque chose de plus serieux que de telles conversations, -- oui, quelque chose de plus serieux, que ce soit une religion, ou seulement de l'ivrognerie !'

eng: "Very well," said Gregory, his face darkening, "you shall see something more serious than either drink or religion."
fr: -- Fort bien, dit Gregory, et son visage s'assombrissait : vous allez voir quelque chose de plus serieux qui n'est ni l'ivrognerie ni la religion.

eng: Syme stood waiting with his usual air of mildness until Gregory again opened his lips.
fr: Syme attendit, avec son expression familiere de douceur extreme, que Gregory ouvrit de nouveau la bouche.

eng: "You spoke just now of having a religion. Is it really true that you have one?"
fr: -- Vous venez de parler de religion. Est-il donc vrai que vous en ayez une ?

eng: "Oh," said Syme with a beaming smile, "we are all Catholics now."
fr: -- Oh ! ~~~ repondit Syme, le visage epanoui d'un grand sourire, nous sommes tous catholiques aujourd'hui.

eng: "Then may I ask you to swear by whatever gods or saints your religion involves that you will not reveal what I am now going to tell you to any son of Adam, and especially not to the police?
fr: -- Eh bien ! ~~~ puis-je vous prier de jurer par tous les dieux ou par tous les saints de votre religion que vous ne revelerez a aucun des fils d'Adam, particulierement aux gens de la police, ce que je vais vous dire ?

eng: Will you swear that!
fr: Le jurez-vous ?

eng: If you will take upon yourself this awful abnegation if you will consent to burden your soul with a vow that you should never make and a knowledge you should never dream about, I will promise you in return " "You will promise me in return?"
fr: Si vous prenez cet engagement solennel, si vous consentez a charger votre ame d'un serment que, du reste, vous ne devriez pas prononcer, et de certaines connaissances auxquelles vous ne devriez pas meme rever, moi, de mon cote, je vous promets... -- Que me promettez-vous ?

eng: Syme suddenly took off his hat.
fr: Syme aussitot enleva son chapeau.

eng: "I will promise you a very entertaining evening."
fr: -- Je vous promets une soiree vraiment amusante.

eng: "inquired Syme, as the other paused.
fr: demanda Syme, comme l'autre s'interrompait.

eng: I disagree; but I hope at least that he is always a sportsman.
fr: Ce n'est pas mon avis. Mais j'espere, du moins, que tout poete est un galant homme.

eng: You say that a poet is always an anarchist.
fr: Vous pretendez que tout poete est un anarchiste.

eng: "Your offer," he said, "is far too idiotic to be declined.
fr: -- L'offre que vous me faites est trop seduisante pour que je la decline.

eng: Permit me, here and now, to swear as a Christian, and promise as a good comrade and a fellow-artist, that I will not report anything of this, whatever it is, to the police.
fr: Ici et maintenant, je vous jure, foi de chretien, et je vous promets en bon camarade et compagnon d'art que je ne rapporterai rien de tout ceci -- quoi que ce soit -- a la police.

eng: He gave two long whistles, and a hansom came rattling down the road.
fr: Il siffla deux fois, longuement ; un cab ne tarda pas a se ranger au pied du reverbere.

eng: "I think," said Gregory, with placid irrelevancy, "that we will call a cab."
fr: -- Je pense, dit Gregory avec placidite, que nous allons prendre un cab.

eng: The two got into it in silence.
fr: Ils prirent place, en silence, sur la banquette.

eng: Gregory gave through the trap the address of an obscure public-house on the Chiswick bank of the river.
fr: Gregory donna au cocher l'adresse d'un bar obscur, situe au bord de la riviere du cote de Chiswick.

eng: The cab whisked itself away again, and in it these two fantastics quitted their fantastic town.
fr: Le cab partit d'un trait. ~~~ Ainsi les deux fantasques poetes quitterent le fantastique faubourg.

eng: CHAPTER II. ~~~ THE SECRET OF GABRIEL SYME
fr: * * * CHAPITRE II LE SECRET DE GABRIEL SYME

eng: The cab pulled up before a particularly dreary and greasy beershop, into which Gregory rapidly conducted his companion.
fr: Le cab s'arreta devant un bar particulierement sale et repugnant, ou Gregory se hata d'introduire son compagnon.

eng: And now, in the name of Colney Hatch, what is it?
fr: Et maintenant, au nom de Colney Hatch, de quoi s'agit-il ?

eng: They seated themselves in a close and dim sort of bar-parlour, at a stained wooden table with one wooden leg.
fr: Ils s'assirent, dans une sorte d'arriere-boutique sombre et mal aeree, devant une table de bois souillee, portee par un pied de bois unique.

eng: The room was so small and dark, that very little could be seen of the attendant who was summoned, beyond a vague and dark impression of something bulky and bearded.
fr: La piece etait si mal eclairee qu'il etait impossible de distinguer les traits du garcon ; Syme n'eut que l'impression vague de quelque chose de puissant, de massif, de barbu.

eng: "Will you take a little supper?"
fr: -- Voulez-vous prendre un leger souper ?

eng: asked Gregory politely.
fr: demanda Gregory, affable.

eng: "Excuse me if I enjoy myself rather obviously!" ~~~ he said to Gregory, smiling.
fr: -- Vous m'excuserez si je ne vous cache pas mon plaisir, dit-il a Gregory, gaiment.

eng: His further attempts at conversation, somewhat disorganised in themselves, were cut short finally as by a thunderbolt by the actual appearance of the lobster.
fr: Il essaya de renouer la conversation ; mais il fut interrompu, des la premiere phrase, par la soudaine apparition de la langouste.

eng: "I shall only have a _cr me de menthe_ myself; I have dined. But the champagne can really be trusted. Do let me start you with a half-bottle of Pommery at least?"
fr: Pour moi, je ne prendrai qu'une creme de menthe ; j'ai dine. Mais le champagne de cette maison n'est pas a dedaigner. Commencez, du moins, par une demi-bouteille de pommery.

eng: "What will you drink?" resumed Gregory, with the same careless yet apologetic air.
fr: -- Que boirez-vous ? reprit Gregory.

eng: To his indescribable astonishment, the man only said "Certainly, sir!" and went away apparently to get it.
fr: A sa grande surprise, il entendit le garcon lui repondre : -- Bien, monsieur. Et il le vit s'eloigner, sans doute pour aller chercher ce qu'on venait de lui demander.

eng: "Thank you!" ~~~ said the motionless Syme. "You are very good."
fr: -- Merci, fit Syme impassible. Bien aimable...

eng: Then he suddenly began to eat with great rapidity and appetite.
fr: et se mit a manger de bon appetit.

eng: Syme tasted it, and found it particularly good.
fr: Il la gouta, la trouva excellente

eng: Accepting the vein of humour, he said, with a well-bred indifference "Oh, bring me some lobster mayonnaise."
fr: et, dans la meme veine d'humour, avec le ton detache d'un homme bien eleve : -- Donnez-moi plutot une langouste a la mayonnaise, dit-il.

eng: Syme received the remark with stolidity, imagining it to be a joke.
fr: Syme ne broncha pas, croyant a une plaisanterie,

eng: "The _p t de foie gras_ is not good here, but I can recommend the game."
fr: 'Le pate de foie gras n'est pas fameux ici ; mais je peux vous recommander le gibier.'

eng: "I don't often have the luck to have a dream like this.
fr: Je n'ai pas souvent la chance de rever comme aujourd'hui.

eng: It is new to me for a nightmare to lead to a lobster.
fr: Car ce n'est pas un fait banal qu'un cauchemar aboutisse a une langouste.

eng: "Well, if I am not drunk, I am mad," replied Syme with perfect calm;
fr: '-- Eh bien, dit Syme parfaitement calme, si je ne suis pas ivre, je suis fou.'

eng: "It is commonly the other way."
fr: 'D'ordinaire c'est le contraire qui arrive.'

eng: "You are not asleep, I assure you," said Gregory.
fr: 'Mais vous ne dormez pas, je vous l'assure !'

eng: "You are, on the contrary, close to the most actual and rousing moment of your existence.
fr: 'Vous approchez meme du moment le plus vivant et le plus poignant de votre existence...'

eng: Ah, here comes your champagne!
fr: 'Ah ! voici votre champagne...'

eng: I admit that there may be a slight disproportion, let us say, between the inner arrangements of this excellent hotel and its simple and unpretentious exterior.
fr: 'Je conviens qu'il peut y avoir, disons une certaine disproportion entre l'organisation interieure de cet excellent hotel et ses dehors simples et sans pretentions.'

eng: But that is all our modesty.
fr: 'Ce contraste est un effet de notre modestie.'

eng: "but I trust I can behave like a gentleman in either condition.'
fr: 'Mais je pense que je saurai me conduire convenablement dans l'un et l'autre cas.'

eng: We are the most modest men that ever lived on earth."
fr: 'Car nous sommes les gens les plus modestes qu'il y ait jamais eu au monde.'

eng: "It is quite simple," replied Gregory.
fr: '-- Mais, c'est tout simple :'

eng: "Oh!" said Syme shortly.
fr: 'Vraiment !'

eng: "You do yourselves well in drinks."
fr: 'vous vous fournissez tres bien en vins.'

eng: "Yes, we are serious about everything," answered Gregory.
fr: 'Nous sommes serieux en tout.'

eng: Then after a pause he added "If in a few moments this table begins to turn round a little, don't put it down to your inroads into the champagne.
fr: 'Et il ajouta : -- Si, dans quelques instants, cette table se met a tourner un peu, n'attribuez pas le phenomene au champagne que vous avez bu.'

eng: I don't wish you to do yourself an injustice."
fr: 'Je ne voudrais pas que vous vous fissiez injure.'

eng: "And who are _we?_" asked Syme, emptying his champagne glass.
fr: '-- Et qui sommes-nous ? demanda Syme en vidant son verre.'

eng: "_We_ are the serious anarchists, in whom you do not believe."
fr: 'nous sommes ces anarchistes serieux auxquels vous refusez de croire.'

eng: May I smoke?"
fr: Puis-je fumer ?

eng: They went rattling down a kind of roaring chimney as rapidly as a lift cut loose, and they came with an abrupt bump to the bottom.
fr: Ils descendirent par une sorte de cheminee mugissante, avec la rapidite d'un ascenseur dont le cable aurait ete coupe et s'arreterent brusquement.

eng: Gregory led him down a low, vaulted passage, at the end of which was the red light.
fr: Gregory le conduisit par un passage bas et voute, au bout duquel brillait la lumiere rouge.

eng: "I must ask you to forgive me all these formalities," said Gregory; "we have to be very strict here."
fr: -- Je vous prie d'excuser ces formalites, dit Gregory. Nous sommes obliges a la plus grande prudence...

eng: On a second glance, Syme saw that the glittering pattern was really made up of ranks and ranks of rifles and revolvers, closely packed or interlocked.
fr: Syme eut bientot constate que cette tapisserie etincelante etait faite de rangees superposees de fusils et de revolvers.

eng: Inside the doorway the passage gleamed as if it were lined with a network of steel.
fr: De l'autre cote de la porte, le passage etincelait comme s'il eut ete tapisse d'acier.

eng: The heavy hinges began to move; it was obviously some kind of password.
fr: Les gonds puissants se mirent a tourner.  C'etait evidemment le mot de passe.

eng: To this he gave the more or less unexpected reply, "Mr. Joseph Chamberlain."
fr: Il fit a cette question cette reponse plus ou moins inattendue : -- M. Joseph Chamberlain.

eng: A heavy voice with a foreign accent asked him who he was.
fr: Une lourde voix a l'accent etranger lui demanda qui il etait.

eng: In the door there was a sort of hatchway or grating, and on this Gregory struck five times.
fr: Il y avait dans cette porte une sorte de grillage ou de judas.

eng: It was an enormous crimson lantern, nearly as big as a fireplace, fixed over a small but heavy iron door.
fr: C'etait une enorme lanterne de couleur ecarlate, presque aussi grande qu'une cheminee, et fixee a une petite et lourde porte de fer.

eng: "Oh, don't apologise," said Syme. "I know your passion for law and order," and he stepped into the passage lined with the steel weapons.
fr: -- Ne vous excusez pas, protesta Syme. Je sais quelle passion vous avez pour l'ordre et la loi. Et il s'engagea dans le passage garni d'armes d'acier.

eng: But when Gregory threw open a pair of doors and let in a red subterranean light, Syme was still smoking with one leg thrown over the other, and had not turned a yellow hair.
fr: Mais quand Gregory eut ouvert deux portes et qu'une rouge lumiere souterraine se fut produite, Syme n'avait pas cesse de fumer, une jambe repliee sur l'autre, et pas un cheveu n'avait bouge sur sa tete.

eng: The next moment the smoke of his cigar, which had been wavering across the room in snaky twists, went straight up as if from a factory chimney, and the two, with their chairs and table, shot down through the floor as if the earth had swallowed them.
fr: Le moment d'apres, la fumee de son cigare, qui avait flotte jusqu'alors dans la piece en serpentant, prit une direction verticale, comme si elle montait d'un tuyau d'usine, et les deux hommes, avec leurs chaises et leur table, s'enfoncerent a travers le plancher.

eng: "Quite so," said Syme placidly, "a kind of screw. How simple that is!"
fr: -- C'est cela meme, consentit Syme, toujours placide, une espece de tire-bouchon. Que cela est donc simple !

eng: "You must not mind it," said Gregory; "it's a kind of screw."
fr: -- Ne faites pas attention, dit Gregory, c'est une espece de tire-bouchon.

eng: It is not a little to his credit that he performed these rites with so much composure, for almost before he had begun them the table at which he sat had begun to revolve, first slowly, and then rapidly, as if at an insane seance.
fr: Il eut pu etre fier d'avoir accompli ces rites avec tant de serenite, car, pendant ce temps, la table s'etait mise a tourner, lentement d'abord, puis tres vite, comme a quelque folle seance de spiritisme.

eng: Syme took the cigar, clipped the end off with a cigar-cutter out of his waistcoat pocket, put it in his mouth, lit it slowly, and let out a long cloud of smoke.
fr: Syme choisit un cigare, en coupa la pointe avec un coupe-cigare qu'il tira de la poche de son gilet, le porta a la bouche, l'alluma lentement et exhala un epais nuage de fumee.

eng: "Certainly!" said Gregory, producing a cigar-case. "Try one of mine."
fr: '-- Certainement ! Et Gregory tira un etui de sa poche.

eng: With his long, fair hair and rather foppish frock-coat, he looked a singularly frail and fanciful figure as he walked down that shining avenue of death.
fr: Avec ses longs cheveux blonds et sa redingote a la mode, il faisait une curieuse figure, singulierement fragile, comme il passait par cette rayonnante avenue de mort.

eng: They passed through several such passages, and came out at last into a queer steel chamber with curved walls, almost spherical in shape, but presenting, with its tiers of benches, something of the appearance of a scientific lecture-theatre.
fr: Ils traverserent plusieurs corridors pareillement decores et aboutirent enfin a une chambre d'acier aux parois courbes. ~~~ De forme presque spherique, cette piece, meublee de bancs parallelement ranges, n'etait pas sans analogie avec un amphitheatre academique.

eng: There were no rifles or pistols in this apartment, but round the walls of it were hung more dubious and dreadful shapes, things that looked like the bulbs of iron plants, or the eggs of iron birds.
fr: Il n'y avait la ni pistolets ni fusils ; mais les murs etaient garnis d'objets autrement redoutables, et qui ressemblaient a des bulbes de plantes metalliques, a des oeufs de metalliques oiseaux...

eng: They were bombs, and the very room itself seemed like the inside of a bomb.
fr: 'C'etaient des bombes, et la piece elle-meme semblait l'interieur d'une bombe.

eng: "And now, my dear Mr. Syme," said Gregory, throwing himself in an expansive manner on the bench under the largest bomb, "now we are quite cosy, so let us talk properly.
fr: -- Et maintenant, cher monsieur Syme, dit Gregory en s'asseyant avec negligence sous la plus grosse bombe, maintenant que nous sommes vraiment a l'aise, causons comme il faut.

eng: "We do not only want to upset a few despotisms and police regulations; that sort of anarchism does exist, but it is a mere branch of the Nonconformists.
fr: Il ne nous suffirait pas de detruire quelques despotes ou de dechirer quelques reglements de police. ~~~ Cette sorte d'anarchisme existe, il est vrai, mais ce n'est qu'une branche du non-conformisme.'

eng: First of all, what is it really all about? What is it you object to? You want to abolish Government?
fr: Et, d'abord, que signifie tout cela ? Quel est votre but ? Avez-vous le projet d'abolir le gouvernement ?

eng: So it is in mere curiosity that I make my queries.
fr: C'est donc par simple curiosite que je vous questionne.

eng: You need not fear to give me information, because, as you remember, you very wisely extorted from me a promise not to tell the police, a promise I shall certainly keep.
fr: Ne craignez pas de me renseigner, puisque, tres prudemment, vous m'avez extorque la promesse de ne rien rapporter a la police. Vous savez assez que, cette promesse, je la tiendrai.

eng: Syme knocked his cigar ash off against the wall, and went in.
fr: Syme, en entrant, fit tomber la cendre de son cigare contre l'un de ces engins meurtriers.

eng: Does this place strike you as being serious?
fr: La piece ou nous sommes vous parait-elle serieuse, oui ou non ?

eng: "It does seem to have a moral under all its gaiety," assented Syme; "but may I ask you two questions?
fr: -- Elle semble, en effet, cacher quelque moralite sous la gaite de ses apparences, reconnut Syme. Mais, puis-je vous poser deux questions ?

eng: That way you have of lighting a cigar would make a priest break the seal of confession.
fr: Votre maniere d'allumer un cigare induirait un pretre a rompre le sceau de la confession...

eng: I would break twenty oaths of secrecy for the pleasure of taking you down a peg.
fr: J'aurais vingt fois jure de me taire que je violerais vingt fois mon serment, pour le seul plaisir de vous faire baisser le ton d'un cran.

eng: Suffice it to say that you were an inexpressibly irritating fellow, and, to do you justice, you are still.
fr: Il me suffira de vous rappeler que vous avez ete irritant au dela de toute expression. Il faut d'ailleurs vous rendre cette justice que vous l'etes encore.

eng: It was one of those quite arbitrary emotions, like jumping off a cliff or falling in love.
fr: C'est un sentiment imperieux, fatal, comme celui qui vous obligerait a sauter du haut d'un rocher ou a tomber amoureux.

eng: Now no human words can give you any notion of why I brought you here.
fr: Il n'y a pas de mots pour definir le sentiment auquel j'ai obei en vous amenant ici.

eng: Well, you said that you were quite certain I was not a serious anarchist.
fr: Vous vous disiez donc tout a fait persuade que je ne suis pas un anarchiste serieux.

eng: "To abolish God!" said Gregory, opening the eyes of a fanatic.
fr: -- Nous avons l'intention d'abolir Dieu ! declara Gregory en ouvrant tout grands ses yeux de fanatique.

eng: We dig deeper and we blow you higher.
fr: Nous creusons plus profond, et nous vous ferons sauter plus haut.

eng: We wish to deny all those arbitrary distinctions of vice and virtue, honour and treachery, upon which mere rebels base themselves.
fr: Nous voulons effacer toutes vos distinctions arbitraires entre vice et vertu, honneur et vilenie, auxquelles de simples revoltes s'appuient et s'attardent.

eng: '"And Right and Left," said Syme with a simple eagerness, "I hope you will abolish them too. They are much more troublesome to me."'
fr: '-- Et la droite et la gauche ? dit Syme avec candeur, je pense que vous les abolirez aussi. Quant a moi, la droite et la gauche m'inquietent beaucoup plus que le tort et le droit.'

eng: '"I told you I was a serious anarchist, and you did not believe me. Nor do _they_ believe me."'
fr: 'Je vous ai dit que je suis un anarchiste serieux et vous ne m'avez pas cru : elles ne me croient pas non plus.'

eng: '"The history of the thing might amuse you," he said. "When first I became one of the New Anarchists I tried all kinds of respectable disguises."'
fr: 'Ecoutez, continua Gregory, ceci vous amusera peut-etre. Quand je devins l'un des Nouveaux Anarchistes, j'essayai toutes sortes de deguisements respectables.'

eng: 'Gregory went on.'
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: 'Syme smoked thoughtfully, and looked at him with interest.'
fr: 'Syme fumait, songeur, regardant Gregory avec interet.'

eng: 'Unless I took them into this infernal room they would not believe me.'
fr: 'Tant que je ne les aurai pas introduites dans cette chambre infernale, elles ne me croiront pas.'

eng: 'Gregory smiled. "The answer is simple," he said.'
fr: 'Ma reponse sera bien simple, dit Gregory en souriant.'

eng: 'May I ask why, after taking all this trouble to barricade yourselves in the bowels of the earth, you then parade your whole secret by talking about anarchism to every silly woman in Saffron Park?'
fr: 'Comment donc, d'une part, vous cachez-vous dans les entrailles de la terre, et, d'autre part, etalez-vous au grand jour votre secret en professant l'anarchie devant toutes les peronnelles de Saffron Park ?'

eng: 'You have a heavy iron door. You cannot pass it without submitting to the humiliation of calling yourself Mr. Chamberlain.'
fr: 'Vous avez une lourde porte de fer. Vous ne pouvez vous la faire ouvrir sans vous soumettre a l'humiliation de vous appeler M. Chamberlain.'

eng: 'You surround yourself with steel instruments which make the place, if I may say so, more impressive than homelike.'
fr: 'Vous vous entourez d'instruments d'acier qui donnent a ce lieu un aspect, si je puis m'exprimer ainsi, plutot guerrier que bourgeois.'

eng: '"With pleasure," resumed Syme.'
fr: '-- Avec plaisir.'

eng: '"You spoke of a second question," snapped Gregory.'
fr: 'Vous annonciez une seconde question, fit Gregory sechement.'

eng: 'We hate Rights as we hate Wrongs. We have abolished Right and Wrong.'
fr: 'Nous detestons, nous, les droits comme les torts. Nous avons aboli le tort et le droit.'

eng: 'The silly sentimentalists of the French Revolution talked of the Rights of Man!'
fr: 'Les sentimentaux stupides qui firent la Revolution francaise parlaient des droits de l'homme !'

eng: '"In all your present acts and surroundings there is a scientific attempt at secrecy. I have an aunt who lived over a shop, but this is the first time I have found people living from preference under a public-house."'
fr: 'Dans tout ce que vous faites, dans tout ce qui nous entoure, je vois une savante recherche du mystere. J'avais une tante qui habitait au-dessus d'un magasin, mais c'est la premiere fois que je vois des gens vivre sous un bar.'

eng: I dressed up as a bishop.
fr: Je m'habillai d'abord en eveque.

eng: I read up all about bishops in our anarchist pamphlets, in _Superstition the Vampire_ and _Priests of Prey_.
fr: Je lus tous nos pamphlets anarchistes sur le clerge, depuis le Vampire de la Superstition jusqu'aux Pretres de proie.

eng: I certainly understood from them that bishops are strange and terrible old men keeping a cruel secret from mankind.
fr: Les eveques, je ne tardai pas a m'en convaincre, sont d'etranges et terribles vieillards, qui cachent a l'humanite quelque cruel secret.

eng: Now I am a humanitarian myself, but I have, I hope, enough intellectual breadth to understand the position of those who, like Nietzsche, admire violence the proud, mad war of Nature and all that, you know.
fr: Tout humanitaire que je sois pour mon compte, j'ai assez de largeur d'esprit pour comprendre Nietzsche et les autres qui admirent la violence, la folle et dure concurrence vitale, etc.

eng: I threw myself into the major. I drew my sword and waved it constantly. I called out Blood!' abstractedly, like a man calling for wine. I often said, Let the weak perish; it is the Law.'
fr: J'entrai donc dans mon role de commandant. Sans cesse je tirais mon epee et je la brandissais. Je criais : << Du sang ! >> comme on demande du vin. J'allais repetant : << Que les faibles perissent ! C'est la loi. >>

eng: Then I made up as a millionaire; but I defended Capital with so much intelligence that a fool could see that I was quite poor.
fr: Alors, je me deguisais en millionnaire. Mais je defendis le capital avec tant d'intelligence qu'un sot aurait compris que je n'avais pas le sou.

eng: Then I tried being a major.
fr: J'essayai de jouer au commandant.

eng: they found out in some way that I was not a bishop at all.
fr: Mais les gens devinerent, je ne sais comment, que je n'etais pas du tout un eveque.

eng: When on my first appearing in episcopal gaiters in a drawing-room I cried out in a voice of thunder, Down! down! presumptuous human reason!
fr: La premiere fois que je penetrai avec mes guetres d'eveque dans un salon, je criai d'une voix tonitruante : << Et toi, raison presomptueuse, humilie-toi ! >>

eng: I was nabbed at once.
fr: La meche etait eventee du coup.

eng: At last I went in despair to the President of the Central Anarchist Council, who is the greatest man in Europe.
fr: En desespoir de cause, j'allai demander avis au president du Conseil Anarchiste Central. ~~~ C'est le plus grand homme d'Europe.

eng: Well, well, it seems majors don't do this. I was nabbed again.
fr: Je fus tout de suite << brule >> une fois de plus.

eng: I was misinformed.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "What is his name?"
fr: -- Comment s'appelle-t-il ?

eng: 'Caesar and Napoleon put all their genius into being heard of, and they _were_ heard of.'
fr: 'Un Cesar, un Napoleon depensent tout leur genie a faire parler d'eux ; ils y reussissent.'

eng: 'asked Syme.'
fr: 'demanda Syme.'

eng: '"That is his greatness."'
fr: 'Et c'est la le secret de sa grandeur.'

eng: '"You would not know it," answered Gregory.'
fr: '-- Si je vous disais son nom, vous ne le connaitriez pas.'

eng: He puts all his genius into not being heard of, and he is not heard of.
fr: Il met, lui, tout son genie a ne pas parler de lui, et l'on ne parle pas de lui.

eng: But you cannot be for five minutes in the room with him without feeling that Caesar and Napoleon would have been children in his hands."
fr: Mais il est impossible d'etre pendant cinq minutes en sa presence sans avoir l'impression que Cesar et Napoleon auraient ete des enfants entre ses mains. ~~~ Gregory se tut brusquement.

eng: I took his advice, and have never regretted it.
fr: J'ai suivi son conseil, et je n'ai jamais eu lieu de le regretter.

eng: Nobody will ever expect you to do anything dangerous then.
fr: << Personne ne soupconnera que vous puissiez faire le moindre mal. >>

eng: he roared so that the room shook.
fr: Et il rugissait si fort que les murs en tremblaient.

eng: I preached blood and murder to those women day and night, and by God! they would let me wheel their perambulators.
fr: J'ai preche l'anarchie devant ces femmes, nuit et jour, et, Seigneur ! elles m'auraient donne a conduire leurs voitures d'enfants.

eng: I nodded.
fr: J'inclinai la tete, en signe d'assentiment.

eng: You want a safe disguise, do you? You want a dress which will guarantee you harmless; a dress in which no one would ever look for a bomb?
fr: << Il vous faut un deguisement sur, n'est-ce pas ? Il vous faut une tenue qui vous garantisse comme un etre parfaitement inoffensif, un vetement d'ou nul ne s'attende a voir sortir une bombe, n'est-ce pas ? >>

eng: He looked at me with his large but indecipherable face.
fr: Il tourna vers moi son grand visage indechiffrable :

eng: I said to him, What disguise will hide me from the world? What can I find more respectable than bishops and majors?
fr: << Comment dois-je me deguiser ? >>, lui demandai-je. << Comment me cacher aux yeux du monde ? Que trouverai-je de plus respectable que les eveques et les commandants ? >>

eng: He was silent and even pale for a moment, and then resumed "But whenever he gives advice it is always something as startling as an epigram, and yet as practical as the Bank of England.
fr: Il avait pali. -- Ses conseils, reprit-il, ont toujours ce double caractere : ils sont a la fois piquants, surprenants comme une epigramme et pratiques comme la Banque d'Angleterre.

eng: He suddenly lifted his lion's voice. Why, then, dress up as an _anarchist_, you fool!
fr: << Eh bien ! deguisez-vous en anarchiste, espece d'imbecile ! >>

eng: And he turned his broad back on me without another word.
fr: Sans un mot de plus, il se detourna, et je ne vis plus que ses larges epaules.

eng: Syme sat watching him with some respect in his large, blue eyes.
fr: De ses grands yeux bleus, Syme considerait Gregory avec un certain respect.

eng: "You took me in," he said.
fr: "-- Je m'y suis laisse prendre, dit-il.

eng: "It is really a smart dodge."
fr: C'est bien joue.

eng: "What do you call this tremendous President of yours?"
fr: Et apres un silence il ajouta : << Comment appelez-vous ce terrible president ? >>

eng: "We generally call him Sunday," replied Gregory with simplicity.
fr: -- Nous l'appelons Dimanche, repondit Gregory avec simplicite.

eng: "You see, there are seven members of the Central Anarchist Council, and they are named after days of the week."
fr: Le Conseil Anarchiste Central se compose de sept membres, qui portent les noms des sept jours de la semaine.

eng: He is called Sunday, by some of his admirers Bloody Sunday.
fr: Nous l'appelons Dimanche, certains de ses admirateurs ajoutent Dimanche de sang.

eng: It is curious you should mention the matter, because the very night you have dropped in (if I may so express it) is the night on which our London branch, which assembles in this room, has to elect its own deputy to fill a vacancy in the Council.
fr: Il est curieux que la conversation nous amene a ce sujet, car, ce soir meme, ou vous venez, pour ainsi dire, de nous tomber du ciel, notre section de Londres va se reunir dans cette piece pour elire son depute au Conseil Central.

eng: "I feel somehow as if you were my mother, Syme," he continued casually.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: The gentleman who has for some time past played, with propriety and general applause, the difficult part of Thursday, has died quite suddenly.
fr: L'homme qui a joue pendant quelque temps, et a la satisfaction generale, le role difficile de Jeudi, est mort subitement.

eng: Consequently, we have called a meeting this very evening to elect a successor.
fr: Nous avons, en consequence, convoque pour ce soir un meeting en vue de le remplacer.

eng: He got to his feet and strolled across the room with a sort of smiling embarrassment.
fr: Il se leva et se mit a arpenter la chambre, avec un sourire embarrasse

eng: "I feel that I can confide anything to you, as you have promised to tell nobody.
fr: puis, negligemment : -- Syme, j'ai en vous une confiance pour ainsi dire filiale. Je sens que je puis m'ouvrir a vous sans reticence, puisque vous m'avez promis d'etre discret.

eng: In fact, I will confide to you something that I would not say in so many words to the anarchists who will be coming to the room in about ten minutes.
fr: J'ai envie de vous faire une confidence que je ne ferais pas aux anarchistes qui seront ici dans dix minutes.

eng: Syme, who had sat down once more with his usual insolent languor, got to his feet with an unusual air of hesitation.
fr: Syme, qui avait repris de son air de langoureuse impertinence sa place sur le banc, se leva de nouveau. L'expression toujours insolente de sa physionomie se nuancait d'une hesitation qui ne lui etait pas familiere.

eng: And he clasped his hands.
fr: Et, de joie, il joignait les mains.

eng: We shall, of course, go through a form of election; but I don't mind telling you that it is practically certain what the result will be.
fr: On va voter, ici, dans une dizaine de minutes ; mais c'est, autant dire, pour la forme.

eng: He looked down for a moment modestly.
fr: Il baissa les yeux modestement.

eng: "It is almost a settled thing that I am to be Thursday."
fr: Il est a peu pres entendu d'avance que, Jeudi, c'est moi.

eng: "My dear fellow," said Syme heartily, "I congratulate you. A great career!"
fr: Mon cher ami ! s'ecria Syme cordialement, je vous felicite ! Quelle belle carriere !

eng: Gregory smiled in deprecation, and walked across the room, talking rapidly.
fr: Gregory sourit pour decliner ces politesses et reprit sa promenade.

eng: "As a matter of fact, everything is ready for me on this table," he said, "and the ceremony will probably be the shortest possible."
fr: Tout est prepare pour moi sur cette table. ~~~ La ceremonie ne sera pas longue.

eng: Syme also strolled across to the table, and found lying across it a walking-stick, which turned out on examination to be a sword-stick, a large Colt's revolver, a sandwich case, and a formidable flask of brandy.
fr: Syme s'approcha de la table que designait Gregory. ~~~ Il y avait une canne a epee, un revolver Colt, une boite a sandwichs et une enorme bouteille de brandy.

eng: Over the chair, beside the table, was thrown a heavy-looking cape or cloak.
fr: Sur une chaise, pres de la table, s'etalait une ample pelerine.

eng: "I have only to get the form of election finished," continued Gregory with animation, "then I snatch up this cloak and stick, stuff these other things into my pocket, step out of a door in this cavern, which opens on the river, where there is a steam-tug already waiting for me, and then then oh, the wild joy of being Thursday!"
fr: Je n'ai qu'a attendre la fin de ce scrutin, continua Gregory avec animation, puis je prendrai cette pelerine et ce gourdin, j'emporterai ce revolver, cette boite et cette bouteille, et je sortirai de cette caverne par une porte qui donne sur la riviere. ~~~ La m'attend un petit bateau a vapeur, et alors... ~~~ Alors !

eng: "Why is it," he asked vaguely, "that I think you are quite a decent fellow? Why do I positively like you, Gregory?"
fr: Pourquoi donc, je me le demande, Gregory, ai-je de vous cette opinion que vous etes un charmant garcon ? Pourquoi donc ai-je pour vous, Gregory, positivement, de l'amitie ?

eng: He paused a moment, and then added with a sort of fresh curiosity, "Is it because you are such an ass?"
fr: Il se tut, puis, avec une curiosite sincere et passionnee : -- Serait-ce parce que vous etes tellement ane ?

eng: There was a thoughtful silence again, and then he cried out "Well, damn it all! this is the funniest situation I have ever been in in my life, and I am going to act accordingly.
fr: Il y eut un nouveau silence, plein de pensees, puis Syme s'ecria : -- Nom de Dieu ! c'est bien ici la situation la plus comique ou je me sois trouve de ma vie, et je vais agir en consequence.

eng: Gregory, I gave you a promise before I came into this place.
fr: Gregory, je vous ai fait une promesse avant de venir ici.

eng: That promise I would keep under red-hot pincers.
fr: Je tiendrai cette promesse, fut-ce sous des tenailles ardentes.

eng: Would you give me, for my own safety, a little promise of the same kind?"
fr: Me feriez-vous, en vue de ma propre securite, une promesse du meme genre ?

eng: "A promise?"
fr: -- Une promesse ?

eng: Gregory tried to spring up straight, but he swayed thrice.
fr: Gregory, par trois fois, tenta de sauter en l'air, sans y parvenir.

eng: "What do you say?" he asked in an inhuman voice.
