fr: Voulez-vous venir le voir ?

eng: asked Syme, with a sort of passion.
fr: demanda Syme passionnement.

eng: "No," said the policeman placidly, "he has a fancy for always sitting in a pitch-dark room.
fr: -- Non. Il a la fantaisie de vivre dans une chambre tres obscure.

eng: "Telephone?" inquired Syme, with interest.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Or rather, I should not say see him, nobody ever sees him; but you can talk to him if you like."
fr: Ou plutot je ne dis pas que vous le verrez, personne ne l'ayant jamais vu, mais vous pourrez causer avec lui, si vous voulez.

eng: He says it makes his thoughts brighter.
fr: Il dit que ses pensees en sont plus lumineuses.

eng: Do come along."
fr: -- Venez avec moi.

eng: Somewhat dazed and considerably excited, Syme allowed himself to be led to a side-door in the long row of buildings of Scotland Yard.
fr: Passablement abasourdi et considerablement intrigue, Syme se laissa conduire jusqu'a une porte menagee dans le long corps de batiment de Scotland Yard.

eng: Almost before he knew what he was doing, he had been passed through the hands of about four intermediate officials, and was suddenly shown into a room, the abrupt blackness of which startled him like a blaze of light.
fr: Sans presque se rendre compte de ce qui lui arrivait, il passa par les mains de quatre employes intermediaires et, subitement, il fut introduit dans une piece dont l'obscurite totale fit sur sa retine une impression identique a celle de la plus vive lumiere.

eng: It was not the ordinary darkness, in which forms can be faintly traced; it was like going suddenly stone-blind.
fr: Car ce n'etait pas cette obscurite ordinaire ou les formes s'estompent vaguement : Syme eut la sensation qu'il venait d'etre frappe de cecite.

eng: "Are you the new recruit?" asked a heavy voice.
fr: '-- C'est vous la nouvelle recrue ? interrogea une voix puissante.

eng: "Are you the new recruit?" said the invisible chief, who seemed to have heard all about it.
fr: '-- C'est vous la nouvelle recrue ? repeta le chef, qui semblait etre au courant de tout.

eng: "All right. You are engaged."
fr: C'est bien. Vous etes enrole.

eng: Syme, quite swept off his feet, made a feeble fight against this irrevocable phrase.
fr: Syme, qui sentait ses jambes se derober sous lui, se defendit faiblement contre l'irrevocable.

eng: And in some strange way, though there was not the shadow of a shape in the gloom, Syme knew two things: first, that it came from a man of massive stature; and second, that the man had his back to him.
fr: Et, mysterieusement, bien qu'il ne put percevoir dans ces tenebres l'ombre meme d'une forme humaine, Syme eut conscience de deux choses : d'abord, que la voix etait celle d'un homme de massive stature, puis, que cet homme lui tournait le dos.

eng: "I really have no experience," he began.
fr: -- Je n'ai, a vrai dire, aucune experience, balbutia-t-il.

eng: "I do," said the other "martyrs."
fr: '-- J'en connais un, moi : celui de martyr.'

eng: "Well, really," said Syme, "I don't know any profession of which mere willingness is the final test."
fr: '-- Pardon, mais... je ne connais aucun metier ou la bonne volonte soit suffisante...'

eng: "You are willing, that is enough," said the unknown.
fr: '-- Vous avez la bonne volonte. Cela suffit. ~~~'

eng: "No one has any experience," said the other, "of the Battle of Armageddon."
fr: '-- Personne n'a aucune experience, repondit la voix, de la bataille d'Armaggedon. --

eng: "But I am really unfit"
fr: '~~~ Je suis tout a fait incapable. ~~~'

eng: I am condemning you to death.
fr: Je vous condamne a mort.

eng: Good day."
fr: Bonjour.

eng: Thus it was that when Gabriel Syme came out again into the crimson light of evening, in his shabby black hat and shabby, lawless cloak, he came out a member of the New Detective Corps for the frustration of the great conspiracy.
fr: C'est ainsi qu'un instant apres Gabriel Syme, toujours coiffe de son miserable chapeau noir et toujours vetu de son miserable manteau d'outlaw, reparut a la lumiere rouge du soir en qualite de membre du nouveau corps de detectives, organise en vue de faire avorter la grande conspiration.

eng: Acting under the advice of his friend the policeman (who was professionally inclined to neatness), he trimmed his hair and beard, bought a good hat, clad himself in an exquisite summer suit of light blue-grey, with a pale yellow flower in the button-hole, and, in short, became that elegant and rather insupportable person whom Gregory had first encountered in the little garden of Saffron Park.
fr: Sur le conseil de son ami le policeman, qui etait par sa profession enclin a la proprete, il se fit peigner la barbe et les cheveux, acheta un chapeau decent, un delicieux complet d'ete bleu gris, mit une fleur d'un jaune pale a sa boutonniere, et devint, en un mot, ce jeune homme d'une elegance un peu insupportable que Gregory devait rencontrer dans son petit jardin de Saffron Park.

eng: Before he finally left the police premises his friend provided him with a small blue card, on which was written, "The Last Crusade," and a number, the sign of his official authority.
fr: Avant qu'il quittat definitivement l'hotel de la police, son ami le pourvut d'une carte bleue qui portait cette inscription : << La Derniere Croisade >>, et un numero ; c'etait le signe de son autorite.

eng: He put this carefully in his upper waistcoat pocket, lit a cigarette, and went forth to track and fight the enemy in all the drawing-rooms of London.
fr: Il la placa soigneusement dans la poche superieure de son gilet, alluma une cigarette et se mit a la poursuite de l'ennemi a travers tous les salons de Londres.

eng: Where his adventure ultimately led him we have already seen.
fr: Nous avons vu ou son aventure finit par l'amener :

eng: At about half-past one on a February night he found himself steaming in a small tug up the silent Thames, armed with swordstick and revolver, the duly elected Thursday of the Central Council of Anarchists.
fr: vers une heure et demie, une nuit de fevrier, il voyageait dans une legere embarcation sur la Tamise. Arme de la canne a epee et du revolver, il etait le Jeudi regulierement elu au Conseil Central Anarchiste.

eng: When Syme stepped out on to the steam-tug he had a singular sensation of stepping out into something entirely new; not merely into the landscape of a new land, but even into the landscape of a new planet.
fr: En s'embarquant sur le petit vapeur, il lui sembla qu'il abordait dans quelque chose d'entierement neuf, non pas seulement dans un nouveau pays, mais dans une nouvelle planete.

eng: This was mainly due to the insane yet solid decision of that evening, though partly also to an entire change in the weather and the sky since he entered the little tavern some two hours before.
fr: Cette impression lui venait sans doute de la decision insensee mais irrevocable qui venait de modifier sa destinee ; le changement du ciel et du temps, depuis qu'il etait entre, deux heures auparavant, dans la petite taverne, y etait aussi toutefois pour quelque chose.

eng: Every trace of the passionate plumage of the cloudy sunset had been swept away, and a naked moon stood in a naked sky.
fr: Plus de traces de plumages affoles : seule et nue, la lune regnait dans le ciel nu.

eng: It gave, not the sense of bright moonshine, but rather of a dead daylight.
fr: et cela suggerait l'idee d'un jour mort plutot que celle d'une belle nuit de lune.

eng: The moon was so strong and full that (by a paradox often to be noticed) it seemed like a weaker sun.
fr: Une lune puissante et pleine, plutot comparable a un soleil pali qu'a une lune normale ;

eng: Over the whole landscape lay a luminous and unnatural discoloration, as of that disastrous twilight which Milton spoke of as shed by the sun in eclipse;
fr: Sur tout le paysage se repandait cette decoloration lumineuse et irreelle, ce crepuscule de desastre que Milton a observe pendant les eclipses de soleil.

eng: so that Syme fell easily into his first thought, that he was actually on some other and emptier planet, which circled round some sadder star.
fr: En sorte que Syme se confirma dans cette pensee, qu'il etait bien sur une autre planete, moins vivante que la notre, gravitant autour d'une etoile plus triste que la notre.

eng: But the more he felt this glittering desolation in the moonlit land, the more his own chivalric folly glowed in the night like a great fire.
fr: Mais, plus profondement il ressentait cette desolation du clair de lune, plus sa folie chevaleresque brulait en lui comme un grand feu.

eng: Even the common things he carried with him the food and the brandy and the loaded pistol took on exactly that concrete and material poetry which a child feels when he takes a gun upon a journey or a bun with him to bed.
fr: Jusqu'aux choses communes qu'il portait dans ses poches, sandwichs, brandy, pistolet charge, s'animaient de cette poesie concrete et materielle dont s'exalte un enfant, quand il emporte un fusil a la promenade ou un gateau dans son lit.

eng: The sword-stick and the brandy-flask, though in themselves only the tools of morbid conspirators, became the expressions of his own more healthy romance.
fr: La canne a epee et la gourde de brandy, ces obligatoires et ridicules accessoires de tout conspirateur, devenaient pour lui l'expression de son propre romantisme.

eng: The sword-stick became almost the sword of chivalry, and the brandy the wine of the stirrup-cup.
fr: La canne a epee, c'etait le glaive du chevalier, et le brandy, le coup de l'etrier !

eng: For even the most dehumanised modern fantasies depend on some older and simpler figure; the adventures may be mad, but the adventurer must be sane.
fr: -- Car les fantaisies modernes, meme les plus deshumanisees, se referent toujours a quelque symbole ancien et simple. ~~~ Que l'aventure soit folle tant qu'on voudra, il faut que l'aventurier ait le bon sens.

eng: The dragon without St. George would not even be grotesque.
fr: Sans saint Georges, le dragon n'est meme pas grotesque.

eng: So this inhuman landscape was only imaginative by the presence of a man really human.
fr: De meme, ce paysage hostile ne sollicitait l'imagination que grace a la presence d'un homme veritable.

eng: To Syme's exaggerative mind the bright, bleak houses and terraces by the Thames looked as empty as the mountains of the moon.
fr: A l'imagination excessive de Syme, les maisons et les terrasses lumineuses et desolees dont la Tamise etait bordee paraissaient aussi desertes, aussi tristement desertes que les montagnes de la Lune.

eng: But even the moon is only poetical because there is a man in the moon.
fr: Mais la Lune elle-meme ne serait pas poetique, s'il n'y avait un homme dans la Lune.

eng: The tug was worked by two men, and with much toil went comparatively slowly.
fr: En depit des efforts des deux mariniers qui dirigeaient l'embarcation, elle n'avancait que lentement.

eng: This scrap of hair almost seemed a mere oversight; the rest of the face was of the type that is best shaven clear-cut, ascetic, and in its way noble.
fr: Cette figure anguleuse, ascetique, noble a sa facon, etait de celles auxquelles la barbe ne sied pas.

eng: Syme drew closer and closer, noting all this, and still the figure did not stir.
fr: Et, tout en faisant ces remarques, Syme se rapprochait toujours ; et l'homme restait toujours immobile.

eng: At first an instinct had told Syme that this was the man whom he was meant to meet. Then, seeing that the man made no sign, he had concluded that he was not. And now again he had come back to a certainty that the man had something to do with his mad adventure.
fr: Au premier regard, Syme avait eu l'intuition que cet homme etait la pour l'attendre. Puis, ne lui voyant faire aucun signe, il avait cru s'etre trompe. Mais, de nouveau, il revenait a la certitude que cet homme devait jouer un role dans sa folle aventure.

eng: They made him feel that he was landing on the colossal steps of some Egyptian palace; and, indeed, the thing suited his mood, for he was, in his own mind, mounting to attack the solid thrones of horrible and heathen kings.
fr: Syme crut aborder aux marches colossales de quelque palais d'Egypte. ~~~ L'idee lui plut. Ne pensait-il pas, en effet, monter a l'assaut des trones massifs ou siegeaient d'horribles rois paiens !

eng: As Syme drew nearer to him step by step, he did not even move a hair; and Syme could come close enough to notice even in the dim, pale morning light that his face was long, pale and intellectual, and ended in a small triangular tuft of dark beard at the very point of the chin, all else being clean-shaven.
fr: De marche en marche, la distance diminuait entre eux ; l'homme ne bougeait pas. Syme put l'approcher d'assez pres pour observer, a la pale lumiere du matin, que la figure de l'inconnu etait longue, bleme, intelligente et se terminait par une touffe de barbe noire, les levres et les joues etant soigneusement rasees, et ces quelques poils semblaient oublies la, par simple negligence.

eng: The two men in the tug put her off again and turned up stream.
fr: Les deux hommes firent reculer le bateau et commencerent a remonter le fleuve.

eng: As a figure he was quite conventional, clad in a silk hat and frock-coat of the more formal type of fashion; he had a red flower in his buttonhole.
fr: Son aspect etait tres ordinaire. Il portait un chapeau de soie et une redingote correcte ; il avait une fleur rouge a la boutonniere.

eng: He leapt out of the boat on to one slimy step, and stood, a dark and slender figure, amid the enormous masonry.
fr: Il sauta a terre et se tint un instant immobile sur la dalle humide et glissante, sombre et fragile figure perdue dans cet immense amas de pierres de taille.

eng: The great stones of the Embankment seemed equally dark and gigantic as Syme looked up at them. They were big and black against the huge white dawn.
fr: Les grandes pierres du quai apparurent, gigantesques et sombres, opposant leur masse noire a la blanche aurore.

eng: It broke like the splitting of great bars of lead, showing bars of silver; and these had brightened like white fire when the tug, changing its onward course, turned inward to a large landing stage rather beyond Charing Cross.
fr: De grandes barres de plomb apparurent dans le ciel, puis s'effacerent sous des barres d'argent qui prirent bientot l'eclat du metal chauffe a blanc. L'embarcation, changeant de cours, se dirigea vers un grand escalier, un peu au-dela de Charing Cross.

eng: The clear moon that had lit up Chiswick had gone down by the time that they passed Battersea, and when they came under the enormous bulk of Westminster day had already begun to break.
fr: Le clair de lune qui avait brille a Chiswick s'eteignit a Battersea, et, quand on arriva sous la masse enorme de Westminster, le jour commencait a poindre.

eng: CHAPTER V. THE FEAST OF FEAR
fr: * * * CHAPITRE V LE REPAS EPOUVANTABLE

eng: At first the large stone stair seemed to Syme as deserted as a pyramid; but before he reached the top he had realised that there was a man leaning over the parapet of the Embankment and looking out across the river.
fr: Tout d'abord, Syme crut l'escalier de pierre desert comme une pyramide. Mais, avant d'avoir atteint le dernier degre, il se rendit compte qu'il y avait un homme accoude au parapet, et que cet homme regardait le fleuve.

eng: They had never spoken a word.
fr: Pendant toute la duree du voyage, ils n'avaient pas prononce une parole.

eng: For the man remained more still than would have been natural if a stranger had come so close.
fr: Un individu frole, presque, par un etranger ne reste pas a ce point immobile et calme sans raison.

eng: There was the silent river and the silent man, a man of even classic face.
fr: Ce fleuve silencieux, cet homme silencieux, au visage classique...

eng: But in all Syme's circumstances, with the dark dawn and the deadly errand and the loneliness on the great dripping stones, there was something unnerving in it.
fr: Mais, dans les circonstances ou se trouvait Syme, sous l'influence de cette aurore menacante, avec la mission meurtriere dont il etait charge, dans la solitude de ces grandes pierres ruisselantes, il recut de cet accueil une impression etrange, qui le glaca, qui le paralysa.

eng: Many people have this nervous trick of a crooked smile, and in many it is even attractive.
fr: Bien des gens ont ce tic nerveux, ce rictus grimacant, et il en est meme chez qui c'est une grace.

eng: Then he took out of his pocket the note from Buttons proving his election, and put it before that sad and beautiful face.
fr: et tout a coup, tirant de sa poche le document qui lui conferait le titre de Jeudi, il le mit sous les yeux tristes et doux de l'inconnu.

eng: Then the man smiled, and his smile was a shock, for it was all on one side, going up in the right cheek and down in the left.
fr: Alors, celui-ci sourit, d'un sourire inquietant, d'un sourire << d'un seul cote >>, qui haussait la joue droite et abaissait la gauche.

eng: Syme looked again and again at the pale, dignified and delicate face, and the face still looked blankly across the river.
fr: Syme considerait toujours cette figure pale, delicate et digne, dont le regard eteint ne se detournait pas de la riviere,

eng: He was as motionless as a wax-work, and got on the nerves somewhat in the same way.
fr: Il etait aussi inerte et a peu pres aussi enervant, par la meme, qu'une poupee de cire.

eng: And there was the last nightmare touch that his smile suddenly went wrong.
fr: Et, comme touche finale au cauchemar, ce sourire grimacant.

eng: There was nothing, rationally speaking, to scare anyone about this.
fr: Raisonnablement, toutefois, il n'y avait la rien d'effroyable.

eng: The spasm of smile was instantaneous, and the man's face dropped at once into its harmonious melancholy.
fr: Mais cette grimace s'effaca instantanement, et la physionomie de l'anarchiste reprit son expression d'harmonieuse melancolie.

eng: After a pause the man spoke again.
fr: Apres un silence, il reprit :

eng: "If we walk up towards Leicester Square," he said, "we shall just be in time for breakfast. Sunday always insists on an early breakfast. Have you had any sleep?"
fr: -- En nous dirigeant tout de suite vers Leicester Square, dit-il, nous arriverons juste a temps pour dejeuner. Dimanche tient beaucoup a dejeuner de bon matin. Avez-vous dormi ?

eng: "It seems to me a very clever idea," said Syme.
fr: -- L'idee de Dimanche me parait tres ingenieuse.

eng: "They say we are a lot of jolly gentlemen who pretend they are anarchists."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "And what do the people say?" asked Syme.
fr: -- Et que disent les gens ? demanda Syme.

eng: We have our breakfast on a balcony on a balcony, if you please overlooking Leicester Square.
fr: nous dejeunons sur un balcon -- un balcon, remarquez-le bien, qui domine Leicester Square.

eng: For now we flaunt ourselves before the public.
fr: car, maintenant, nous nous exposons aux yeux du public,

eng: Well, he is the only man on earth, I know; but sometimes I really think that his huge brain is going a little mad in its old age.
fr: Je sais bien qu'il n'a pas son pareil au monde ; mais, vraiment, je crains parfois que son vaste cerveau ne se detraque un peu, avec l'age :

eng: He spoke without further explanation or inquiry, like a man speaking to an old colleague.
fr: Sans plus de questions ni d'explications, il parla comme on parle a un vieux collegue.

eng: He said that if you didn't seem to be hiding nobody hunted you out.
fr: Il disait que, si nous ne paraissions pas nous dissimuler, personne ne se defierait de nous.

eng: Originally, of course, we met in a cell underground, just as your branch does.
fr: Au debut, naturellement, nous nous reunissions sous terre, dans une cave, comme font les membres de votre section.

eng: So in case you don't know, I'd better tell you that he is carrying out his notion of concealing ourselves by not concealing ourselves to the most extraordinary lengths just now.
fr: Pour le cas ou vous ne le sauriez pas, je vous dirai donc qu'il a resolu de nous cacher en ne nous cachant pas du tout.

eng: "Of course, the Secretary of the branch told you everything that can be told. But the one thing that can never be told is the last notion of the President, for his notions grow like a tropical forest.
fr: -- Sans nul doute, le president de la section vous a dit tout ce qu'il pouvait vous dire. Mais la seule chose qu'on ne puisse jamais dire, c'est la derniere idee de Dimanche car ses idees se multiplient comme les vegetations d'une foret tropicale.

eng: It seemed almost as if all friendly words were to him lifeless conveniences, and that his only life was hate.
fr: On eut jure qu'il s'acquittait de ces gestes et propos de bonne grace comme d'insignifiantes obligations, et qu'il ne vivait que de haine.

eng: He spoke with casual civility, but in an utterly dead voice that contradicted the fanaticism of his face.
fr: Il parlait avec une civilite negligente, mais d'une voix extremement monotone qui faisait un vif contraste avec l'ardeur fanatique de sa physionomie.

eng: "Nor have I," answered the man in an ordinary tone. "I shall try to get to bed after breakfast."
fr: -- Moi non plus, repondit l'autre d'une voix egale. Je tacherai de dormir apres dejeuner.

eng: "No," said Syme.
fr: -- Non.

eng: Then Sunday made us take a private room at an ordinary restaurant.
fr: Puis, Dimanche nous convoqua dans un cabinet de restaurant.

eng: "It's quite simple what they say," answered his guide.
fr: -- Ils disent, reprit son guide, que nous sommes de gais compagnons, des gentlemen qui se pretendent anarchistes.

eng: "Clever!
fr: -- Ingenieuse !

eng: God blast your impudence! ~~~ Clever!"
fr: Que Dieu punisse votre impudence !

eng: cried out the other in a sudden, shrill voice which was as startling and discordant as his crooked smile.
fr: s'ecria l'autre d'une voix aigue qui etonnait et jurait avec son personnage tout autant qu'avec son rictus.

eng: "When you've seen Sunday for a split second you'll leave off calling him clever."
fr: Ingenieuse ! ~~~ Quand vous aurez vu Dimanche le quart d'une seconde, vous perdrez l'envie de traiter ses idees d'ingenieuses !

eng: With this they emerged out of a narrow street, and saw the early sunlight filling Leicester Square.
fr: Sur ces mots, ils atteignirent le terme d'une rue etroite, et Leicester Square leur apparut, baigne dans la lumiere du matin.

eng: It will never be known, I suppose, why this square itself should look so alien and in some ways so continental.
fr: On ne saura jamais, je pense, pourquoi ce square a un aspect si etranger et, en quelque maniere, continental.

eng: It will never be known whether it was the foreign look that attracted the foreigners or the foreigners who gave it the foreign look.
fr: On ne saura jamais si c'est son aspect etranger qui attira les etrangers ou si ce sont les etrangers qui lui donnerent son aspect etranger.

eng: But on this particular morning the effect seemed singularly bright and clear.
fr: Justement, ce matin-la, ce caractere de Leicester Square etait particulierement clair et evident.

eng: Between the open square and the sunlit leaves and the statue and the Saracenic outlines of the Alhambra, it looked the replica of some French or even Spanish public place.
fr: Le square ouvert et les feuilles ensoleillees des arbres, la statue et la silhouette sarrasine de l'Alhambra, evoquaient on ne savait quelle place publique de France ou d'Espagne.

eng: And this effect increased in Syme the sensation, which in many shapes he had had through the whole adventure, the eerie sensation of having strayed into a new world.
fr: Syme eut de plus en plus nettement une sensation qui devait se reproduire bien des fois au cours de son aventure, la sensation aigue qu'il s'etait egare dans une planete nouvelle.

eng: As a fact, he had bought bad cigars round Leicester Square ever since he was a boy.
fr: En fait, il n'avait cesse d'acheter de mauvais cigares aux environs de Leicester Square, depuis sa jeunesse.

eng: But as he turned that corner, and saw the trees and the Moorish cupolas, he could have sworn that he was turning into an unknown Place de something or other in some foreign town.
fr: Mais, ce jour-la, en decouvrant au tournant du coin les coupoles mauresques et les arbres, il eut jure qu'il debouchait sur la << Place de Chose ou Machin >> de quelque ville etrangere.

eng: In the wall there was one large French window, probably the window of a large coffee-room; and outside this window, almost literally overhanging the square, was a formidably buttressed balcony, big enough to contain a dining-table.
fr: Au-dessus d'une grande porte-fenetre, sans doute la porte d'un cafe, un balcon enorme faisait saillie, dominant le square, un balcon assez spacieux pour qu'une table y fut mise.

eng: At one corner of the square there projected a kind of angle of a prosperous but quiet hotel, the bulk of which belonged to a street behind.
fr: En angle, au coin du square, se profilait un hotel, dont la facade principale donnait sur une rue laterale.

eng: In fact, it did contain a dining-table, or more strictly a breakfast-table; and round the breakfast-table, glowing in the sunlight and evident to the street, were a group of noisy and talkative men, all dressed in the insolence of fashion, with white waistcoats and expensive button-holes.
fr: Sur ce balcon, il y avait, en effet, une table, une table a dejeuner, et, autour de cette table, visible de la rue et en plein soleil, un groupe d'hommes bruyants et bavards, tous habilles avec l'insolence de la mode, le gilet blanc et la boutonniere fleurie.

eng: Some of their jokes could almost be heard across the square.
fr: Quand ils plaisantaient, on les entendait parfois de l'autre bout du square.

eng: Then the grave Secretary gave his unnatural smile, and Syme knew that this boisterous breakfast party was the secret conclave of the European Dynamiters.
fr: Le grave compagnon de Syme fit sa grimace si peu naturelle, et Syme comprit que ces joyeux convives etaient les membres du conclave secret des dynamiteurs europeens.

eng: At the nearest end of the balcony, blocking up a great part of the perspective, was the back of a great mountain of a man.
fr: A l'une des extremites du balcon, interceptant la perspective, c'etait le dos d'une gigantesque montagne humaine.

eng: He had not seen it literally because it was too large to see.
fr: Et cela lui avait echappe, parce que c'etait trop grand pour etre vu tout d'abord.

eng: Then, as Syme continued to stare at them, he saw something that he had not seen before.
fr: Puis, comme il ne pouvait detourner son regard de ce groupe, il y remarqua quelque chose qui tout d'abord lui avait echappe.

eng: When Syme had seen him, his first thought was that the weight of him must break down the balcony of stone.
fr: En l'apercevant, Syme pensa tout de suite que le balcon de pierre allait ceder sous le poids de cette masse de chair.

eng: Syme had never thought of asking whether the monstrous man who almost filled and broke the balcony was the great President of whom the others stood in awe.
fr: Syme n'avait pas un instant songe a demander si ce monstre qui remplissait le balcon etait bien le grand President dont les anarchistes ne pouvaient prononcer le nom sans trembler.

eng: This man was planned enormously in his original proportions, like a statue carved deliberately as colossal.
fr: la cause reelle de l'impression d'excessif qu'il produisait etait dans l'ordonnance des plans de sa personne, dans les proportions originales selon lesquelles cette statue vivante avait ete executee.

eng: He knew it was so, with an unaccountable but instantaneous certainty.
fr: Il le savait, il l'avait su immediatement, sans qu'il lui eut ete possible de preciser les motifs de sa certitude.

eng: His vastness did not lie only in the fact that he was abnormally tall and quite incredibly fat.
fr: Et ce n'etait pas seulement parce qu'il etait extraordinairement haut de stature, et incroyablement gros, que cet homme paraissait si ample :

eng: And the waiter hurried away with a napkin over his arm, much pleased with the singular frivolity of the gentlemen upstairs.
fr: Et le garcon, sa serviette sous le bras, s'eloigna rapidement, fort amuse lui-meme de l'exceptionnelle frivolite de ces messieurs.

eng: They do say they will throw bombs at ze king."
fr: ils pretendent qu'ils veulent jeter des bombes sur le roi !

eng: "They do talk and they do laugh at what they talk.
fr: ils causent joyeusement ;

eng: The ears that stood out from it looked larger than human ears.
fr: les oreilles paraissaient plus grandes que des oreilles humaines.

eng: As Syme and the guide approached the side door of the hotel, a waiter came out smiling with every tooth in his head.
fr: Comme Syme et son guide approchaient de l'hotel, un garcon vint a eux souriant de toutes ses dents.

eng: The two men mounted the stairs in silence.
fr: Les deux hommes gravirent l'escalier en silence.

eng: "The gentlemen are up there, sare," he said.
fr: -- Ces messieurs sont la-haut, dit-il ;

eng: His head, crowned with white hair, as seen from behind looked bigger than a head ought to be.
fr: Vue de derriere comme la voyait Syme, la tete, couronnee de cheveux blancs, paraissait plus haute et plus large que nature,

eng: He was enlarged terribly to scale; and this sense of size was so staggering, that when Syme saw him all the other figures seemed quite suddenly to dwindle and become dwarfish.
fr: Tout etait en proportion. Aupres de ce colosse, tous les autres hommes se rapetissaient, devenaient des nains.

eng: They were still sitting there as before with their flowers and frock-coats, but now it looked as if the big man was entertaining five children to tea.
fr: A les voir, assis tous les cinq autour de la table, on eut dit que le grand homme offrait le the a des enfants.

eng: Syme, indeed, was one of those men who are open to all the more nameless psychological influences in a degree a little dangerous to mental health.
fr: Syme etait un de ces hommes qui sont sujets aux influences psychologiques les plus obscures, a un degre qui ne va pas sans quelque danger pour la sante de l'esprit.

eng: Utterly devoid of fear in physical dangers, he was a great deal too sensitive to the smell of spiritual evil.
fr: Inaccessible a la peur physique, il etait beaucoup trop sensible a l'odeur du mal moral.

eng: Twice already that night little unmeaning things had peeped out at him almost pruriently, and given him a sense of drawing nearer and nearer to the head-quarters of hell. ~~~ And this sense became overpowering as he drew nearer to the great President.
fr: Plusieurs fois deja pendant cette nuit, des choses insignifiantes avaient pris a ses yeux une importance capitale, lui donnant la sensation qu'il etait en route vers le quartier general de l'enfer ; et cette sensation devenait irresistible, maintenant qu'il allait aborder le grand President.

eng: The form it took was a childish and yet hateful fancy.
fr: Elle prit la forme d'une suggestion puerile et pourtant detestable.

eng: As he walked across the inner room towards the balcony, the large face of Sunday grew larger and larger; and Syme was gripped with a fear that when he was quite close the face would be too big to be possible, and that he would scream aloud.
fr: Comme il s'avancait vers le balcon en traversant la piece qui le precedait, il lui sembla que la large figure de Dimanche s'elargissait encore, s'amplifiait toujours, et Syme fut pris de terreur a la pensee que cette figure serait bientot trop vaste pour etre possible, et qu'il ne pourrait s'empecher de jeter un cri.

eng: He remembered that as a child he would not look at the mask of Memnon in the British Museum, because it was a face, and so large.
fr: Il se rappelait qu'enfant il ne pouvait regarder le masque de Memnon au Musee britannique, parce que c'etait une figure, et si grande.

eng: By an effort, braver than that of leaping over a cliff, he went to an empty seat at the breakfast-table and sat down.
fr: Par un effort plus heroique que celui qu'il faudrait pour se precipiter du haut d'une falaise, il se dirigea vers un siege vacant aupres de la table et s'assit.

eng: He sobered himself a little by looking at their conventional coats and solid, shining coffee-pot;
fr: Il retrouva un peu de serenite en constatant que ses voisins etaient convenablement et normalement vetus, que la cafetiere etait brillante et solide.

eng: which gave the meal the look of a wedding breakfast.
fr: si bien qu'on se fut cru a un festin de noce.

eng: nothing about them caught the eye at first, except that by the President's caprice they had been dressed up with a festive respectability,
fr: Rien de frappant, a premiere vue, sinon que, pour obeir au caprice du maitre, tous les membres du Conseil etaient mis comme pour un gala,

eng: In the presence of the President the whole company looked sufficiently commonplace;
fr: Comparee au President, toute la compagnie avait l'air passablement vulgaire.

eng: His face was very large, but it was still possible to humanity.
fr: oui, son visage etait fort grand, mais il ne depassait tout de meme pas les proportions permises a l'humanite.

eng: then he looked again at Sunday.
fr: Puis, il jeta de nouveau un regard sur Dimanche :

eng: The men greeted him with good-humoured raillery as if they had always known him.
fr: Les autres le saluerent avec bonne humeur, avec familiarite, comme s'ils l'avaient connu de longue date.

eng: One man indeed stood out at even a superficial glance.
fr: L'un de ces individus se distinguait, pourtant, a l'examen le plus superficiel.

eng: He at least was the common or garden Dynamiter.
fr: On pouvait reconnaitre en lui le dynamiteur vulgaire et pour ainsi dire vulgaris.

eng: He wore, indeed, the high white collar and satin tie that were the uniform of the occasion; but out of this collar there sprang a head quite unmanageable and quite unmistakable, a bewildering bush of brown hair and beard that almost obscured the eyes like those of a Skye terrier.
fr: Il portait bien, comme les autres, un grand col blanc et une cravate de satin : l'uniforme. ~~~ Mais, de ce col et de cette cravate emergeait une tete indisciplinable. ~~~ Pas moyen de s'y tromper.

eng: But the eyes did look out of the tangle, and they were the sad eyes of some Russian serf.
fr: C'etait une broussaille etonnante de barbe et de cheveux bruns ou luisaient les yeux d'un terrier, ou plutot peut-etre les yeux tristes d'un moujik russe.

eng: And, indeed, when Syme came in the President, with that daring disregard of public suspicion which was his policy, was actually chaffing Gogol upon his inability to assume conventional graces.
fr: Justement, comme Syme entrait, le President, avec ce mepris audacieux de la suspicion publique dont il avait fait un principe, etait en train de railler Gogol, lui reprochant d'etre refractaire aux manieres et graces mondaines.

eng: Now if a gentleman goes about London in a top hat and a frock-coat, no one need know that he is an anarchist.
fr: Qu'un gentleman coiffe du haut-de-forme, vetu de la redingote classique, se promene dignement dans Londres, personne ne soupconnera en lui un anarchiste.

eng: The effect of this figure was not terrible like that of the President, but it had every diablerie that can come from the utterly grotesque.
fr: Cette figure n'etait pas terrifiante, comme celle du President ; mais elle avait toute cette diablerie qui est un effet de l'extreme grotesque.

eng: If out of that stiff tie and collar there had come abruptly the head of a cat or a dog, it could not have been a more idiotic contrast.
fr: Si de ce col avait surgi une tete de chat ou de chien, le contraste n'eut pas ete plus deconcertant.

eng: The man's name, it seemed, was Gogol; he was a Pole, and in this circle of days he was called Tuesday.
fr: Cet homme, parait-il, se nommait Gogol. Il etait polonais et, dans ce cycle des jours de la semaine, portait le nom de Mardi.

eng: His soul and speech were incurably tragic; he could not force himself to play the prosperous and frivolous part demanded of him by President Sunday.
fr: Sa physionomie et son langage etaient incurablement tragiques, et il n'etait point en etat de jouer le role frivole et joyeux que lui imposait Dimanche.

eng: "Our friend Tuesday," said the President in a deep voice at once of quietude and volume, "our friend Tuesday doesn't seem to grasp the idea.
fr: -- Notre ami Mardi, disait le President de sa voix profonde et calme, ne saisit pas bien mon idee.

eng: He dresses up like a gentleman, but he seems to be too great a soul to behave like one.
fr: Il s'habille comme un gentleman, mais on voit qu'il a l'ame trop grande pour se tenir comme un gentleman.

eng: He insists on the ways of the stage conspirator.
fr: Il ne peut renoncer aux attitudes des conspirateurs de melodrame.

eng: But if a gentleman puts on a top hat and a frock-coat, and then goes about on his hands and knees well, he may attract attention.
fr: Mais si, tout bien mis qu'il soit, il se met a marcher a quatre pattes, alors, certes, il attirera l'attention.

eng: That's what Brother Gogol does.
fr: C'est ce que fait le frere Gogol.

eng: He goes about on his hands and knees with such inexhaustible diplomacy, that by this time he finds it quite difficult to walk upright."
fr: Il a mis une si profonde diplomatie a marcher a quatre pattes qu'il eprouve maintenant une reelle difficulte a se tenir sur ses pieds.

eng: "I am not good at concealment," said Gogol sulkily, with a thick foreign accent; "I am not ashamed of the cause."
fr: '-- Che ne suis bas habile a me teguiser, fit Gogol d'un air farouche, avec un fort accent etranger. ~~~ Che n'ai bas honte de la gause.'

eng: "Yes you are, my boy, and so is the cause of you," said the President good-naturedly.
fr: '-- Mais si ! ~~~ repliqua le President avec gaite, et la cause a honte de vous.'

eng: "You hide as much as anybody; but you can't do it, you see, you're such an ass! You try to combine two inconsistent methods."
fr: 'Vous vous efforcez autant qu'un autre de vous cacher, mais vous n'y reussissez pas, parce que vous etes un ane. Vous pretendez concilier deux methodes inconciliables.'

eng: "When a householder finds a man under his bed, he will probably pause to note the circumstance."
fr: 'Quand un proprietaire trouve un homme sous son lit, naturellement il prend note de cette circonstance.'

eng: "But if he finds a man under his bed in a top hat, you will agree with me, my dear Tuesday, that he is not likely even to forget it."
fr: 'Mais, si c'est un homme coiffe du haut-de-forme qu'il trouve sous son lit, il est peu probable, vous en conviendrez avec moi, mon cher Mardi, qu'il l'oublie facilement.'

eng: "Now when you were found under Admiral Biffin's bed..."
fr: 'Or, quand on vous trouva sous le lit de l'amiral Biffin...'

eng: The only metaphor he could think of was this, that they all looked as men of fashion and presence would look, with the additional twist given in a false and curved mirror.
fr: 'Syme se formula a lui-meme sa propre pensee en se disant que ces gens-la lui apparaissaient comme auraient fait des gens a la mode et bien eleves avec la legere touche qu'y aurait ajoutee un miroir fausse, concave ou convexe.'

eng: "Right, my boy, right," said the President with a ponderous heartiness, "you aren't good at anything."
fr: '-- Parfaitement, mon ami, parfaitement, mon ami, interrompit le President avec une lourde bonhomie : vous n'etes habile a rien.'

eng: "I am not good at deception," said Tuesday gloomily, flushing.
fr: '-- Je ne suis pas habile a tromper le monde... repondit Gogol rougissant.'

eng: But now that Syme had more space and light to observe him, there were other touches.
fr: 'Mais, maintenant que Syme pouvait le considerer a loisir et au grand jour, il distinguait en lui d'autres singularites.'

eng: Syme's original cicerone bore the title of Monday; he was the Secretary of the Council, and his twisted smile was regarded with more terror than anything, except the President's horrible, happy laughter.
fr: 'Le cicerone de Syme etait Lundi, secretaire du Conseil. ~~~ Apres le rire abominablement rejoui du President, rien de plus affreux que le rictus du secretaire.'

eng: Only the individual examples will express this half-concealed eccentricity.
fr: 'Des precisions individuelles pourront seules rendre compte de cette secrete anomalie.'

eng: Each man had something about him, perceived perhaps at the tenth or twentieth glance, which was not normal, and which seemed hardly human.
fr: 'Ils avaient tous quelque chose d'exceptionnel, qui se derobait a la premiere analyse, et ce quelque chose d'exceptionnel etait quelque chose d'a peine humain.'

eng: His fine face was so emaciated, that Syme thought it must be wasted with some disease; yet somehow the very distress of his dark eyes denied this.
fr: 'Ce visage noble, mais invraisemblablement emacie, denoncait-il les ravages de la maladie ? ~~~ L'intensite meme de la detresse qu'on lisait dans ses yeux protestait contre cette hypothese.'

eng: But as he looked at the others, he began to see in each of them exactly what he had seen in the man by the river, a demoniac detail somewhere.
fr: 'Mais, en les etudiant avec plus d'attention, il observait en chacun d'eux, comme chez l'homme qui l'avait attendu sur le quai, un caractere demoniaque.'

eng: He had thought at first that they were all of common stature and costume, with the evident exception of the hairy Gogol.
fr: 'Les commensaux de Dimanche, Gogol excepte, lui avaient d'abord paru des gens assez normaux et meme vulgaires, somme toute.'

eng: As he did so, he gradually felt all his sense of something spiritually queer return.
fr: 'Et de nouveau il se sentait opprime par l'horreur que lui causaient toujours les monstruosites psychiques.'

eng: While this stream of conversation continued, Syme was looking more steadily at the men around him.
fr: 'Tandis que la conversation se poursuivait, Syme examinait les hommes qui l'entouraient.'

eng: That lop-sided laugh, which would suddenly disfigure the fine face of his original guide, was typical of all these types.
fr: 'Au rictus grimacant qui defigurait soudain les traits de son guide correspondait chez tous quelque deformation.'

eng: It was no physical ill that troubled him.
fr: Cet homme ne souffrait pas d'un mal physique.

eng: It reminded one irrationally of drowsy odours and of dying lamps in the darker poems of Byron and Poe.
fr: Cela faisait songer aux odeurs enivrantes, aux lampes mourantes des plus mysterieux poemes de Byron ou de Poe.

eng: But Syme, sensitive to such things, felt somehow that the man carried a rich atmosphere with him, a rich atmosphere that suffocated.
fr: Syme ne tarda pas a s'apercevoir qu'on respirait autour de ce personnage une atmosphere terriblement capiteuse, capiteuse a en etouffer.

eng: He had a black French beard cut square and a black English frock-coat cut even squarer.
fr: De tous, c'etait le seul qui portat ses habits elegants comme s'ils eussent ete vraiment les siens. Il arborait une barbe noire, taillee en carre, a la francaise ; mais sa redingote affectait la plus pure coupe britannique.

eng: Next was Wednesday, a certain Marquis de St. Eustache, a sufficiently characteristic figure.
fr: Mais n'etait-ce pas un fou aussi que Mercredi, -- un certain marquis de Saint-Eustache, figure aussi peu banale que les deux autres ?

eng: Next to him sat Tuesday, the tousle-headed Gogol, a man more obviously mad.
fr: La folie de Mardi se trahissait plus vite que celle de son voisin Lundi.

eng: His eyes were alive with intellectual torture, as if pure thought was pain.
fr: Sa souffrance etait purement intellectuelle : c'etait sa pensee qui faisait sa torture.

eng: The first few glances found nothing unusual about him, except that he was the only man at table who wore the fashionable clothes as if they were really his own.
fr: Au premier abord, on ne trouvait rien d'inusite chez lui.

eng: He was typical of each of the tribe; each man was subtly and differently wrong.
fr: Et ce trait apparentait entre eux tous les membres du Conseil.

eng: With this went a sense of his being clad, not in lighter colours, but in softer materials; his black seemed richer and warmer than the black shades about him, as if it were compounded of profound colour.
fr: Tout, chez lui, prenait un accent special ; le drap noir de son habit paraissait plus riche, plus chaud, teint d'une couleur plus intense que celle des ombres noires qui l'entouraient.

eng: His black coat looked as if it were only black by being too dense a purple.
fr: Le secret de ce noir, c'est qu'il etait une pourpre trop dense.

eng: His black beard looked as if it were only black by being too deep a blue.
fr: Et le secret aussi de sa barbe si noire, c'est qu'elle etait d'un bleu trop fonce.

eng: he might be a Jew;
fr: Peut-etre un juif ;

eng: he might be something deeper yet in the dark heart of the East.
fr: mais, vraisemblablement ses racines plongeaient plus profondement encore au sombre coeur de l'Orient.

eng: Whatever he was he was not a Frenchman;
fr: D'ou qu'il vint, il n'etait certainement pas francais.

eng: And in the gloom and thickness of the beard his dark red mouth showed sensual and scornful.
fr: Dans l'epaisseur tenebreuse de cette barbe, la bouche, d'un rouge ardent, etincelait, sensuelle et meprisante.

eng: In the bright coloured Persian tiles and pictures showing tyrants hunting, you may see just those almond eyes, those blue-black beards, those cruel, crimson lips.
fr: Dans les tableaux joyeusement barioles et sur les briques de la sombre cour de Perse, qui representent des tyrans en chasse, on voit de ces yeux en amande, de ces barbes noires aux reflets bleus, de ces levres ecarlates et feroces.

eng: Again and again Syme strove to pull together his common sense in their presence.
fr: A plusieurs reprises, Syme fit un grand effort pour reconquerir son sang-froid en leur presence.

eng: Such were the six men who had sworn to destroy the world.
fr: Tels etaient les six hommes qui avaient jure la destruction du monde.

eng: CHAPTER VI. THE EXPOSURE
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VI DEMASQUE !

eng: Syme even had the thought that his eyes might be covered up because they were too frightful to see.
fr: Il pensa meme que le docteur ne se cachait ainsi les yeux que parce qu'ils etaient trop horribles a voir.

eng: Partly from this, and partly because he had a vulgar virility wanting in most of the others it seemed to Syme that he might be the wickedest of all those wicked men.
fr: Cette singularite, jointe a cette virilite vulgaire dont tous les autres, sauf Gogol, etaient prives, persuada Syme que le docteur aux yeux noirs devait etre le pire d'entre ces mauvais.

eng: You could not tell what his smile or his gravity meant.
fr: Que signifiait son eternel sourire ? Que voulait dire sa gravite ?

eng: They took away the key of the face.
fr: Elles cachaient pour ainsi dire ce qui en eut ete la cle.

eng: But on the younger and grosser man they seemed only an enigma.
fr: Elles ne convenaient pas a ce jeune homme rable, dont elles rendaient la physionomie bizarrement enigmatique.

eng: Had the dying Professor worn them, or even the pale Secretary, they would have been appropriate.
fr: Sur le nez du vieux professeur ou du pale secretaire, elles ne l'eussent point surpris.

eng: Syme's eye always caught the black glasses and the blind grin.
fr: Le regard de Syme ne pouvait se detacher de ces lunettes noires, de ce sourire fige.

eng: Then came Syme, and next a very old man, Professor de Worms, who still kept the chair of Friday, though every day it was expected that his death would leave it empty.
fr: Puis venait Syme, et puis un tres vieux monsieur, l'illustre professeur de Worms, occupait le siege de Vendredi. Du moins, il l'occupait encore, mais on pouvait chaque jour s'attendre a ce qu'il le laissat vacant.

eng: There was nothing whatever odd about him, except that he wore a pair of dark, almost opaque spectacles.
fr: Seul signe particulier : il avait sur le nez une paire de lunettes aux verres noirs, presque opaques.

eng: In no other case, not even that of Gogol, did the bridegroom brilliancy of the morning dress express a more painful contrast.
fr: Nul autre, pas meme Gogol, ne faisait avec son habit de fiance un contraste plus penible.

eng: It may have been merely a crescendo of nervous fancy that had gone before, but those black discs were dreadful to Syme; they reminded him of half-remembered ugly tales, of some story about pennies being put on the eyes of the dead.
fr: Pourquoi ces disques sombres epouvanterent-ils Syme ? Peut-etre le crescendo d'imaginations delirantes qui l'agitait le predisposait-il a tout prendre au tragique. Il se rememora aussitot une affreuse histoire, a demi oubliee, ou il etait question de sous qu'on incrustait dans les yeux des morts.

eng: Save for his intellect, he was in the last dissolution of senile decay.
fr: Encore que son cerveau gardat toute son activite, le professeur penchait au dernier periode de la decadence senile.

eng: For the red flower in his button-hole showed up against a face that was literally discoloured like lead; the whole hideous effect was as if some drunken dandies had put their clothes upon a corpse.
fr: La fleur rouge de sa boutonniere accusait, exagerait encore la lividite d'un visage litteralement decolore, plombe. ~~~ On eut dit un cadavre que quelques dandies ivres auraient affuble de leurs habits mondains.

eng: When he rose or sat down, which was with long labour and peril, something worse was expressed than mere weakness, something indefinably connected with the horror of the whole scene.
fr: Chaque fois qu'il devait se lever ou s'asseoir, ce qui n'allait pas sans peine, ses mouvements trahissaient quelque chose de pire qu'une simple faiblesse, quelque chose d'indefinissablement lie a l'horreur de toute la scene.

eng: It did not express decrepitude merely, but corruption.
fr: Ce n'etait pas seulement de la decrepitude, c'etait deja de la pourriture !

eng: His face was as grey as his long grey beard, his forehead was lifted and fixed finally in a furrow of mild despair.
fr: Son visage etait aussi gris que sa longue barbe grise. Une ride profonde, expression d'un doux desespoir, creusait son front.

eng: He could not help thinking that whenever the man moved a leg or arm might fall off.
fr: Il ne put s'empecher de penser qu'a chaque mouvement le professeur pouvait tres bien laisser choir un de ses bras ou une de ses jambes.

eng: Another hateful fancy crossed Syme's quivering mind.
fr: Une idee detestable traversa l'esprit fremissant de Syme.

eng: He had that combination of _savoir-faire_ with a sort of well-groomed coarseness which is not uncommon in young doctors.
fr: On observait chez lui ce melange de desinvolture et de familiarite polie qui caracterise souvent les jeunes medecins.

eng: He carried his fine clothes with confidence rather than ease, and he mostly wore a set smile.
fr: Il portait ses beaux habits hardiment plutot qu'avec aisance, et un sourire vague restait fige sur ses levres.

eng: Right at the end sat the man called Saturday, the simplest and the most baffling of all.
fr: Samedi tenait le bout de la table. ~~~ Le plus simple de tous ; non pas le moins etonnant.

eng: He was a short, square man with a dark, square face clean-shaven, a medical practitioner going by the name of Bull.
fr: Ce petit homme trapu, au visage carre et rase de pres, portait le nom de Bull : le docteur Bull.

eng: Sometimes he saw for an instant that these notions were subjective, that he was only looking at ordinary men, one of whom was old, another nervous, another short-sighted.
fr: Par instants, il se rendait compte qu'il n'y avait la que des gens fort ordinaires, dont l'un etait vieux, l'autre neurasthenique, l'autre myope...

eng: The sense of an unnatural symbolism always settled back on him again.
fr: Mais toujours il retombait sous l'empire d'un symbolisme fantastique.

eng: Each figure seemed to be, somehow, on the borderland of things, just as their theory was on the borderland of thought.
fr: Chacun de ces personnages paraissait situe a l'extreme frontiere des choses, de meme que leur theorie etait a l'extreme frontiere de la pensee.

eng: He knew that each one of these men stood at the extreme end, so to speak, of some wild road of reasoning.
fr: Il savait que chacun de ces hommes se tenait pour ainsi dire au point extreme de quelque route sauvage de la pensee.

eng: He could only fancy, as in some old-world fable, that if a man went westward to the end of the world he would find something say a tree that was more or less than a tree, a tree possessed by a spirit;
fr: -- Un homme, songeait Syme, qui marcherait toujours vers l'ouest jusqu'au bout du monde, finirait sans doute par trouver quelque chose, par exemple un arbre, qui serait a la fois plus et moins qu'un arbre, soit un arbre possede par des esprits.

eng: and that if he went east to the end of the world he would find something else that was not wholly itself a tower, perhaps, of which the very shape was wicked.
fr: ~~~ Et, de meme, en allant toujours vers l'est, jusqu'au bout du monde, il rencontrerait une certaine chose qui ne serait pas non plus tout a fait cette chose meme, une tour peut-etre, dont l'architecture deja serait un peche.

eng: and over their bacon and eggs upon their sunny balcony these beaming gentlemen had decided how both should die.
fr: et, sur le balcon ensoleille, en consommant leur jambon et leurs oeufs, ces joyeux conspirateurs decidaient la mort de l'un et de l'autre.

eng: Only three days afterwards the Czar was to meet the President of the French Republic in Paris,
fr: Dans trois jours, le Tsar devait rencontrer le President de la Republique francaise a Paris,

eng: The waiter downstairs had spoken quite correctly when he said that they were talking about bombs and kings.
fr: Le garcon ne se trompait pas en disant qu'il s'agissait de bombes et de rois.

eng: They were deep in the discussion of an actual and immediate plot.
fr: Ils parlaient, a fond, d'un complot a realiser sans remise.

eng: and not the least of the contrasts of that bewildering breakfast-table was the contrast between the easy and unobtrusive tone of talk and its terrible purport.
fr: et le ton aise et enjoue des causeurs faisait avec le sujet de l'entretien le plus etonnant des contrastes que reunissait cet etonnant dejeuner.

eng: Talk had been going on steadily as he took in the scene;
fr: La conversation ne s'etait pas interrompue,

eng: The ends of the earth were closing in.
fr: En eux les deux bouts du monde se rejoignaient.

eng: So these figures seemed to stand up, violent and unaccountable, against an ultimate horizon, visions from the verge.
fr: C'est ainsi que les membres du Conseil, avec leurs silhouettes violentes et incomprehensibles, etaient pour Syme de vivantes visions de l'abime, et se detachaient sur un horizon ultime.

eng: Even the instrument was chosen; the black-bearded Marquis, it appeared, was to carry the bomb.
fr: On designait meme le camarade qui jetterait la bombe : c'etait le marquis a la barbe noire.

eng: Very simply, he had no fear to spare for the French President or the Czar; he had begun to fear for himself.
fr: Ce n'etait plus pour le Tsar et le President de la Republique qu'il tremblait : c'etait pour lui-meme.

eng: Most of the talkers took little heed of him, debating now with their faces closer together, and almost uniformly grave, save when for an instant the smile of the Secretary ran aslant across his face as the jagged lightning runs aslant across the sky.
fr: La plupart des anarchistes, passionnement interesses par la discussion, ne se preoccupaient guere de Syme. ~~~ Serres les uns contre les autres, ils etaient tous tres graves. A peine le rictus du secretaire passait-il parfois sur son visage, comme un eclair dans le ciel.

eng: But there was one persistent thing which first troubled Syme and at last terrified him. The President was always looking at him, steadily, and with a great and baffling interest.
fr: Mais Syme fit une remarque qui d'abord le troubla et bientot le terrifia : le President ne cessait de le regarder fixement, de le devisager, avec un interet persistant.

eng: He would have thought of nothing but the need of saving at least two human bodies from being ripped in pieces with iron and roaring gas.
fr: Il n'aurait plus pense qu'a la necessite de sauver les deux hommes des fragments de fer et de la deflagration de la poudre qui menacait de les dechiqueter.

eng: But the truth was that by this time he had begun to feel a third kind of fear, more piercing and practical than either his moral revulsion or his social responsibility.
fr: Mais le fait est qu'en ce moment precis, il commencait a ressentir une crainte personnelle, immediate, ou s'evanouissaient ses sentiments de repulsion et meme le souci de ses responsabilites sociales.

eng: Ordinarily speaking, the proximity of this positive and objective crime would have sobered Syme, and cured him of all his merely mystical tremors.
fr: Dans des circonstances moins extraordinaires, l'imminence de la realite objective, positive, du crime aurait calme Syme et dissipe ses craintes purement mystiques.

eng: The enormous man was quite quiet, but his blue eyes stood out of his head. ~~~ And they were always fixed on Syme.
fr: L'enorme individu restait parfaitement calme ; mais ses yeux bleus lui sortaient de la tete, et ces terribles yeux etaient fixes sur Syme.

eng: Syme felt moved to spring up and leap over the balcony.
fr: Syme eprouva un desir presque irresistible de sauter dans la rue, par-dessus le balcon.

eng: When the President's eyes were on him he felt as if he were made of glass. ~~~ He had hardly the shred of a doubt that in some silent and extraordinary way Sunday had found out that he was a spy.
fr: Il se sentait transparent comme le verre pour les prunelles aigues de Dimanche et ne doutait plus que sa qualite d'espion, de quelque silencieuse et extraordinaire facon, n'eut ete eventee par cet homme redoutable.

eng: He looked over the edge of the balcony, and saw a policeman, standing abstractedly just beneath, staring at the bright railings and the sunlit trees.
fr: Il jeta un regard par-dessus la balustrade du balcon et vit, juste en bas, un policeman qui considerait distraitement les grilles du square et les arbres ensoleilles.

eng: Then there fell upon him the great temptation that was to torment him for many days.
fr: Il eut alors une intense tentation qui devait plus d'une fois le hanter durant les jours qui suivirent.

eng: In the presence of these powerful and repulsive men, who were the princes of anarchy, he had almost forgotten the frail and fanciful figure of the poet Gregory, the mere aesthete of anarchism.
fr: Dans la compagnie de ces etres hideux, repugnants et puissants, de ces princes de l'anarchie, il avait jusqu'alors presque oublie ce personnage falot, le poete Gregory, simple esthete de l'anarchie.

eng: He even thought of him now with an old kindness, as if they had played together when children.
fr: Il se ressouvenait de lui, maintenant, avec une sorte de sympathie, comme d'un ami avec lequel il aurait joue, jadis, dans son enfance.

eng: He had promised never to do the very thing that he now felt himself almost in the act of doing.
fr: il lui avait promis de ne pas faire precisement ce qu'il avait ete sur le point de faire.

eng: He took his cold hand off the cold stone balustrade.
fr: Il retira sa main glacee de la froide balustrade de pierre.

eng: He had promised not to jump over that balcony and speak to that policeman.
fr: Il lui avait promis de ne pas enjamber le balcon, de ne pas appeler ce policeman.

eng: But he remembered that he was still tied to Gregory by a great promise.
fr: Mais il se rappelait aussi qu'il restait lie a Gregory par une promesse intransgressible :

eng: His soul swayed in a vertigo of moral indecision.
fr: Son ame roulait dans un vertige d'indecision.

eng: He had only to snap the thread of a rash vow made to a villainous society, and all his life could be as open and sunny as the square beneath him.
fr: Il n'avait qu'a violer un serment inconsidere, prete a une societe de bandits, et sa vie devenait aussi belle et riante que ce square ensoleille.

eng: He had, on the other hand, only to keep his antiquated honour, and be delivered inch by inch into the power of this great enemy of mankind, whose very intellect was a torture-chamber.
fr: D'autre part, s'il restait fidele aux lois antiques de l'honneur, il se livrait peu a peu sans recours a ce grand ennemi de l'humanite dont l'evidente et immense intelligence etait une chambre de torture.

eng: Whenever he looked down into the square he saw the comfortable policeman, a pillar of common sense and common order.
fr: Chaque fois qu'il se tournait vers le square, il voyait le policeman, confortable comme un pilier du sens commun et de l'ordre public.

eng: Whenever he looked back at the breakfast-table he saw the President still quietly studying him with big, unbearable eyes.
fr: Et, chaque fois que le regard de Syme revenait a la table, il voyait le President qui continuait a l'epier, de ses gros yeux insupportables.

eng: In all the torrent of his thought there were two thoughts that never crossed his mind.
fr: Il est deux idees, cependant, qui, dans le torrent de ses pensees, ne lui vinrent pas a l'esprit.

eng: Either by anonymous poison or sudden street accident, by hypnotism or by fire from hell, Sunday could certainly strike him.
fr: Poison anonyme ou brusque accident, fortuit en apparence, hypnotisme, feu infernal : peu importait comment, mais certainement Dimanche pouvait le frapper.

eng: But Sunday was not the man who would carry himself thus easily without having, somehow or somewhere, set open his iron trap.
fr: Mais Dimanche n'etait pas homme a montrer tant d'aisance sans avoir, quelque part et de quelque maniere, prepare son piege.

eng: The place might be public, the project might seem impossible.
fr: Sans doute, sur une place publique une telle execution eut pu paraitre impossible.

eng: First, it never occurred to him to doubt that the President and his Council could crush him if he continued to stand alone.
fr: D'abord, il ne lui arriva pas un instant de mettre en doute que le President et son Conseil ne pussent l'aneantir, s'il restait la, seul, parmi ces miserables.

eng: If he defied the man he was probably dead, either struck stiff there in his chair or long afterwards as by an innocent ailment.
fr: Que Syme osat defier cet homme, et Syme etait condamne -- atteint de paralysie sur son siege ou mourant longtemps apres de quelque maladie mysterieuse.

eng: If he called in the police promptly, arrested everyone, told all, and set against them the whole energy of England, he would probably escape; certainly not otherwise.
fr: En appelant sur-le-champ la police, en faisant arreter tout le monde, en racontant tout, en suscitant contre ces monstres toute l'energie de l'Angleterre, peut-etre eut-il echappe.

eng: Mais son salut n'exigeait certainement pas moins.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He might have been called something above man, with his large plans, which were too obvious to be detected, with his large face, which was too frank to be understood.
fr: Oui, cet etre aux plans vastes, trop visibles pour etre vus, au visage trop ouvert, trop explicite pour qu'on le comprit, pouvait faire penser qu'il y avait la plus qu'un homme.

eng: If any such creature be conceivable, he looked, indeed, somewhat like it, with his earth-shaking abstraction, as of a stone statue walking.
fr: Et, en effet, si le Surhomme est concevable, Dimanche lui ressemblait beaucoup, avec son energie capable d'ebranler la terre dans un moment de distraction. C'etait une statue de pierre en mouvement.

eng: They might have called Sunday the super-man.
fr: Ils auraient salue en lui le Surhomme.

eng: Many moderns, inured to a weak worship of intellect and force, might have wavered in their allegiance under this oppression of a great personality.
fr: Beaucoup d'autres, en ce temps, habitues a honorer de toute leur faiblesse l'intelligence et la force, auraient pu hesiter dans leur loyaute, ceder au prestige oppressif de la puissante personnalite de Dimanche.

eng: It never occurred to him to be spiritually won over to the enemy.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: There was a second thought that never came to him.
fr: Et il n'eut pas davantage l'idee qu'il pourrait etre gagne a l'ennemi.

eng: They were a balconyful of gentlemen overlooking a bright and busy square; but he felt no more safe with them than if they had been a boatful of armed pirates overlooking an empty sea.
fr: Il y avait la, sur un balcon, au-dessus d'un square passager, quelques gentlemen, parmi lesquels Syme ne se sentait pas plus en securite qu'il ne l'eut ete, au milieu de la mer deserte, dans une chaloupe pleine de pirates armes.

eng: But this was a kind of modern meanness to which Syme could not sink even in his extreme morbidity.
fr: Mais Syme, quelle que fut la depression dont il souffrit, n'etait pas expose a tomber dans cette faiblesse, si moderne.

eng: Like any man, he was coward enough to fear great force; but he was not quite coward enough to admire it.
fr: Comme tout le monde, il etait assez lache pour craindre la force ; il n'etait pas tout a fait assez lache pour l'admirer.

eng: "You are wrong," said the Secretary, drawing his black brows together.
fr: -- Vous avez tort, protesta le secretaire en froncant les sourcils.

eng: "The knife was merely the expression of the old personal quarrel with a personal tyrant.
fr: Le couteau convenait a l'antique querelle personnelle d'un individu contre un tyran.

eng: Dynamite is not only our best tool, but our best symbol.
fr: La dynamite n'est pas seulement notre instrument le meilleur, elle est aussi notre meilleur symbole.

eng: "Every man knows in his heart," he said, "that nothing is worth doing."
fr: -- Chacun sait, dit-il, chacun sait, au fond de son coeur, que rien ne vaut aucun effort.

eng: It is as perfect a symbol of us as is incense of the prayers of the Christians.
fr: Un aussi parfait symbole de l'anarchie que peut l'etre l'encens pour les prieres des chretiens.

eng: It expands; it only destroys because it broadens; even so, thought only destroys because it broadens.
fr: La dynamite se repand et ne tue que parce qu'elle se repand. La pensee aussi ne detruit que parce qu'elle se repand.

eng: A man's brain is a bomb," he cried out, loosening suddenly his strange passion and striking his own skull with violence.
fr: Le cerveau est une bombe !

eng: The old Professor was staring at the ceiling with dull eyes.
fr: Le vieux professeur regardait au plafond de ses yeux morts.

eng: "No, if the only end of the thing is nothing," said Dr. Bull with his sphinx-like smile, "it hardly seems worth doing."
fr: -- En effet, dit le docteur Bull avec son sourire de sphinx, si le neant est le but unique de tout, cela vaut-il le moindre effort ?

eng: I thought of one yesterday in bed."
fr: J'y pensais hier soir, dans mon lit.

eng: "I want to do a lot of beastly things before I die.
fr: je veux faire autant de mal que je pourrai avant de mourir.

eng: "I don't want the universe broken up just yet," drawled the Marquis.
fr: -- Je ne desire pas que l'univers saute en ce moment, dit le marquis, tres bas :

eng: A man's brain must expand, if it breaks up the universe."
fr: Il faut que la pensee se repande, l'univers en fut-il reduit en poussiere.

eng: It must expand! It must expand!
fr: Il veut se repandre ! Il faut qu'il se repande !

eng: I take it we should all agree with the original notion of a bomb.
fr: Il me semble que nous devons nous en tenir a l'idee premiere : la bombe.

eng: The only question is how Wednesday is to strike the blow.
fr: La question est celle de savoir comment Mercredi frappera son coup.

eng: "Before we discuss that," he said in a small, quiet voice, "let us go into a private room.'
fr: -- Avant d'en venir a discuter ce point, dit-il d'une voix etrangement flutee, je vous prie de m'accompagner dans un cabinet particulier.'

eng: President Sunday had risen to his feet, seeming to fill the sky above them.
fr: Le President Dimanche s'etait leve, et il n'y avait plus de ciel au-dessus du balcon.

eng: The speech was broken off short under a vast shadow.
fr: Le secretaire s'interrompit brusquement : une ombre vaste venait de s'allonger sur la table.

eng: As to the actual arrangements, I should suggest that tomorrow morning he should go first of all to "
fr: Quant aux details, je suis d'avis que, des demain matin, notre camarade s'embarque pour...

eng: "My brain feels like a bomb, night and day.
fr: s'ecria-t-il en s'abandonnant soudain a sa passion et en se frappant le crane avec violence : mon cerveau est une bombe que je sens sur le point, sans cesse, d'eclater !

eng: There was a singular silence, and then the Secretary said "We are wandering, however, from the point.
fr: Il se fit un etrange silence, puis : -- Nous nous ecartons de la question, observa le secretaire.

eng: And it would be a new emotion to get a knife into a French President and wriggle it round."
fr: Quelle exquise sensation ! Enfoncer un couteau dans le dos d'un President de la Republique et retourner le fer dans la plaie !

eng: "I have often wondered," said the Marquis, taking a great bite out of a slice of bread and jam, "whether it wouldn't be better for me to do it with a knife.
fr: -- Je me suis demande souvent, dit le marquis, en mordant dans une tartine de confiture, si je ne ferais pas mieux d'employer le couteau, de preference a la bombe.

eng: Most of the best things have been brought off with a knife.
fr: Le couteau a servi a couper d'excellentes choses.

eng: The men were eating as they talked, and even in this they were typical.
fr: Les anarchistes mangeaient en causant, et jusque dans leur maniere de manger se revelait le caractere de chacun.

eng: Dr. Bull and the Marquis ate casually and conventionally of the best things on the table cold pheasant or Strasbourg pie.
fr: Le docteur Bull et le marquis chipotaient avec negligence les meilleurs morceaux, du faisan froid, du pate de Strasbourg.

eng: The old Professor had such slops as suggested a sickening second childhood.
fr: Le vieux professeur avait des hoquets precurseurs d'un prochain gatisme.

eng: And even in this President Sunday preserved his curious predominance of mere mass.
fr: Le President gardait, la comme en tout, la superiorite incontestable de sa masse.

eng: For he ate like twenty men; he ate incredibly, with a frightful freshness of appetite, so that it was like watching a sausage factory.
fr: Il mangeait comme vingt ! Il mangeait incroyablement !

eng: But the Secretary was a vegetarian, and he spoke earnestly of the projected murder over half a raw tomato and three quarters of a glass of tepid water.
fr: Le secretaire etait vegetarien, et discutait de bombes et de meurtres tout en absorbant une tomate crue, arrosee d'un verre d'eau tiede.

eng: Yet continually, when he had swallowed a dozen crumpets or drunk a quart of coffee, he would be found with his great head on one side staring at Syme.
fr: On eut cru en le regardant devorer, assister a la manoeuvre d'une fabrique de saucisses. Et apres avoir enfourne une douzaine de petits pains en quelques bouchees et bu toute une pinte de cafe, il recommencait, la tete penchee, a surveiller Syme.

eng: I have something very particular to say."
fr: J'ai une communication tres speciale a vous faire.

eng: Syme stood up before any of the others.
fr: Syme fut le premier debout.

eng: He found himself filled with a supernatural courage that came from nowhere.
fr: Il sentit affluer en lui, il ne savait d'ou, un courage surnaturel.

eng: Syme stood up taut, as if it had been a bugle before the battle.
fr: Syme se redressa fierement, comme s'il eut entendu le clairon sonner la bataille.

eng: A barrel-organ in the street suddenly sprang with a jerk into a jovial tune.
fr: Soudain, dans la rue voisine, un orgue de Barbarie attaqua une ritournelle.

eng: The instant of choice had come at last, the pistol was at his head.
fr: Le moment de choisir etait venu ; le pistolet etait sur sa tempe.

eng: On the pavement before he could hear the policeman idly stir and stamp, for the morning, though bright, was cold.
fr: En bas, le policeman se promenait paresseusement tout en tapant de la semelle, car la matinee etait belle, mais froide.

eng: That jingling music seemed full of the vivacity, the vulgarity, and the irrational valour of the poor, who in all those unclean streets were all clinging to the decencies and the charities of Christendom.
fr: Il y avait pour lui, dans cette humble melodie, toute la vivacite, toute la vulgarite aussi, et toute l'irrationnelle vertu des pauvres qui, par les rues souillees de Londres, vont au hasard des pas, fermement attaches aux decences et aux charites du Christianisme.

eng: His youthful prank of being a policeman had faded from his mind; he did not think of himself as the representative of the corps of gentlemen turned into fancy constables, or of the old eccentric who lived in the dark room.
fr: Sa juvenile equipee de policier benevole, il n'y songeait plus ; il ne se concevait plus lui-meme comme le representant d'une association de gentlemen jouant en amateurs le role de detectives ; il avait oublie le vieil original qui vivait dans sa chambre pleine de nuit. ~~~ Non !

eng: But he did feel himself as the ambassador of all these common and kindly people in the street, who every day marched into battle to the music of the barrel-organ.
fr: Il etait l'ambassadeur de tous ces pauvres gens, honnetes et vulgaires, qui, par les rues, s'en vont a la bataille de la vie, chaque matin, au son de l'orgue de Barbarie.

eng: He felt towards them all that unconscious and elementary superiority that a brave man feels over powerful beasts or a wise man over powerful errors.
fr: Il avait sur eux tous cette inconsciente et elementaire superiorite d'un brave homme sur des betes puissantes, d'un sage sur des erreurs puissantes.

eng: For an instant, at least, he looked down upon all their sprawling eccentricities from the starry pinnacle of the commonplace.
fr: Un instant, du moins, il jugea leur bizarrerie ignoble, du haut de ce point de vue celeste : le lieu commun.

eng: And this high pride in being human had lifted him unaccountably to an infinite height above the monstrous men around him.
fr: Et cette grande gloire d'etre simplement un homme l'exaltait, sans qu'il put dire pourquoi ni comment, a une hauteur incommensurable au-dessus des monstres qui l'entouraient.

eng: He knew that he had neither the intellectual nor the physical strength of President Sunday; but in that moment he minded it no more than the fact that he had not the muscles of a tiger or a horn on his nose like a rhinoceros.
fr: Il ne possedait, sans doute, et il le savait bien, ni la force intellectuelle ni la force physique du President Dimanche ; mais il n'etait pas plus sensible a cette inferiorite qu'il n'eut regrette de ne pas avoir les muscles du tigre ou l'appendice nasal du rhinoceros.

eng: All was swallowed up in an ultimate certainty that the President was wrong and that the barrel-organ was right.
fr: Il oubliait tout devant cette certitude supreme : que Dimanche avait tort et que l'orgue de Barbarie avait raison.

eng: There clanged in his mind that unanswerable and terrible truism in the song of Roland "Pa ens ont tort et Chr tiens ont droit."
fr: Dans sa memoire chantait le truisme sans replique et terrible de la Chanson de Roland : Paiens ont tort et Chretiens ont droit !

eng: which in the old nasal French has the clang and groan of great iron.
fr: qui etait, en ce vieux francais nasillard, pareil au bruit des grandes armes de fer.

eng: This liberation of his spirit from the load of his weakness went with a quite clear decision to embrace death.
fr: Le fardeau de sa faiblesse se detachait de lui, et, fermement, il prit la resolution d'affronter la mort.

eng: If the people of the barrel-organ could keep their old-world obligations, so could he.
fr: Il songea que les gens de l'orgue de Barbarie tenaient leurs engagements, selon les lois de l'honneur antique ; il ferait comme eux.

eng: This very pride in keeping his word was that he was keeping it to miscreants.
fr: La fidelite a sa parole serait d'autant plus glorieuse qu'il l'avait donnee, cette parole d'honneur, a des mecreants.

eng: It was his last triumph over these lunatics to go down into their dark room and die for something that they could not even understand.
fr: Et son dernier triomphe sur ces fous serait de les suivre dans ce cabinet particulier et de mourir pour une cause qu'ils ne pourraient meme pas comprendre.

eng: The barrel-organ seemed to give the marching tune with the energy and the mingled noises of a whole orchestra; and he could hear deep and rolling, under all the trumpets of the pride of life, the drums of the pride of death.
fr: L'orgue de Barbarie jouait une marche avec toute l'energie et toute la parfaite harmonie d'un savant orchestre ; et Syme distinguait, sous les eclats des cuivres qui celebraient la gloire de vivre, le profond roulement de tambour qui affirmait la gloire de mourir.

eng: The conspirators were already filing through the open window and into the rooms behind.
fr: Deja, les conspirateurs s'eloignaient par la porte-fenetre et par les pieces.

eng: Syme went last, outwardly calm, but with all his brain and body throbbing with romantic rhythm.
fr: Syme franchit le dernier le seuil du balcon. ~~~ Exterieurement calme, il fremissait dans son cerveau et dans tous ses membres d'un rythme romantique.

eng: When they were all in, he closed and locked the door.
fr: Quand tous furent entres, Dimanche ferma la porte et tourna la clef dans la serrure.

eng: The first to speak was Gogol, the irreconcilable, who seemed bursting with inarticulate grievance.
fr: Le premier, Gogol l'irreductible prit la parole. Il paraissait etouffer de fureur.

eng: No one except Syme seemed to have any notion of the blow that was about to fall.
fr: Nul, excepte Syme, n'avait l'air de se douter du coup qui allait etre frappe.

eng: The President seemed to take the foreigner's incoherent satire with entire good humour.
fr: Le President subit avec toute sa bonne humeur l'incoherente diatribe de l'etranger.

eng: "You can't get hold of it yet, Gogol," he said in a fatherly way. "When once they have heard us talking nonsense on that balcony they will not care where we go afterwards.
fr: -- Vous ne comprenez pas encore, Gogol, dit-il paternellement. Les gens qui nous ont entendus dire des betises sur le balcon ne se soucient plus de savoir ou nous allons ensuite.

eng: If we had come here first, we should have had the whole staff at the keyhole. You don't seem to know anything about mankind."
fr: Si nous avions commence par nous cacher ici, tous les garcons seraient venus ecouter a la porte... Vous ne connaissez pas les hommes.

eng: "I die for zem," cried the Pole in thick excitement, "and I slay zare oppressors. I care not for these games of gonzealment. I would zmite ze tyrant in ze open square."
