fr: -- Je meurs pour eux, s'ecria le Polonais ! Je tue leurs oppresseurs ! Mais je n'aime pas le jeu de cache-cache. Je voudrais frapper les tyrans en plein square.

eng: "I see, I see," said the President, nodding kindly as he seated himself at the top of a long table. "You die for mankind first, and then you get up and smite their oppressors. So that's all right.
fr: -- C'est bien, c'est bien, dit le President en s'asseyant au bout de la table. Vous commencez par mourir pour l'humanite, et puis vous ressuscitez pour frapper les tyrans. C'est a merveille.

eng: And now may I ask you to control your beautiful sentiments, and sit down with the other gentlemen at this table. For the first time this morning something intelligent is going to be said."
fr: Permettez-moi, maintenant, de vous prier de maitriser vos beaux sentiments et de vous asseoir avec ces messieurs. Pour la premiere fois, ce matin, vous allez entendre une parole sensee.

eng: Syme, with the perturbed promptitude he had shown since the original summons, sat down first.
fr: Avec la promptitude empressee qu'il avait montree des le debut, Syme fut le premier a s'asseoir.

eng: The President led them down an irregular side stair, such as might be used by servants, and into a dim, cold, empty room, with a table and benches, like an abandoned boardroom.
fr: Le President les conduisit, par un escalier de service, dans une chambre vide, froide, mal eclairee. Il y avait une table et quelques bancs. On se fut cru dans une chambre de bord abandonnee.

eng: "Zso! ~~~ Zso!" he cried, with an obscure excitement, his heavy Polish accent becoming almost impenetrable. "You zay you nod ide. You zay you show himselves. It is all nuzzinks. Ven you vant talk importance you run yourselves in a dark box!"
fr: -- Voila donc, s'ecria-t-il -- et, inarticule, son anglais-polonais devenait presque incomprehensible -- voila donc comment vous renoncez a vous cacher ! Vous dites que vous vous montrez ! Vous vous moquez de nous ! Quand il s'agit de parler serieusement, vous ne manquez pas de vous enfermer dans une boite obscure !

eng: Gogol sat down last, grumbling in his brown beard about gombromise.
fr: Gogol s'assit le dernier, maugreant toujours dans sa barbe brune, et a plusieurs reprises on put percevoir le mot << gompromis >>.

eng: As for him, he had merely the feeling of a man mounting the scaffold with the intention, at any rate, of making a good speech.
fr: Quant a lui, il eprouvait la sensation de l'homme qui monte a l'echafaud, mais qui se promet de ne pas mourir avant d'avoir fait un beau discours.

eng: "Comrades," said the President, suddenly rising, "we have spun out this farce long enough.
fr: -- Camarades ! ~~~ dit le President en se levant soudain, cette farce a assez dure !

eng: I have called you down here to tell you something so simple and shocking that even the waiters upstairs (long inured to our levities) might hear some new seriousness in my voice.
fr: Je vous ai reunis ici pour vous apprendre quelque chose de si simple et pourtant de si choquant que les garcons de cet etablissement, si habitues qu'ils soient a nos folies, pourraient remarquer dans mes paroles une gravite inaccoutumee. ~~~ Camarades !

eng: I suggest Comrade Saturday, Dr. Bull."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: They all stared at him;
fr: 'Tous les regards etaient fixes sur Dimanche.'

eng: then they all started in their seats, for the next words, though not loud, had a living and sensational emphasis.
fr: 'Brusquement, les membres du Conseil se leverent, car les paroles qui suivirent, sans etre prononcees a haute voix, le furent avec une energie qui fit sensation.'

eng: Sunday struck the table.
fr: 'Dimanche frappa du poing sur la table.'

eng: "Not one word more about the plans and places must be said at this meeting.
fr: '-- Pas un mot de plus, aujourd'hui, sur nos plans !'

eng: Comrades, we were discussing plans and naming places.
fr: 'nous discutions tout a l'heure des plans d'action ; nous proposions des lieux...'

eng: Sunday had spent his life in astonishing his followers;
fr: 'Dimanche avait passe sa vie a etonner ses compagnons.'

eng: but it seemed as if he had never really astonished them until now.
fr: 'On eut pourtant dit, a les voir, qu'ils subissaient pour la premiere fois cette impression d'etonnement.'

eng: They all moved feverishly in their seats, except Syme.
fr: 'Ils s'agitaient sur leurs sieges, febrilement, tous, excepte Syme.'

eng: He sat stiff in his, with his hand in his pocket, and on the handle of his loaded revolver.
fr: 'Immobile, il serrait, dans sa poche, la crosse de son revolver, s'appretant a vendre cherement sa vie :'

eng: When the attack on him came he would sell his life dear.
fr: 'on saurait enfin si le President etait mortel.'

eng: He would find out at least if the President was mortal.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: I propose, before saying anything else, that those plans and places should not be voted by this meeting, but should be left wholly in the control of some one reliable member.
fr: 'Avant d'aller plus loin, je vous demande de confier entierement et sans controle la decision a l'un de nous, a un seul : le camarade Samedi, le docteur Bull.'

eng: Not one tiny detail more about what we mean to do must be mentioned in this company."
fr: 'Pas la plus mince revelation de nos projets dans cette societe !'

eng: Sunday went on smoothly "You will probably understand that there is only one possible motive for forbidding free speech at this festival of freedom.'
fr: 'Dimanche reprit, d'une voix egale : -- Vous le devinez sans doute : pour proscrire, de ce festival de la liberte, la liberte de la parole, je ne puis avoir qu'un seul motif.'

eng: Strangers overhearing us matters nothing.
fr: Peu importe que des etrangers nous entendent.

eng: They assume that we are joking.
fr: Il est entendu pour eux que nous plaisantons.

eng: "Yes," he said slowly, "there is a spy in this room.'
fr: -- Oui, prononca-t-il avec lenteur, il y a dans cette chambre un espion.

eng: But what would matter, even unto death, is this, that there should be one actually among us who is not of us, who knows our grave purpose, but does not share it, who "
fr: Ce qui importe, ce qui a une importance capitale, c'est qu'il y a parmi nous un homme qui n'est pas des notres, un homme qui connait nos graves desseins et qui n'a pour eux aucune sympathie, un homme...

eng: The Secretary screamed out suddenly like a woman.
fr: Le secretaire poussa un cri percant, un cri de femme, et se leva d'un bond :

eng: "It can't be!" he cried, leaping.
fr: -- C'est impossible !...

eng: The President flapped his large flat hand on the table like the fin of some huge fish.
fr: Le President abattit sur la table sa main, large comme la nageoire d'un poisson enorme.

eng: "There can't "
fr: Il est impossible que...

eng: There is a traitor at this table.
fr: Il y a un traitre a cette table.

eng: "Well, my man," said the President briskly, addressing him as one addresses a total stranger, "will you oblige me by putting your hand in your upper waistcoat pocket and showing me what you have there?"
fr: -- Eh bien ! ~~~ mon garcon, reprit le President, comme s'il se fut adresse a un inconnu, voulez-vous me faire le plaisir de fouiller la poche superieure de votre gilet et de me montrer ce que vous y trouverez ?

eng: The three who had risen fell away from Gogol, and that equivocal person himself resumed his seat.
fr: Les trois hommes qui avaient apprehende Gogol le lacherent, et ce personnage equivoque reprit sa place.

eng: His name "
fr: Il se nomme...

eng: THE UNACCOUNTABLE CONDUCT OF PROFESSOR DE WORMS
fr: CONDUITE INEXPLICABLE DU PROFESSEUR DE WORMS

eng: CHAPTER VII.
fr: * * * CHAPITRE VII

eng: "Sit down!" said Sunday in a voice that he used once or twice in his life, a voice that made men drop drawn swords.
fr: -- Assis ! cria Dimanche d'une voix dont il se servait rarement, une voix qui faisait tomber des mains les epees menacantes.

eng: But Syme saw little of the scene, for he was blinded with a beneficent darkness;
fr: Mais Syme ne vit pas grand'chose de ce qui se passa ensuite. Il etait comme aveugle par une obscurite bienfaisante.

eng: Even the Professor made an effort to rise.
fr: Le professeur lui-meme fit un effort pour se lever.

eng: With the same flash three men sprang at his throat.
fr: Au meme instant, trois hommes lui sautaient a la gorge.

eng: Gogol sprang to his feet, a pistol in each hand.
fr: Gogol se dressa sur ses pieds, un revolver dans chaque main.

eng: "He is that hairy humbug over there who pretends to be a Pole."
fr: c'est ce charlatan chevelu qui se pretend Polonais.

eng: "His name is Gogol," said the President.
fr: -- Il se nomme Gogol, continua le President :

eng: Syme half rose from his seat, his finger firm on the trigger.
fr: Syme se leva a demi, le doigt sur la detente de son revolver.

eng: I will waste no more words.
fr: Je ne perdrai pas un mot de plus.

eng: he had sunk down into his seat shuddering, in a palsy of passionate relief.
fr: Effondre sur son banc, il tremblait, comme epouvante de se sentir sauve.

eng: The alleged Pole was a little pale under his tangle of dark hair, but he put two fingers into the pocket with apparent coolness and pulled out a blue strip of card.
fr: Le pretendu Polonais avait pali sous sa broussaille de poils sombres. ~~~ Il glissa pourtant avec calme apparent deux doigts dans la poche indiquee et en tira un bout de carte bleue.

eng: When Syme saw it lying on the table, he woke up again to the world outside him.
fr: En voyant cette carte sur la table, Syme reprit conscience du monde exterieur.

eng: For although the card lay at the other extreme of the table, and he could read nothing of the inscription on it, it bore a startling resemblance to the blue card in his own pocket, the card which had been given to him when he joined the anti-anarchist constabulary.
fr: Bien qu'elle fut posee a l'autre bout de la table, et qu'il n'en put pas lire l'inscription, cette carte ressemblait etonnamment a celle qu'il avait lui-meme en poche et qui lui avait ete remise a son entree dans la police antianarchiste.

eng: "Pathetic Slav," said the President, "tragic child of Poland, are you prepared in the presence of that card to deny that you are in this company shall we say _de trop?_" "Right oh!"
fr: -- Slave pathetique, dit le President, fils tragique de la Pologne, etes-vous dispose a pretendre, maintenant et devant cette carte, qu'en notre societe vous n'etes pas... comment dirai-je... de trop ?

eng: "I gather that you fully understand your position," said Sunday.
fr: -- Je pense que vous vous rendez compte de votre position, continua Dimanche.

eng: "You bet," answered the Pole.
fr: -- Tu parles ! repliqua le Polonais.

eng: "I see it's a fair cop. All I say is, I don't believe any Pole could have imitated my accent like I did his."
fr: Mais croyez-vous qu'un vrai Polonais aurait su etre aussi Polonais que moi ?

eng: "Not a bit," answered Gogol;
fr: -- Pas le moins du monde !

eng: Now listen to me.
fr: Ecoutez-moi ;

eng: "I will do you the justice to say," said Sunday, not without a sort of brutal admiration, "that you seem to have kept pretty cool under it.
fr: -- Je vous rendrai justice en disant que vous avez su, sous ce masque si chaud, garder votre sang-froid, fit Dimanche, avec une sorte d'admiration brutale.

eng: "It was hot," he added.
fr: -- C'etait bien chaud, ajouta-t-il.

eng: and with one finger he ripped off the whole of his shaggy head-covering, emerging with thin red hair and a pale, pert face.
fr: Et, d'un coup, Gogol arracha tout son masque barbu et chevelu, d'ou emergea une figure pale et effrontee, au poil blond.

eng: Do you mind leaving your beard with your card?"
fr: Voyez-vous quelque inconvenient a laisser ici votre barbe avec votre carte ?

eng: said the late Gogol.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "I believe your own accent to be inimitable, though I shall practise it in my bath.
fr: Votre accent d'ailleurs est inimitable ; pourtant, je m'y essaierai en prenant mon bain.

eng: It made everyone jump to hear a clear, commercial and somewhat cockney voice coming out of that forest of foreign hair.
fr: Chacun fut surpris d'entendre une voix claire, commerciale pour ainsi dire et presque faubourienne, sortir de cette foret de cheveux exotiques.

eng: It was irrational, as if a Chinaman had suddenly spoken with a Scotch accent.
fr: C'etait tout aussi paradoxal que si, tout a coup, un Chinois eut parle anglais avec l'accent ecossais.

eng: "I concede the point," said Sunday.
fr: -- Je vous accorde ce point.

eng: I like you.
fr: vous me plaisez.

eng: The consequence is that it would annoy me for just about two and a half minutes if I heard that you had died in torments.
fr: Il me serait donc desagreable, pendant au moins deux minutes et demie, d'apprendre que vous avez succombe aux tourments.

eng: Well, if you ever tell the police or any human soul about us, I shall have that two and a half minutes of discomfort.
fr: Eh bien ! ~~~ si vous parlez de nous a la police ou a ame qui vive, il me faudra subir ces deux minutes et demie de desagrement.

eng: On your discomfort I will not dwell.
fr: Quant a l'ennui qui en resulterait pour vous, je n'y insiste pas.

eng: Good day. ~~~ Mind the step."
fr: Adieu, donc, et prenez garde a l'escalier.

eng: The other four got to their feet grumbling more or less, and betook themselves elsewhere to find lunch, for it was already well past midday.
fr: Les quatre autres finirent par s'en aller, a la recherche de leur lunch, car il etait plus de midi.

eng: The red-haired detective who had masqueraded as Gogol rose to his feet without a word, and walked out of the room with an air of perfect nonchalance.
fr: Le ci-devant Gogol, le detective aux cheveux roux se leva sans mot dire et quitta la chambre, lentement, avec un air de parfaite nonchalance.

eng: They meant that while Sunday could not denounce him like Gogol, he still could not trust him like the others.
fr: Peut-etre Dimanche n'avait-il pas la certitude de pouvoir le demasquer, comme il avait fait de Gogol, mais il se mefiait !

eng: Syme sat long after the rest had gone, revolving his strange position.
fr: Syme resta longtemps seul, a mediter sur son etrange situation.

eng: If the last words of the President meant anything, they meant that he had not after all passed unsuspected.
fr: Si les paroles du President n'etaient pas denuees de sens, elles signifiaient que Syme etait, tout au moins, soupconne.

eng: The Professor went last, very slowly and painfully.
fr: Le professeur gagna la porte tres lentement, tres peniblement.

eng: Four of the men left behind gaped after him without any apparent glimmering of his meaning.
fr: Des cinq hommes qui restaient dans le cabinet, quatre ouvraient la bouche, ecarquillaient les yeux ; ils paraissaient au comble de l'etonnement.

eng: "Secretary," said the President seriously, "if you'd take your head home and boil it for a turnip it might be useful. I can't say. ~~~ But it might."
fr: -- Secretaire, interrompit le President, tres serieusement, si vous rapportez votre tete chez vous, essayez donc de la faire cuire, comme un navet ; peut-etre alors sera-t-elle bonne a quelque chose. Toutefois, je n'affirme rien.

eng: Of course, I fully appreciate your forethought when in the actual presence of a traitor "
fr: Sans doute, et je rends pleinement hommage a votre prudence, en presence d'un traitre...

eng: "It is a fundamental rule of our society that all plans shall be debated in full council.
fr: C'est une des regles fondamentales de notre societe, que tous les plans doivent etre discutes en plein conseil.

eng: "I must protest, President, that the thing is irregular," he said.
fr: -- J'ai le devoir de protester, President, contre cette irregularite ! dit-il.

eng: He was one of those men who are conscientious even in crime.
fr: C'etait un de ces hommes qui sont consciencieux jusque dans le crime.

eng: But the late loud scenes had whipped up the almost naked nerves of the Secretary.
fr: Mais la scene dramatique a laquelle il venait d'assister avait singulierement surexcite le systeme nerveux du secretaire.

eng: "Leave it as it is. Let Saturday settle it. I must be off. Breakfast here next Sunday."
fr: Laissons tout en plan. Samedi arrangera tout. Je m'en vais. Je suis presse. Nous dejeunerons ici dimanche prochain.

eng: "No, I think not," said the President with a yawn like an unobtrusive earthquake.
fr: -- Je ne suis pas de votre avis, repondit le President, avec un baillement comparable a un discret tremblement de terre.

eng: "Would it not be better," he said a little sharply, "to discuss further the details of our project, now that the spy has left us?"
fr: -- Ne vaudrait-il pas mieux, dit-il sechement, reprendre la discussion de notre projet, maintenant que nous sommes entre nous ?

eng: The Secretary turned to him with working eyebrows.
fr: Le secretaire se tourna vers lui, les sourcils fronces.

eng: "I really fail to understand " he began in high offense.
fr: -- En verite, murmura-t-il, je ne puis comprendre...

eng: "I must go off at once; I have to take the chair at a Humanitarian meeting."
fr: Il faut que je vous quitte sur-le-champ : j'ai l'obligation de presider une reunion humanitaire.

eng: "Time is flying," said the President in his gayest manner, after glancing at his watch, which like everything about him seemed bigger than it ought to be.
fr: -- Le temps passe, dit le President de sa facon la plus enjouee en consultant une montre qui, comme lui-meme et comme tout ce qu'il portait sur lui, etait de dimensions anormales.

eng: Yet the astonished Syme was able to realise that this ease was suddenly assumed; for there was a slight stumble outside the door, which showed that the departing detective had not minded the step.
fr: Mais Syme, stupefait, put se convaincre que cette aisance etait jouee, car un leger trebuchement l'avertit bientot que le detective n'avait pas pris garde a l'escalier.

eng: Syme alone had even a glimmering, and such as it was it froze him to the bone.
fr: Syme seul se doutait de la verite, et ce doute le faisait frissonner jusque dans la moelle de ses os.

eng: The Secretary reared back in a kind of equine anger.
fr: Le secretaire etouffa un rugissement de fureur.

eng: And with these words he shouldered his way out of the room, shaking with incomprehensible scorn.
fr: Sur ces mots, il quitta la piece en haussant les epaules.

eng: Why, you dancing donkey," he roared, rising, "you didn't want to be overheard by a spy, didn't you? How do you know you aren't overheard now?"
fr: ane bate que vous etes ! rugit-il en se levant. Vous ne vouliez pas qu'un espion nous entendit, hein ? Or, que savez-vous si, en ce moment meme, un espion ne nous entend pas ?

eng: "That's it, that's it," said the President, nodding a great many times. "That's where you fail right enough. You fail to understand.
fr: -- Parfaitement, dit le President en inclinant la tete a plusieurs reprises, c'est bien cela ! vous ne pouvez comprendre, et cela vous arrive assez souvent. Voyons !

eng: He had escaped a thunderbolt, but he was still under a cloud.
fr: Il avait echappe au premier coup de tonnerre, mais le nuage pesait encore sur lui.

eng: His top hat was loaded with snow like the hat of Father Christmas, the white drift was rising round his boots and ankles; but it seemed as if nothing could tear him away from the contemplation of the colourless wax doll in dirty evening dress.
fr: Son chapeau etait blanc comme celui du pere Noel, et la neige s'epaississait autour de ses souliers. Mais il semblait que rien ne put l'arracher a la contemplation de cette poupee fanee.

eng: At last he rose and made his way out of the hotel into Leicester Square.
fr: Enfin, il sortit et gagna Leicester Square.

eng: The bright, cold day had grown increasingly colder, and when he came out into the street he was surprised by a few flakes of snow.
fr: La temperature s'etait refroidie. Syme eprouva quelque ennui a voir tomber des flocons de neige.

eng: While he still carried the sword-stick and the rest of Gregory's portable luggage, he had thrown the cloak down and left it somewhere, perhaps on the steam-tug, perhaps on the balcony.
fr: Il avait toujours la canne a epee et le reste des bagages de Gregory, mais sa pelerine etait restee il ne savait ou, dans le bateau peut-etre, ou sur le balcon.

eng: It was quite strange that any human being should stand in such weather observing such a shop.
fr: Il etait assez etrange qu'un etre humain quelconque se tint par un pareil temps en observation devant une telle boutique.

eng: Hoping, therefore, that the snow-shower might be slight, he stepped back out of the street for a moment and stood up under the doorway of a small and greasy hair-dresser's shop, the front window of which was empty, except for a sickly wax lady in evening dress.
fr: Esperant que la rafale ne durerait pas, il se refugia sous l'auvent d'une petite boutique de coiffeur, dont la vitrine ne contenait qu'une maladive figure de femme en cire, decolletee.

eng: He was considerably astonished to see, standing quite still outside the shop and staring into the window, a man.
fr: Il ne fut pas peu surpris de voir un homme arrete devant la vitrine et qui se tenait la, immobile, comme hypnotise par l'insupportable statuette.

eng: Snow, however, began to thicken and fall fast; and Syme, having found one glance at the wax lady quite sufficient to depress his spirits, stared out instead into the white and empty street.
fr: Pourtant, la neige tombait de plus en plus dense. Syme, agace par le sourire fade de la figurine, se retourna vers la rue et regarda les paves blanchir.

eng: That any human being should stand in such weather looking into such a shop was a matter of sufficient wonder to Syme; but his idle wonder turned suddenly into a personal shock; for he realised that the man standing there was the paralytic old Professor de Worms.
fr: L'etonnement de Syme ne tarda pas a changer en un malaise tres personnel, car il reconnut tout a coup le vieux professeur paralytique de Worms.

eng: It scarcely seemed the place for a person of his years and infirmities.
fr: Ce n'etait guere l'endroit qui convenait a un homme de son age, accable des infirmites qu'il avait.

eng: For Syme thirsted first and last to get clear of the whole poisonous atmosphere, if only for an hour.
fr: Car Syme avait besoin d'echapper, ne fut-ce que pour une heure, a l'atmosphere empoisonnee qu'il respirait depuis la veille.

eng: Syme was ready to believe anything about the perversions of this dehumanized brotherhood;
fr: Syme etait pret a admettre n'importe quoi d'invraisemblable sur le compte de n'importe lequel des << deshumanises >> qui composaient le Conseil.

eng: but even he could not believe that the Professor had fallen in love with that particular wax lady.
fr: Mais il ne pouvait croire que le vieux professeur fut amoureux de cette poupee de cire.

eng: He could only suppose that the man's malady (whatever it was) involved some momentary fits of rigidity or trance.
fr: Il prefera s'expliquer le cas en supposant que le malade etait sujet a des acces de catalepsie, de rigidite subite,

eng: He was not inclined, however, to feel in this case any very compassionate concern.
fr: et meme il se felicita, n'etant nullement enclin a la pitie envers un tel individu,

eng: On the contrary, he rather congratulated himself that the Professor's stroke and his elaborate and limping walk would make it easy to escape from him and leave him miles behind.
fr: de pouvoir, par une fuite rapide, le distancer tout de suite.

eng: Then he could collect his thoughts, formulate his policy, and decide finally whether he should or should not keep faith with Gregory.
fr: Alors, il pourrait, du moins, mettre de l'ordre dans ses pensees, deliberer sur la conduite a tenir, et d'abord resoudre ce probleme : etait-il, ou non, enchaine par la parole donnee a Gregory ?

eng: He strolled away through the dancing snow, turned up two or three streets, down through two or three others, and entered a small Soho restaurant for lunch.
fr: Sous les flocons de neige qui dansaient dans l'air, il s'eloigna, traversa quelques rues et entra dans un petit restaurant de Soho pour y prendre son lunch.

eng: He partook reflectively of four small and quaint courses, drank half a bottle of red wine, and ended up over black coffee and a black cigar, still thinking.
fr: Il mangea de trois ou quatre plats, tout en reflechissant, but une demi-bouteille de vin rouge et termina par une tasse de cafe accompagnee d'un cigare.

eng: When he entered that lower room he stood stricken and rooted to the spot.
fr: En penetrant dans cette piece, il crut sentir que ses pieds prenaient racine dans le plancher.

eng: But even the shudder had the delightful shame of escape.
fr: Mais, tout en frissonnant, il songea aussi qu'il avait fui, et il en eut une impression melee de quelque honte et de beaucoup de plaisir.

eng: He had taken his seat in the upper room of the restaurant, which was full of the chink of knives and the chatter of foreigners.
fr: Il avait choisi sa place dans la salle du premier etage, ou retentissaient indiscontinument le cliquetis des couteaux et des fourchettes et le bruit des conversations, en langues etrangeres.

eng: He remembered that in old days he had imagined that all these harmless and kindly aliens were anarchists.
fr: Il se rappela que, jadis, il avait soupconne d'anarchisme ces braves et inoffensifs etrangers,

eng: He shuddered, remembering the real thing.
fr: et il frissonna en songeant a ce que c'etait qu'un veritable anarchiste.

eng: For an instant Syme stood as rigid as the stick he leant upon.
fr: Un instant, Syme resta droit, rigide comme la canne sur laquelle il s'appuyait.

eng: The wine, the common food, the familiar place, the faces of natural and talkative men, made him almost feel as if the Council of the Seven Days had been a bad dream;
fr: Le vin, la nourriture, qui n'avait rien d'extraordinaire, le caractere familier de l'endroit, les visages de ces hommes bavards et simples, tout le rassurait, et il etait tente de croire que le Conseil des Sept n'etait qu'un mauvais reve !

eng: and although he knew it was nevertheless an objective reality, it was at least a distant one.
fr: Bien qu'il fut oblige de convenir en lui-meme que le terrible Conseil n'avait rien de chimerique, ce n'etait, du moins, pour l'instant, qu'une realite lointaine.

eng: Tall houses and populous streets lay between him and his last sight of the shameful seven;
fr: De grandes maisons, des rues populeuses, le separaient des maudits Sept.

eng: he was free in free London, and drinking wine among the free.
fr: Il etait libre, dans une ville libre, et il buvait son vin parmi des hommes libres.

eng: With a somewhat easier action, he took his hat and stick and strolled down the stair into the shop below.
fr: Avec un soupir de soulagement, il prit son chapeau et sa canne, et descendit dans la salle du rez-de-chaussee, qu'il devait traverser pour sortir.

eng: At a small table, close up to the blank window and the white street of snow, sat the old anarchist Professor over a glass of milk, with his lifted livid face and pendent eyelids.
fr: A une petite table, tout pres de la fenetre et de la rue blanche de neige, le vieux professeur anarchiste etait assis devant un verre de lait, avec ses paupieres mi-closes, et son visage livide.

eng: Then with a gesture as of blind hurry, he brushed past the Professor, dashing open the door and slamming it behind him, and stood outside in the snow.
fr: Puis, avec une precipitation folle, il passa tout pres du professeur, ouvrit la porte et, la faisant claquer derriere lui, bondit dans la rue, dans la neige.

eng: "Can that old corpse be following me?"
fr: -- Ce cadavre me suivrait-il ?

eng: he asked himself, biting his yellow moustache.
fr: se demandait Syme en mordillant sa moustache blonde.

eng: "I stopped too long up in that room, so that even such leaden feet could catch me up.
fr: Je me suis trop attarde, je lui ai donne le temps de me rejoindre malgre ses pieds de plomb.

eng: But the Professor did not look round.
fr: Le professeur ne parut pas avoir entendu.

eng: Syme's walking-stick had fallen from his hand with a great clang, which confessed the concealed steel.
fr: La canne de Syme lui echappa des mains et fit en tombant un bruit metallique qui revela la presence de l'epee.

eng: One comfort is, with a little brisk walking I can put a man like that as far away as Timbuctoo.
fr: Heureusement qu'en hatant un peu le pas, je puis sans peine mettre entre lui et moi la distance d'ici a Tombouctou...

eng: Was he really following me?
fr: Pourquoi me suivrait-il ?

eng: Syme, who was commonly a cool character, was literally gaping as a rustic gapes at a conjuring trick.
fr: Syme qui etait un homme plutot calme le regardait, bouche bee, comme un paysan qui assiste a un tour de passe-passe.

eng: He had seen no cab following; he had heard no wheels outside the shop; to all mortal appearances the man had come on foot.
fr: Il n'avait remarque aucun cab derriere lui ; il n'en avait pas entendu s'arreter devant la boutique. Selon toute apparence, le professeur etait venu a pied.

eng: But the old man could only walk like a snail, and Syme had walked like the wind!
fr: ~~~ Mais quoi ? Le vieillard n'allait guere plus vite qu'un escargot, et Syme avait file comme le vent ! ~~~

eng: He started up and snatched his stick, half crazy with the contradiction in mere arithmetic, and swung out of the swinging doors, leaving his coffee untasted.
fr: Affole par l'invraisemblance materielle du fait, il se leva, ramassa sa canne et s'esquiva, sans avoir touche a son cafe.

eng: An omnibus going to the Bank went rattling by with an unusual rapidity.
fr: Un omnibus se dirigeant vers la Banque passait a grande allure.

eng: He had a violent run of a hundred yards to reach it; but he managed to spring, swaying upon the splash-board and, pausing for an instant to pant, he climbed on to the top.
fr: Syme dut faire une centaine de pas en courant pour l'atteindre. ~~~ Il sauta sur le marchepied, respira un instant, puis monta a l'imperiale.

eng: Or am I too fanciful?
fr: Du reste, ma supposition n'est pas raisonnable.

eng: When he had been seated for about half a minute, he heard behind him a sort of heavy and asthmatic breathing.
fr: Il y etait installe depuis une demi-minute, a peu pres, quand il entendit venir d'en bas un souffle d'asthmatique.

eng: He let himself into a seat with characteristic care, and wrapped himself up to the chin in the mackintosh rug.
fr: Il s'avanca a tout petits pas, se laissa tomber sur la banquette en poussant de legers soupirs et s'enveloppa lentement dans les plis de la bache de laine.

eng: Scarcely had he done so, when Professor de Worms hobbled heavily into the shop, sat down with difficulty and ordered a glass of milk.
fr: A peine l'avait-il commandee que le professeur de Worms, peniblement et en trebuchant, ouvrait la porte de la boutique et, s'asseyant avec difficulte, demandait une tasse de lait.

eng: Getting into his eyes and beard, they added their unremitting futility to his already irritated nerves; and by the time that he had come at a swinging pace to the beginning of Fleet Street, he lost patience, and finding a Sunday teashop, turned into it to take shelter.
fr: ~~~ A l'entree de Fleet Street, il perdit patience, et, se trouvant devant une maison de the ouverte le dimanche, il s'y refugia.

eng: The snow-flakes tormented him like a swarm of silver bees.
fr: Les flocons le piquaient comme d'innombrables essaims d'abeilles argentees, penetrant dans ses yeux, dans sa barbe, surexcitant ses nerfs deja fort tendus.

eng: As he crossed the great market the snow increased, growing blinding and bewildering as the afternoon began to darken.
fr: Comme il traversait le Grand Marche, la rafale de neige se fit plus abondante. Elle devenait aveuglante a mesure que le jour baissait.

eng: He set off at a smart pace, twisting and whirling his stick, in the direction of Covent Garden.
fr: D'un bon pas, tout en faisant tournoyer sa canne entre ses doigts, il prit la direction de Covent Garden.

eng: Surely Sunday would not be such a fool as to send a lame man?"
fr: Si Dimanche me faisait surveiller, il n'aurait pas charge de cette mission un paralytique.

eng: Turning sharply, he saw rising gradually higher and higher up the omnibus steps a top hat soiled and dripping with snow, and under the shadow of its brim the short-sighted face and shaky shoulders of Professor de Worms.
fr: Se retournant aussitot, il vit s'elever graduellement sur les marches de l'omnibus un chapeau haut de forme, blanc de neige, puis le visage de myope, puis les epaules tremblantes du vieux professeur de Worms.

eng: He ordered another cup of black coffee as an excuse.
fr: Par contenance, il commanda une seconde tasse de cafe noir.

eng: Every movement of the old man's tottering figure and vague hands, every uncertain gesture and panic-stricken pause, seemed to put it beyond question that he was helpless, that he was in the last imbecility of the body.
fr: Chaque mouvement de ce corps branlant, le moindre de ses gestes demontrait jusqu'a la parfaite evidence la debilite sans remede, la totale impuissance de cet organisme use.

eng: He had repressed an elemental impulse to leap over the side.
fr: Il avait du reprimer un mouvement impulsif qu'il avait eu de se jeter en bas, du haut de l'imperiale.

eng: Syme sprang erect upon the rocking car, and after staring wildly at the wintry sky, that grew gloomier every moment, he ran down the steps.
fr: Syme se dressa de toute sa hauteur et, jetant un regard affole sur ce ciel d'hiver, qui d'instant en instant devenait plus sombre, se laissa glisser, plutot qu'il ne descendit, le long de l'escalier.

eng: And yet, unless the philosophical entities called time and space have no vestige even of a practical existence, it appeared quite unquestionable that he had run after the omnibus.
fr: Et pourtant, a moins d'admettre que les entites philosophiques appelees espace et temps fussent depourvues de toute realite, il etait infiniment probable que ce vieillard avait du courir apres l'omnibus.

eng: Too bewildered to look back or to reason, he rushed into one of the little courts at the side of Fleet Street as a rabbit rushes into a hole.
fr: Sans regarder en arriere, sans reflechir, il s'engagea a l'aveuglette, comme un lievre dans un trou, dans l'une des petites cours qui avoisinent Fleet Street.

eng: He moved by inches, he let himself down with little gasps of caution.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He had a vague idea, if this incomprehensible old Jack-in-the-box was really pursuing him, that in that labyrinth of little streets he could soon throw him off the scent.
fr: Il avait vaguement l'idee de depister le vieux diable en se perdant lui-meme dans ce labyrinthe de ruelles etroites.

eng: He dived in and out of those crooked lanes, which were more like cracks than thoroughfares; and by the time that he had completed about twenty alternate angles and described an unthinkable polygon, he paused to listen for any sound of pursuit.
fr: Il se plongea donc dans ces ruelles qui semblaient des culs-de-sac plutot que des passages, et apres avoir tourne une vingtaine de coins et decrit quelque inimaginable polygone, au bout de quelques minutes, il s'arreta, pretant l'oreille.

eng: There was none; there could not in any case have been much, for the little streets were thick with the soundless snow.
fr: Aucun bruit de pas. ~~~ Du reste, la couche epaisse de neige dont ces ruelles etaient tapissees etouffait tous les bruits.

eng: But right up against these dreary colours rose the black bulk of the cathedral; and upon the top of the cathedral was a random splash and great stain of snow, still clinging as to an Alpine peak.
fr: Sur ce fond morne, la masse noire de la cathedrale s'elevait, et a son sommet, on distinguait une grande tache de neige, comme sur un pic alpestre.

eng: The sealed and sullen sunset behind the dark dome of St. Paul's had in it smoky and sinister colours colours of sickly green, dead red or decaying bronze, that were just bright enough to emphasise the solid whiteness of the snow.
fr: Derriere Saint-Paul, le soleil, comme un disque de metal, avait des teintes fumeuses et sinistres, morbides, des teintes d'un rouge fletri, d'un bronze terni, qui faisaient ressortir la blancheur opaque de la neige.

eng: Under the white fog of snow high up in the heaven the whole atmosphere of the city was turned to a very queer kind of green twilight, as of men under the sea.
fr: Sous l'epais brouillard qui planait, la ville prenait une etrange couleur verdatre et comme sous-marine.

eng: And at the very word Sunday he bit his lip; the word was henceforth for hire like some indecent pun.
fr: En prononcant tout bas ce mot, il se mordit la levre. Dimanche ! Ces syllabes comportaient desormais pour lui un jeu de mots sacrilege.

eng: Then he told himself that some degree of emptiness was natural; first because the snow-storm was even dangerously deep, and secondly because it was Sunday.
fr: Puis, il reflechit que la tempete de neige etait un danger. Enfin il se rappela que c'etait dimanche.

eng: At first he was startled to find these great roads so empty, as if a pestilence had swept through the city.
fr: Il fut d'abord etonne de la solitude de ces grandes voies. C'etait comme si la peste eut decime la population.

eng: When he did so, he struck it much farther up than he had fancied. He came out into what seemed the vast and void of Ludgate Circus, and saw St. Paul's Cathedral sitting in the sky.
fr: Mais il erra longtemps encore en tous sens avant de gagner la grande artere, et, quand il y parvint, il se trouva beaucoup plus loin qu'il n'aurait pense, dans la vaste solitude de Ludgate-Circus. Il apercut la cathedrale de Saint-Paul assise en plein ciel.

eng: Yet he rambled and dodged for a long time before he struck the main thoroughfare.
fr: Mais il erra longtemps encore en tous sens avant de gagner la grande artere, et, quand il y parvint, il se trouva beaucoup plus loin qu'il n'aurait pense, dans la vaste solitude de Ludgate-Circus.

eng: He felt a new impulse to break out of this hive of houses, and to get once more into the open and lamp-lit street.
fr: Il eprouva de nouveau le besoin de gagner les rues larges et eclairees, de sortir de ce dedale de maisons tristes.

eng: On each side of Syme the walls of the alley were blind and featureless; there was no little window or any kind of eve.
fr: A la droite et a la gauche de Syme, les murs de l'allee etaient unis et sans caractere ; pas une fenetre, rien qui fit penser a un oeil.

eng: But when a few hundred yards farther on he stood still again to listen, his heart stood still also, for he heard from that space of rugged stones the clinking crutch and labouring feet of the infernal cripple.
fr: Il n'en avait pas tenu grand compte d'abord. Et il allait reprendre sa course, quand son coeur cessa de battre : il entendait resonner, dans cet endroit deblaye, la bequille de l'infernal perclus.

eng: He thought little of this as he passed it, only plunging into yet another arm of the maze.
fr: Il n'en avait pas tenu grand compte d'abord. Et il allait reprendre sa course, quand son coeur cessa de battre : il entendait resonner, dans cet endroit deblaye, la bequille de l'infernal perclus.

eng: Somewhere behind Red Lion Court, however, he noticed a place where some energetic citizen had cleared away the snow for a space of about twenty yards, leaving the wet, glistening cobble-stones.
fr: Quelque part, toutefois, derriere Red Lion Court il avait remarque en passant qu'un citoyen energique avait balaye la neige sur l'espace d'une vingtaine de metres ; la le gravier apparaissait, humide et luisant.

eng: The sky above was loaded with the clouds of snow, leaving London in a darkness and oppression premature for that hour of the evening.
fr: Le ciel, couvert de nuages, versait sur Londres un crepuscule dense, insolite a cette heure peu avancee de l'apres-midi.

eng: It had fallen accidentally, but just so fallen as to half drape the dome from its very topmost point, and to pick out in perfect silver the great orb and the cross.
fr: La masse neigeuse, apres s'etre lentement amoncelee, s'etait ecroulee, mais en s'ecroulant, elle avait drape le dome, du haut en bas, d'une echarpe blanche, de facon a faire saillir en argent pur le globe et la croix.

eng: When Syme saw it he suddenly straightened himself, and made with his sword-stick an involuntary salute.
fr: A cette vue, Syme se raidit involontairement, il fit de la canne-epee le salut militaire.

eng: He knew that that evil figure, his shadow, was creeping quickly or slowly behind him, and he did not care.
fr: Il savait que le hideux compere le suivait toujours comme son ombre ; mais il ne s'en souciait plus.

eng: It seemed a symbol of human faith and valour that while the skies were darkening that high place of the earth was bright.
fr: C'etait comme un symbole de la foi et de la vertu, ce haut lieu de la terre qui restait resplendissant dans les cieux assombris.

eng: The devils might have captured heaven, but they had not yet captured the cross.
fr: Les demons pouvaient s'etre empares des cieux ; ils ne pouvaient toucher a la croix.

eng: He had a new impulse to tear out the secret of this dancing, jumping and pursuing paralytic; and at the entrance of the court as it opened upon the Circus he turned, stick in hand, to face his pursuer.
fr: Syme eut brusquement l'envie d'arracher, a ce paralytique dansant et sautillant qui le poursuivait, son secret. ~~~ A l'angle du Circus, il se retourna, etreignant sa canne, pour faire face a son persecuteur.

eng: Professor de Worms came slowly round the corner of the irregular alley behind him, his unnatural form outlined against a lonely gas-lamp, irresistibly recalling that very imaginative figure in the nursery rhymes, "the crooked man who went a crooked mile."
fr: Le professeur de Worms tourna lentement le coin de l'allee irreguliere d'ou il venait. ~~~ Sa forme outrageante, estompee contre un reverbere solitaire, rappela irresistiblement a Syme << le bonhomme tortu qui fit un mille tordu >>, dont il est question dans les chansons de nourrice.

eng: He really looked as if he had been twisted out of shape by the tortuous streets he had been threading.
fr: On etait vraiment tente de croire que sa forme tordue lui avait ete donnee, imposee, par ces rues tortueuses.

eng: He came nearer and nearer, the lamplight shining on his lifted spectacles, his lifted, patient face.
fr: Il se rapprochait, et la lumiere du reverbere se refletait sur son binocle releve, sur sa figure patiente, qu'il tenait droite, immobile.

eng: The man's colourless face and manner seemed to assert that the whole following had been an accident.
fr: Le vieillard semblait protester, tacitement, par son visage ferme, par ses manieres, en quelque sorte incolores, qu'il ne poursuivait personne et que toutes ces rencontres avaient ete de simples et insignifiantes coincidences.

eng: There was something in this silent and unexpected innocence that left Syme in a final fury.
fr: Ce silence, cette sorte d'innocence jouee, exaspererent Syme.

eng: Syme was galvanised with an energy that was something between bitterness and a burst of boyish derision.
fr: Syme se sentit galvanise par une soudaine energie, nuancee de fureur et d'ironie.

eng: Syme waited for him as St. George waited for the dragon, as a man waits for a final explanation or for death.
fr: Syme l'attendait comme saint Georges attendit le dragon, comme un homme qui va provoquer une explication finale, ou la mort.

eng: And the old Professor came right up to him and passed him like a total stranger, without even a blink of his mournful eyelids.
fr: Et le vieux professeur alla droit a Syme, et passa devant lui comme devant un inconnu, sans un regard de ses yeux eplores.

eng: Concealment was impossible now; and looking back over his shoulder, he could see the black figure of the old gentleman coming after him with long, swinging strides like a man winning a mile race.
fr: Impossible maintenant de se cacher. En se retournant, il put voir le vieillard qui le poursuivait a grandes enjambees. ~~~ On eut dit deux hommes se defiant a la course. (The last part is a partial match, describing the chase)

eng: He made a wild gesture as if to knock the old man's hat off, called out something like "Catch me if you can," and went racing away across the white, open Circus.
fr: Il fit un geste violent, qui faillit faire tomber le chapeau du professeur, cria quelque chose comme : << Attrape-moi si tu peux ! >> et se mit a courir a travers le large et blanc Circus.

eng: But the head upon that bounding body was still pale, grave and professional, like the head of a lecturer upon the body of a harlequin.
fr: Mais la tete du professeur restait toujours livide, grave, immobile et, pour tout dire, professorale : la tete d'un conferencier plantee sur le corps d'un arlequin.

eng: This outrageous chase sped across Ludgate Circus, up Ludgate Hill, round St. Paul's Cathedral, along Cheapside, Syme remembering all the nightmares he had ever known.
fr: Cette etrange course se continua sans repit a travers Ludgate-Circus, par Ludgate Hill, autour de la cathedrale de Saint-Paul, le long de Cheapside ; Syme croyait revivre tous les cauchemars oublies.

eng: Then Syme broke away towards the river, and ended almost down by the docks.
fr: Enfin, il se dirigea vers le fleuve et s'arreta tout pres des docks.

eng: He saw the yellow panes of a low, lighted public-house, flung himself into it and ordered beer.
fr: Il apercut les portes jaunes d'un bar illumine, s'y engouffra et commanda de la biere.

eng: It was a foul tavern, sprinkled with foreign sailors, a place where opium might be smoked or knives drawn.
fr: C'etait une taverne borgne, pleine de marins etrangers, un endroit, peut-etre, ou l'on fumait de l'opium, ou l'on jouait du couteau...

eng: A moment later Professor de Worms entered the place, sat down carefully, and asked for a glass of milk.
fr: L'instant d'apres le professeur de Worms entra, s'assit avec precaution, et commanda un verre de lait.

eng: If the man had one character as a paralytic and another character as a pursuer, the antithesis might make him more interesting, but scarcely more soothing.
fr: Qu'il eut le privilege de reunir en sa personne les deux caracteres du paralytique et du coureur, cela le rendait fort interessant, mais encore plus inquietant.

eng: It would be a very small comfort that he could not find the Professor out, if by some serious accident the Professor should find him out.
fr: La compensation serait mince, pour Syme, s'il parvenait a penetrer le mystere du professeur, pendant que, de son cote, le professeur lui arracherait son propre secret.

eng: "But perhaps I misunderstood the delicacies of your German philosophy. Perhaps policeman is a relative term. In an evolutionary sense, sir, the ape fades so gradually into the policeman, that I myself can never detect the shade. The monkey is only the policeman that may be. Perhaps a maiden lady on Clapham Common is only the policeman that might have been.'
fr: -- Peut-etre certaines finesses de votre philosophie teutonique m'echappent-elles ? Peut-etre, dans votre esprit, << policeman >> est-il un terme tout relatif ? Du point de vue de l'evolution, monsieur, le singe se transforme en policeman par des degres si insensibles, que je n'aurai sans doute pas percu toutes ces delicates nuances. Le singe est le policeman qui sera peut-etre un jour. La vieille fille de Clapham Common est peut-etre le policeman qu'elle aurait pu etre.

eng: The old Professor shook his head with a gravity that gave no hope, but Syme ran on with a feverish irony.
fr: Le vieux professeur branlait la tete avec une gravite desesperante. Syme reprit, sur un ton d'ironie febrile :

eng: Do, do let me be a postman."
fr: Pourquoi ne serais-je pas plutot un facteur ?

eng: "Did I take a policeman's hat by mistake out of the restaurant?" asked Syme, smiling wildly. "Have I by any chance got a number stuck on to me somewhere? Have my boots got that watchful look? Why must I be a policeman?
fr: -- Aurais-je pris par erreur, en quittant le restaurant, le chapeau d'un policeman ? Porte-je quelque part sur moi un numero ? Mes chaussures ont-elles cette physionomie vigilante qui caracterise celles de policiers ? Pourquoi serais-je un policeman ?

eng: "The process was simple enough," answered the Professor patiently. "I thought you looked like a policeman. I think so now."
fr: -- C'est tres simple, dit le professeur, avec insistance, vous avez l'air d'un policeman. Je l'ai vu tout de suite et je le vois encore.

eng: "A policeman?" he said, laughing vaguely.
fr: -- Un policeman ! Un policeman !

eng: "Whatever made you think of a policeman in connection with me?"
fr: Et il continuait de rire. Puis il reprit : -- Qu'y a-t-il donc en moi qui vous fasse penser a un policeman ?

eng: Whatever else Syme had expected, he had never expected anything so brutal and actual as this.
fr: Si pret a tout que fut Syme, il ne pouvait s'attendre a une telle question, si directe, si brutale.

eng: This incomprehensible man from the fierce council, after all, had certainly pursued him.
fr: Donc, et sans qu'aucun doute la-dessus fut possible, cet etre incomprehensible le poursuivait.

eng: When Gabriel Syme found himself finally established in a chair, and opposite to him, fixed and final also, the lifted eyebrows and leaden eyelids of the Professor, his fears fully returned.
fr: Quand il se trouva assis enfin et en face de lui les sourcils leves du professeur qui le regardait fixement sous ses paupieres plombees, Syme se sentit de nouveau pris de terreur.

eng: He emptied a whole pewter pot of ale before the professor had touched his milk.
fr: Syme avait deja vide son pot de biere : le verre de lait du professeur etait encore intact.

eng: One possibility, however, kept him hopeful and yet helpless.
fr: Une seule explication rassurante, mais si peu probable !

eng: Even his great presence of mind could only manage a reply with an air of rather blundering jocularity.
fr: Malgre toute sa presence d'esprit, il ne trouva sur le moment rien de mieux que de repeter, en eclatant de rire, d'un rire force :

eng: Perhaps it was some regular form or sign.
fr: peut-etre y avait-il la une sorte de rite, comme un signe de l'entree en fonctions du nouveau conseiller ;

eng: It was just possible that this escapade signified something other than even a slight suspicion of him.
fr: Peut-etre le poursuivait-on sans l'epier, a proprement parler, sans le soupconner ;

eng: Perhaps it was a ritual.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: Perhaps the new Thursday was always chased along Cheapside, as the new Lord Mayor is always escorted along it.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: He was just selecting a tentative inquiry, when the old Professor opposite suddenly and simply cut him short.
fr: Et Syme cherchait comment il pourrait bien entamer la conversation avec le vieux professeur, quand celui-ci lui adressa la parole.

eng: Before Syme could ask the first diplomatic question, the old anarchist had asked suddenly, without any sort of preparation "Are you a policeman?"
fr: Sans le moindre preambule, avant que Syme eut formule la question diplomatique qu'il venait enfin de trouver : -- Etes-vous un policeman ? lui demanda le vieil anarchiste.

eng: Perhaps the foolish scamper was some sort of friendly signal that he ought to have understood.
fr: peut-etre le nouveau Jeudi etait-il et devait-il etre ainsi poursuivi le long de Cheapside, ainsi que le nouveau lord-maire y est escorte.

eng: I don't mind being the policeman that might have been.
fr: Peu m'importe si j'ai l'aspect du policeman que j'aurais pu etre.

eng: He leant his angular elbow far across the table, and put up his large loose hand like a flap to his ear.
fr: 'Et il fit de sa main large ouverte un porte-voix a son oreille, comme pour ne rien perdre de la reponse attendue.'

eng: Professor de Worms fell back in his chair with a curious air of kindly collapse.
fr: 'Le professeur de Worms se laissa retomber sur sa chaise de l'air etrange d'un homme qui s'evanouit gentiment.'

eng: "I am not in the British police," said Syme with insane calm.
fr: '-- Je n'appartiens pas a la police britannique, articula Syme avec le calme de la folie.'

eng: Will there really be no mistake? You are an anarchist, you are a dynamiter! Above all, you are not in any sense a detective? You are not in the British police?
fr: 'Pas d'erreur entre nous, n'est-ce pas ! Vous etes bien un anarchiste ! Vous etes bien un dynamiteur et non pas un detective ! Vous n'appartenez en aucune facon a la police britannique !'

eng: "I don't mind being anything in German thought."
fr: 'Peu m'importe d'etre quoi que ce soit selon la philosophie allemande...'

eng: "You swear it! You swear it!
fr: 'Vous le jurez ? ~~~ repeta le professeur.'

eng: "You swear it," said the old man, leaning across to him, his dead face becoming as it were loathsomely alive.
fr: '-- Vous le jurez ? ~~~ dit le vieillard en s'accoudant sur la table, et son regard prit soudain une intensite menacante.'

eng: "No!" answered Syme, like a man standing on the hangman's drop.
fr: '-- Non ! repondit Syme, avec l'accent d'un homme qui serait sur le point d'etre pendu.'

eng: "Are you, or are you not, a police detective?"
fr: 'etes-vous un detective, oui ou non ?'

eng: "Did you hear me ask a plain question, you pattering spy?" he shrieked in a high, crazy voice.
fr: '-- Vous avez entendu ma question, espion trembleur ! fit-il d'une voix rauque : etes-vous un detective, oui ou non ?'

eng: The old man struck his palsied hand passionately on the rickety table, nearly breaking it.
fr: 'Le vieillard frappa de sa main paralysee la table bancale, qui chancela.'

eng: "Your suggestion is ridiculous," he began. "Why on earth..."
fr: '-- Votre supposition est ridicule, dit-il, pourquoi, jamais...?...'

eng: Syme's heart turned to stone, but his face never changed.
fr: 'Le coeur de Syme cessa de battre, mais son visage ne changea pas d'expression.'

eng: "Are you a detective?"
fr: 'Etes-vous un detective ?'

eng: "Are you in the police service?" said the old man, ignoring all Syme's improvised and desperate raillery.
fr: '-- Etes-vous au service de la police ? interrogea froidement le vieillard, qui n'avait pas meme ecoute les plaisanteries improvisees et desesperees de Syme.'

eng: If you swear falsely, will you be damned? Will you be sure that the devil dances at your funeral? Will you see that the nightmare sits on your grave?
fr: 'Si vous vous parjurez, savez-vous que vous serez damne ? Savez-vous que le diable dansera a votre enterrement ? Savez-vous que le grand cauchemar vous attend deja au bord de votre tombe ?'

eng: "That's a pity," he said, "because I am."
fr: -- C'est dommage, dit-il, car, moi, j'en suis.

eng: He knew simultaneously that he was a fool and a free man.
fr: Et il constata avec plaisir qu'il etait lui-meme un sot et un homme libre.

eng: This devil from whom he had been fleeing all day was only an elder brother of his own house, who on the other side of the table lay back and laughed at him.
fr: Ce diable qu'il avait fui des heures durant, voila que c'etait un frere aine ! Et il considerait avec stupeur ce bon diable qui, lui-meme, le considerait en riant.

eng: Syme sprang up straight, sending back the bench behind him with a crash.
fr: Syme se dressa en faisant choir bruyamment son banc.

eng: "Because you are what?" he said thickly. "You are what?"
fr: Vous etes quoi ? murmura-t-il d'une voix tremblante. Qu'etes-vous ?

eng: "I am a policeman," said the Professor with his first broad smile, and beaming through his spectacles.
fr: Un policeman, dit le professeur, qui sourit pour la premiere fois, tandis que ses yeux rayonnaient derriere ses lunettes.

eng: "But as you think policeman only a relative term, of course I have nothing to do with you. I am in the British police force; but as you tell me you are not in the British police force, I can only say that I met you in a dynamiters' club. I suppose I ought to arrest you."
fr: Puisque vous estimez que le mot policeman n'a qu'un sens relatif, nous ne pouvons nous entendre. Je suis de la police britannique et vous n'en etes pas. Je n'ai donc qu'une chose a vous dire : je vous ai rencontre dans un club de dynamiteurs, et je pense que mon devoir est de vous arreter.

eng: And with these words he laid on the table before Syme an exact facsimile of the blue card which Syme had in his own waistcoat pocket, the symbol of his power from the police.
fr: Et il deposa sur la table l'exact fac-simile de la carte bleue que Syme portait dans la poche de son gilet.

eng: Syme had for a flash the sensation that the cosmos had turned exactly upside down, that all trees were growing downwards and that all stars were under his feet.
fr: Syme eut, un instant, l'impression que l'univers avait fait un demi-tour sur lui-meme, que les arbres poussaient vers le sol et qu'il avait les etoiles sous ses pieds.

eng: Then came slowly the opposite conviction. For the last twenty-four hours the cosmos had really been upside down, but now the capsized universe had come right side up again.
fr: Puis, peu a peu, il revint a la conviction contraire : pendant les dernieres vingt-quatre heures l'univers etait retourne sens dessus dessous, et c'etait maintenant, tout a coup, qu'il reprenait son equilibre.

eng: He did not for the moment ask any questions of detail; he only knew the happy and silly fact that this shadow, which had pursued him with an intolerable oppression of peril, was only the shadow of a friend trying to catch him up.
fr: Il ne fit aucune question. ~~~ Il ne s'enquit d'aucun detail. Il se contenta du fait indeniable et heureux que cette ombre tant redoutee etait devenue bienfaisante.

eng: For with any recovery from morbidity there must go a certain healthy humiliation.
fr: On a toujours, dans toutes les convalescences, ce sentiment de saine humiliation.

eng: There comes a certain point in such conditions when only three things are possible: first a perpetuation of Satanic pride, secondly tears, and third laughter.
fr: Dans ces crises, il vient un moment ou il faut choisir entre trois choses : ou bien on s'obstine dans un orgueil satanique, ou bien on pleure, ou bien on rit.

eng: Syme's egotism held hard to the first course for a few seconds, and then suddenly adopted the third.
fr: L'egotisme de Syme fit qu'il s'arreta d'abord au premier parti, puis, sans transition, il adopta le troisieme.

eng: Taking his own blue police ticket from his own waist coat pocket, he tossed it on to the table; then he flung his head back until his spike of yellow beard almost pointed at the ceiling, and shouted with a barbaric laughter.
fr: Tirant de la poche de son gilet sa propre carte bleue, il la jeta, lui aussi, sur la table, puis il leva la tete de telle facon que la pointe de sa barbe menacait le ciel, et il eclata de rire, d'un rire de barbare.

eng: Even in that close den, perpetually filled with the din of knives, plates, cans, clamorous voices, sudden struggles and stampedes, there was something Homeric in Syme's mirth which made many half-drunken men look round.
fr: Meme dans cette taverne peu sonore, ou l'on n'entendait guere que le bruit des couteaux, des assiettes, des pots et des voix avinees, le rire homerique de Syme retentit si fort que plusieurs individus ivres a moitie se retournerent.

eng: "What yer laughing at, guv'nor?" asked one wondering labourer from the docks.
fr: -- De quoi riez-vous, monsieur ? demanda un debardeur.

eng: "At myself," answered Syme, and went off again into the agony of his ecstatic reaction.
fr: -- De moi-meme, repondit Syme, et il s'abandonna de nouveau a son acces de folle hilarite.

eng: "Pull yourself together," said the Professor, "or you'll get hysterical. Have some more beer. I'll join you."
fr: -- Revenez a vous, conseilla le professeur, vous allez avoir une crise de nerfs ! Demandez encore de la biere. Je vais en faire autant.

eng: "You haven't drunk your milk," said Syme.
fr: -- Vous n'avez pas bu votre lait, observa Syme.

eng: "My milk!"
fr: -- Mon lait !

eng: said the other, in tones of withering and unfathomable contempt, "my milk!
fr: fit l'autre avec un mepris insondable, mon lait !

eng: Do you think I'd look at the beastly stuff when I'm out of sight of the bloody anarchists?
fr: Pensez-vous que je daigne jamais jeter un regard sur cette drogue quand ces maudits anarchistes ne me voient pas ?

eng: Finish my milk? Great blazes! yes, I'll finish it right enough!
fr: Boire ce lait ! Dieu du ciel ! Attendez...

eng: We're all Christians in this room, though perhaps," he added, glancing around at the reeling crowd, "not strict ones.
fr: 'Nous sommes entre chretiens, ici, quoique tous, continua-t-il en examinant la foule des consommateurs, ne soient pas de la plus stricte observance.

eng: He laughed at the idea of the paralytic Professor being really a young actor dressed up as if for the foot-lights.
fr: Il s'egayait a penser que le vieux professeur etait, en realite, un jeune comedien, grime comme au moment de paraitre sur la scene.

eng: Syme's laughter at all this had about it a wild weakness of relief.
fr: Syme rit encore.

eng: "Yes," answered the other dispassionately. "I am subject to colds."
fr: -- Si, repondit l'autre, flegmatiquement, je suis sujet aux rhumes.

eng: "I understand now," he cried; "of course, you're not an old man at all."
fr: -- Je comprends maintenant ! ~~~ s'ecria-t-il. Naturellement, vous n'etes pas du tout un vieillard.

eng: I was thirty-eight last birthday."
fr: Lors de mon dernier anniversaire, j'avais trente-huit ans.

eng: As to whether I'm an old man, that's not for me to say.
fr: Quant a savoir si je suis un vieillard, ce n'est pas a moi d'en juger.

eng: "I can't take my face off here," replied Professor de Worms. "It's rather an elaborate make-up.
fr: -- Je ne puis oter ma << figure >> ici, repliqua le professeur : c'est une machine plutot compliquee.

eng: "Yes, but I mean," said Syme impatiently, "there's nothing the matter with you."
fr: -- Et vous n'etes pas malade non plus.

eng: Syme was staring at him with a happy curiosity.
fr: Syme le contemplait avec sympathie.

eng: and he knocked the tumbler off the table, making a crash of glass and a splash of silver fluid.
fr: Et il fit tomber le verre, qui se brisa bruyamment en repandant le liquide argente.

eng: But he felt that he would have laughed as loudly if a pepperpot had fallen over.
fr: Mais il sentait qu'il aurait ri d'aussi bon coeur si un moutardier s'etait renverse sur la table.

eng: The false Professor drank and wiped his false beard. ~~~ "Did you know," he asked, "that that man Gogol was one of us?"
fr: Le faux professeur vida son verre de biere, puis, passant sa main dans sa barbe : -- Saviez-vous, demanda-t-il, que ce Gogol fut des notres ?
-- Moi ?

eng: "Who would condescend to strike down the mere things that he does not fear? Who would debase himself to be merely brave, like any common prizefighter? Who would stoop to be fearless like a tree? Fight the thing that you fear."
fr: -- Qui donc condescendrait a frapper seulement les etres dont il n'a pas peur ? Qui donc voudrait etre brave a la facon d'un lutteur forain ! Qui donc voudrait ignorer la peur, comme un arbre ? Il faut lutter contre ceux que l'on craint.

eng: "Professor," he cried, "it is intolerable. Are you afraid of this man?"
fr: -- Professeur ! s'ecria-t-il, cela n'est pas tolerable ! Auriez-vous peur de cet homme ?

eng: "Because I am afraid of him," said Syme; "and no man should leave in the universe anything of which he is afraid."
fr: -- Precisement parce que j'ai peur de lui. ~~~ On ne doit pas laisser vivre un etre dont on a peur.

eng: "Why?"
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "How?" asked the staring Professor.
fr: -- Comment ? demanda le professeur, et pourquoi ?

eng: "Yes," he said in a voice indescribable, "you are right. I am afraid of him. Therefore I swear by God that I will seek out this man whom I fear until I find him, and strike him on the mouth. If heaven were his throne and the earth his footstool, I swear that I would pull him down."
fr: -- Vous avez raison, commenca-t-il d'une voix que rien ne peut rendre, j'ai peur de lui. C'est pourquoi je jure devant Dieu que je chercherai cet homme et que je le frapperai sur la bouche. Quand le ciel serait son trone et la terre son tabouret, je jure que je l'en arracherai.

eng: Syme was dumb for an instant. Then he rose to his feet erect, like an insulted man, and thrust the chair away from him.
fr: Syme, d'abord, resta muet. Mais, se dressant soudain de toute sa hauteur, comme un homme insulte, il repoussa violemment sa chaise :

eng: "Yes, I am," he said mildly. "So are you."
fr: -- Oui, dit-il doucement, et vous aussi.

eng: The Professor lifted his heavy lids, and gazed at Syme with large, wide-open, blue eyes of an almost ethereal honesty.
fr: Le professeur leva ses lourdes paupieres et appuya sur Syme le regard de ses yeux bleus, grands ouverts, ou se lisait une franchise etheree.

eng: De Worms blinked at him with a sort of blind wonder. He made an effort to speak, but Syme went on in a low voice, but with an undercurrent of inhuman exaltation
fr: Le professeur de Worms lorgna Syme et fit un effort pour parler. Mais Syme reprit aussitot, a voix basse mais avec une exaltation continue :

eng: The face of the unforgettable President sprang into his mind as startling as a coloured photograph, and he remarked this difference between Sunday and all his satellites, that their faces, however fierce or sinister, became gradually blurred by memory like other human faces, whereas Sunday's seemed almost to grow more actual during absence, as if a man's painted portrait should slowly come alive.
fr: Les traits de l'inoubliable President se presenterent a son imagination avec toute la nettete d'une photographie en couleurs. Et il remarqua cette difference entre Dimanche et ses satellites, que leurs visages, si feroces qu'ils fussent, s'etaient peu a peu estompes deja dans sa memoire, tandis que celui de Dimanche y restait present avec l'inalterable energie de la realite. Bien plus, l'absence semblait le rendre plus energique et vivant encore. C'etait comme un portrait qui s'eveillerait a la vie.

eng: "No," said the Professor with sobriety, "not if we were three hundred against Sunday."
fr: Non, repondit le professeur, trois cents hommes ne pourraient venir a bout de Dimanche.

eng: "No, I didn't know it," answered Syme in some surprise.
fr: 'Non, je ne savais pas, repondit Syme avec surprise.

eng: "But didn't you?"
fr: Mais, vous, l'ignoriez-vous donc ?

eng: "I knew no more than the dead," replied the man who called himself de Worms.
fr: Je n'en savais pas plus la-dessus que les morts du cimetiere.

eng: "I thought the President was talking about me, and I rattled in my boots."
fr: Je croyais que le President voulait parler de moi, et je tremblais dans mes bottes.

eng: "And I thought he was talking about me," said Syme, with his rather reckless laughter.
fr: Et moi de meme !

eng: They were both silent for a measure of moments, and then Syme's speech came with a rush, like the sudden foaming of champagne.
fr: Ils resterent silencieux pendant quelques instants. Puis Syme parla, et ce fut comme la mousse qui s'echappe d'une bouteille de champagne.

eng: "I had my hand on my revolver all the time."
fr: Je croyais qu'il parlait de moi ! Tout le temps, j'avais la main sur mon revolver.

eng: And the mere name struck Syme cold and serious; his laughter had died in his heart before it could die on his lips.
fr: A ce seul nom, Syme redevint subitement grave. Le rire etait mort dans son coeur avant d'expirer sur ses levres.

eng: Syme struck the table with an exclamation.
fr: Syme frappa du poing la table :

eng: "Not if we were three hundred against four?" asked Syme, jeering rather boisterously.
fr: -- Comment ? fit Syme interloque, a trois cents contre quatre.

eng: "If we had been three hundred we could still have done nothing."
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: "We were three," he said.
fr: Eussions-nous ete trois cents, dit-il, nous ne pouvions rien.

eng: The face of Professor de Worms darkened, and he did not look up.
fr: La figure du professeur s'assombrit ; il baissa les yeux.

eng: "Three out of seven is a fighting number. If we had only known that we were three!"
fr: Trois contre quatre, on peut se battre ! Si nous avions su que nous etions trois !

eng: "So had I," said the Professor grimly; "so had Gogol evidently."
fr: C'est ce que je faisais aussi, dit le professeur, et c'est evidemment ce que faisait aussi Gogol.

eng: "Why, there were three of us there!" he cried.
fr: -- Trois ! s'ecria-t-il, nous etions trois !

eng: You remember the old tale of the English clergyman who gave the last rites to the brigand of Sicily, and how on his death-bed the great robber said, I can give you no money, but I can give you advice for a lifetime: your thumb on the blade, and strike upwards.'
fr: Vous souvient-il de cette vieille histoire d'un clergyman anglais qui administrait les derniers sacrements a un brigand sicilien ? ~~~ Le grand detrousseur, a son lit de mort, dit au ministre : << Je n'ai pas d'argent a vous donner, mais voici un avis qui pourra toujours vous etre utile : Le pouce sur la lame, et frappez de bas en haut !

eng: ""Will you tell me?" asked Syme with eager eyes."
fr: "Me le direz-vous ?"

eng: ""Yes," said the other in his curious, absent-minded way, "I know where he is myself.""
fr: "Si, dit l'autre, de sa maniere etrange et distraite ; pour moi, je sais ou le prendre."

eng: ""And we don't know where he is.""
fr: "Et nous ne savons ou le prendre ?"

eng: ""Confound it!" cried Syme."
fr: "Malheur !"

eng: ""I will take you there," said the Professor, and took down his own hat from a peg."
fr: "Je vous y menerai, dit le professeur en decrochant son chapeau de la patere."

eng: ""You remember, of course," resumed the soi-disant de Worms, pulling his beard and looking out of the window, "that when we broke up rather hurriedly the whole arrangements for the atrocity were left in the private hands of the Marquis and Dr. Bull."
fr: "Vous vous rappelez, reprit le professeur en se tirant la barbe et en regardant par la fenetre d'un air desinteresse, qu'un peu avant de lever si precipitamment la seance, Dimanche avait confie tous les preparatifs de l'attentat au docteur Bull et au marquis."

eng: "So I say to you, strike upwards, if you strike at the stars."
fr: "L'avis est bon, en effet : frappez de bas en haut, si vous voulez atteindre les etoiles !"

eng: "The other looked at the ceiling, one of the tricks of his pose."
fr: "Dimanche est une etoile fixe, dit le professeur, le regard au plafond."

eng: ""Sunday is a fixed star," he said."
fr: "Dimanche est une etoile fixe, dit le professeur, le regard au plafond."

eng: ""You shall see him a falling star," said Syme, and put on his hat."
fr: "Vous verrez que ce sera une etoile filante et tombee, conclut Syme en prenant son chapeau."

eng: "The decision of his gesture drew the Professor vaguely to his feet."
fr: "La decision de ce geste determina le professeur a se lever."

eng: ""Have you any idea," he asked, with a sort of benevolent bewilderment, "exactly where you are going?"
fr: "Avez-vous une idee ? demanda-t-il avec bienveillance. Savez-vous exactement ou vous allez ?"

eng: "The Marquis is by this time probably crossing the Channel. But where he will go and what he will do it is doubtful whether even the President knows; certainly we don't know."
fr: "En ce moment, le marquis, probablement, est en train de passer le detroit. Mais, que fera-t-il et ou ira-t-il ? On peut douter que Dimanche lui-meme le sache. Ce qui est sur, c'est que nous l'ignorons."

eng: "The only man who does know is Dr. Bull."
fr: "Le seul homme qui soit au courant de l'affaire, c'est le docteur Bull."

eng: ""Yes," replied Syme shortly, "I am going to prevent this bomb being thrown in Paris.""
fr: "Oui, repondit Syme tres vite. Je vais les empecher de jeter leur bombe a Paris !"

eng: ""Have you any conception how?" inquired the other."
fr: "Vous avez un moyen ?"

eng: ""No," said Syme with equal decision."
fr: "Non. Syme ne voyait aucun moyen ; il n'en etait pas moins tres decide."

eng: Syme stood looking at him with a sort of rigid excitement.
fr: Syme le considerait, immobile a force d'etre febrile.

eng: Most of the snow was melted or trampled to mud,
fr: 'La neige fondue s'etait changee en boue.'

eng: "Young man," said the Professor pleasantly, "I am amused to observe that you think I am a coward.  As to that I will say only one word, and that shall be entirely in the manner of your own philosophical rhetoric. You think that it is possible to pull down the President. I know that it is impossible, and I am going to try it,"
fr: 'Jeune homme, repondit le professeur avec gaite, je vois que vous me prenez pour un lache, et cela m'amuse. Je ne vous dirai qu'un mot, un mot tout a fait dans le gout de votre rhetorique philosophique : vous croyez qu'il est possible d'abattre le President ; je sais que c'est impossible, et je vais essayer de le faire.'

eng: "Will you take the risk?"
fr: 'Partagerez-vous les risques avec moi ?'

eng: "Will you join me?"
fr: 'M'accompagnerez-vous ?'

eng: "What do you mean?" he asked sharply.
fr: '-- Que voulez-vous dire ?'

eng: and opening the tavern door, which let in a blast of bitter air, they went out together into the dark streets by the docks.
fr: 'Il ouvrit la porte de la taverne. Une bouffee d'air marin penetra dans la salle. Les deux detectives prirent l'une des rues sombres qui avoisinent les docks.'

eng: but here and there a clot of it still showed grey rather than white in the gloom.
fr: 'Par places, dans le crepuscule, par petits tas, elle faisait des taches grises plutot que blanches.'

eng: The small streets were sloppy and full of pools, which reflected the flaming lamps irregularly, and by accident, like fragments of some other and fallen world.
fr: Dans des flaques d'eau se reflechissaient irregulierement les lumieres des reverberes, comme des clartes emanees d'un autre monde.

eng: Even as he stared, the highest light in this innumerably lighted turret abruptly went out, as if this black Argus had winked at him with one of his innumerable eyes.
fr: Juste en cet instant, la lumiere la plus haute de cette tour aux innombrables yeux s'eteignit brusquement, comme si ce noir Argus avait cligne de l'une de ses paupieres.

eng: "Where are you going?" Syme inquired.
fr: -- Ou allons-nous ? demanda Syme.

eng: "No," answered his friend. "As a matter of fact he lives some way off, on the other side of the river, but we can tell from here whether he has gone to bed."
fr: -- Non. Il habite assez loin, de l'autre cote du fleuve. Mais, d'ici, nous pourrons voir s'il est couche.

eng: "Does he live round the corner?"
fr: -- Le docteur habite ici ?

eng: "Dr. Bull!" exclaimed Syme.
fr: (No direct equivalent in text)

eng: On the Surrey side at this point there ran out into the Thames, seeming almost to overhang it, a bulk and cluster of those tall tenements, dotted with lighted windows, and rising like factory chimneys to an almost insane height.
fr: C'etait cette masse de hautes maisons, pointillees de fenetres eclairees, qu'on voit, du cote de Surrey, s'elever, comme des cheminees d'usine, a des hauteurs insensees.

eng: Their special poise and position made one block of buildings especially look like a Tower of Babel with a hundred eyes.
fr: En particulier, un corps de batiment semblait une Tour de Babel aux cent yeux.

eng: but his companion walked on with a certain briskness, towards where, at the end of the street, an inch or two of the lamplit river looked like a bar of flame.
fr: Mais son compagnon se dirigeait, d'un pas assez rapide, vers l'extremite de la rue, ou le fleuve, illumine par les lampes, faisait comme une boue de flamme.

eng: Syme felt almost dazed as he stepped through this growing confusion of lights and shadows;
fr: Syme eprouva une sorte d'etourdissement en penetrant dans cette confusion de lumieres et d'arbres.

eng: Syme had never seen any of the sky-scraping buildings in America, so he could only think of the buildings in a dream.
fr: Syme n'avait jamais vu les skyscrapers americains ; aussi ne songea-t-il, devant ce gigantesque batiment, qu'aux tours dont il avait reve.

eng: Turning the corner as he spoke, and facing the dim river, flecked with flame, he pointed with his stick to the other bank.
fr: Tout en parlant, ils atteignirent l'endroit que designait le professeur. Celui-ci, de sa canne, montra, par-dela la nappe tachee de lumiere, la rive opposee.

eng: "Just now," answered the Professor, "I am going just round the corner to see whether Dr. Bull has gone to bed. He is hygienic, and retires early."
fr: -- Nous allons tourner le coin et voir si le docteur Bull est deja couche. ~~~ Il se couche tot. Il a un grand respect pour les lois de l'hygiene.

eng: Professor de Worms swung round on his heel, and struck his stick against his boot. ~~~ "We are too late," he said, "the hygienic Doctor has gone to bed."
fr: Le professeur de Worms pirouetta sur son talon et frappa sa botte de sa canne : -- Nous arrivons trop tard ; le prudent docteur est couche.

eng: "What do you mean?"
fr: -- Qu'est-ce a dire ?

eng: asked Syme.
fr: demanda Syme.

eng: "Does he live over there, then?"
fr: Est-ce qu'il habite la-bas ?

eng: "Yes," said de Worms, "behind that particular window which you can't see.
fr: -- Oui, precisement derriere cette fenetre que vous ne pouvez plus voir.

eng: Come along and get some dinner.
fr: Venez, allons souper.

eng: We must call on him tomorrow morning.
fr: Nous irons le voir demain matin.

eng: Without further parley, he led the way through several by-ways until they came out into the flare and clamour of the East India Dock Road.
fr: Ils suivirent plusieurs ruelles et gagnerent les lumieres et le bruit d'East India Dock Road.

eng: The Professor, who seemed to know his way about the neighbourhood, proceeded to a place where the line of lighted shops fell back into a sort of abrupt twilight and quiet, in which an old white inn, all out of repair, stood back some twenty feet from the road.
fr: Le professeur, qui paraissait bien connaitre ces parages, se dirigea vers un endroit ou la ligne illuminee des boutiques etait subitement brisee par un bloc d'ombre et de silence.

eng: "You can find good English inns left by accident everywhere, like fossils," explained the Professor.
fr: -- On trouve un peu partout, expliqua le professeur de Worms, de bons vieux hotels anglais abandonnes comme des fossiles.

eng: "I once found a decent place in the West End."
fr: Il m'est arrive de decouvrir un hotel tres convenable dans le West End.

eng: "I suppose," said Syme, smiling, "that this is the corresponding decent place in the East End?"
fr: -- Je pense, dit Syme en souriant, que voici le pendant de celui-ci dans l'East End.

eng: Through all this ordeal his root horror had been isolation,
fr: Tout au long de cette epreuve, sa crainte la plus vive avait ete de rester isole.

eng: "It is," said the Professor reverently, and went in.
